Subject: [sfraves] BSP: [[[ *~STILLDREAM~* ]]] Just around the corner - Tickets in stores now!

[[[[[[ *~STILLDREAM~* ]]]]]]
--5 Year Anniversary Campout--
June 17, 18 and 19th of the year 2005

The Stilldream Collective is ready to celebrate their 5 Year Anniversary of
amazing music under the stars.  They have been working hard for the last 6
months to ensure this is going to be the best Stilldream Event of ALL time.
We want you to be there, come be part of the Stilldream Experience!

100% Confirmed Line-Up!!!

The Attack People, LIVE!
www.abiotic.net / Mankind - Minneapolis, MN
It's our pleasure to welcome for the first time At a Stilldream Event, one
of the best and fastest growing acts in the United States. Thick driving
bass meets aggressive percussion. Lush analog sounds creating moody
atmospheres. The music is heavy yet groovy. Contrasting from one extreme to
the other with ease. This is The Attack People. They are the Sound of the
Future!

Dig-Dug
USC Events, Seattle
For over 7 years, DJ Dig-Dug has been a resident DJ for the Northwests
largest electronic music event production company, USC Events. his
underlying themes of warped basslines and intelligent drum loops bring a
sense of unity to his signature sound.   DJ Dig-Dug has developed a
following based on skillsnot hype.   Get Ready!

Treavor
www.Moontribe.org, Sound of Mind - SF
While most DJs are focused on one type of electronica, Treavor is known to
make the barriers between Techno, Trance, House and Breaks seem non-existent
often fusing them into one set. This keeps Treavor one step ahead and allows
him to be able to play any time of the night at any event.  Be Prepared for
the Treavor Experience!

Mystre (www.djmystre.com, Reverb Records - SF)
Dyloot (www.skillsdj.com, Deep Voices - Berkley
Serch (www.theserch.com, www.m13graphics.com - Chicago)
Nick Tornetta (Future Tracks, www.nicktornetta.com - Seattle)
Detonate (Good Beat, www.klubstompers.com - Seattle)
Sarah Shoxx (Shoxx Wear, www.klubstompers.com - Seattle)

Effendi (www.klubstompers.com - Seattle)
Icon (www.djicon.com, Reverb - SF)
B-Smarter (Equalize, Sparxx - Seattle)
Michael Liu (www.illuminationrecords.com, San Jose)
Mubali (Mistress of Evil Recs, Trishula Recs, Germany)
Dirt (www.techno-truth.com, Cymbalic Records, SF)

Stilldream Collective
(www.stilldream.org):

Mek

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) Quote of the Day (Wed)

well, i just spent 2 hours downloading all my emails from the middle of
april to the present down to FogBook ... so i'll probably spend the next
month and a half re-reading (and closely analyzing) every email sent to
sfraves and i'll be making reports to osby, the acting gatekeeper of san
francisco.  so be good!  or if you haven't, make sure you keep yourself in
check.

... and there is another gatekeeper watching over all you, making sure
you're tuned into the cultural side of life and scoffing at you when
you're not.  so be cultured, too!  trust me, it's worth it!

now i've almost collected a week's worth of "sfraver" quotes, so if you
have any, send them to me privately (not the list) so we can surprise
everyone!  muwahhahahaha!

Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org,
 Eleanor Judis <ellerockit@yahoo.com>
From: John B <SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com>
Date: Wed, 1 Jun 2005 17:30:05 -0700
To: Bam <invibe@gmail.com>
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.622)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] skillz party- im confused

Well....  it was fairly standard Skills.  Excellent production value, 
but with a somewhat bland (IMHO) standard trance/house/jungle lineup.  
Sound was excellent and well-run.  They didn't do too much in the way 
of decorations.... just some banners and the cutouts of the Skills 
robots.  But the lighting was downright badass.  And every time I go 
back to that venue, I like it more and more.

The main attraction for me, though, was all of the people I hardly get 
to see anymore, but they'll still come out for the Skills parties.  I 
swear... for the first half of the party I spent as much time in the 
entrance foyer area seeing which old friend would show up next as I did 
in any of the rooms.  That, and the buzz amongst us about Imagine was 
almost intoxicating itself.  The first two people I saw when I got in 
were Alison and Kristie, and Duckee was not far behind.  Good times.

The main room got somewhat overcrowded.  But I think if the total 
attendance had been spread over the three rooms, they'd all have been 
fine.  But the house room was only half as populated as the main, and 
the downstairs room was almost deserted every time I ventured there.

Overall, I had a great time and think I got my money's worth; 
especially since I was already on my way towards the door when the 
party got shut down.  Though I *DID* get the early $25 presales, not 
the fifty-something dollar door tix.

As for the fire alarms going off, that's about right.... though 
depending on who I asked, there was some disagreement on wether it was 
a singular dumbass who actually pulled the handle, or a bunch of 
collective dumbasses smoking where they shouldn't have been.  (And yes, 
Skills *DID* provide an outdoor smoking area, so there's no excusing 
the selfish and disrespectful asswipes who were smoking *inside* the 
venue (Even if it turns out they weren't the ones who set off the 
alarms.)).


cya,
john

Subject: Re: [sfraves] skillz party- im confused

that's kinda sad to hear that the rooms didn't get equal coverage as
far as people.  i'm still shocked that this party totally sold out
4,500 people before the day of the event.  skills seems to be doing
something right in their marketting.

the house and dnb lineups seemed solid to me.  is trance still that
popular among that crowd?  i guess it is.

even if you went for the trance...would you not be interested in
hopping to other rooms to check out the other music?

i guess my only comment about the house lineup is that it's the same
house lineup they always have.  i mean, how many times does Doc, Dan
and Donald come through SF?

-b

On 6/1/05, John B <SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com> wrote:
> Well....  it was fairly standard Skills.  Excellent production value,
> but with a somewhat bland (IMHO) standard trance/house/jungle lineup.
> Sound was excellent and well-run.  They didn't do too much in the way
> of decorations.... just some banners and the cutouts of the Skills
> robots.  But the lighting was downright badass.  And every time I go
> back to that venue, I like it more and more.
>=20
> The main attraction for me, though, was all of the people I hardly get
> to see anymore, but they'll still come out for the Skills parties.  I
> swear... for the first half of the party I spent as much time in the
> entrance foyer area seeing which old friend would show up next as I did
> in any of the rooms.  That, and the buzz amongst us about Imagine was
> almost intoxicating itself.  The first two people I saw when I got in
> were Alison and Kristie, and Duckee was not far behind.  Good times.
>=20
> The main room got somewhat overcrowded.  But I think if the total
> attendance had been spread over the three rooms, they'd all have been
> fine.  But the house room was only half as populated as the main, and
> the downstairs room was almost deserted every time I ventured there.
>=20
> Overall, I had a great time and think I got my money's worth;
> especially since I was already on my way towards the door when the
> party got shut down.  Though I *DID* get the early $25 presales, not
> the fifty-something dollar door tix.
>=20
> As for the fire alarms going off, that's about right.... though
> depending on who I asked, there was some disagreement on wether it was
> a singular dumbass who actually pulled the handle, or a bunch of
> collective dumbasses smoking where they shouldn't have been.  (And yes,
> Skills *DID* provide an outdoor smoking area, so there's no excusing
> the selfish and disrespectful asswipes who were smoking *inside* the
> venue (Even if it turns out they weren't the ones who set off the
> alarms.)).
>=20
>=20
> cya,
> john
>=20
>=20

From: Other World <otherworld_sfr@yahoo.com>

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] *BSP*  Depth Charge  6/4  w/ Sutekh, Jeno,  Dragn'fly vs. Amber, Azeem ...

Otherworld, Coil, & Radiant Atmospheres
proudly present
++++ DEPTH CHARGE ++++
Saturday, June 4, 2005
more info 510 287 5917

UNLEASH YOUR INNER KRAKEN

When they've had enough rum, the old-timers sing
the tale of the last voyage of the Jiggletech,
a noble submarine. Weighing anchor, she drifted from
port and set out in search of the Other World, an
undersea grotto of kinky pyramids and giant pearls.

  Dj Jeno (Wicked)
  http://www.djjeno.com/

  Sutekh (Force Inc. / Mille Plateaux / Context)
  http://www.context.fm/artists_sutekh.html

  Dragnfly vs. Amber
  (lovetribe / sister sf / iamthedj.com)
  http://www.djdragnfly.com
  http://www.iamthedj.com/music.html

  Ethan vs. Donna Matrix (FnF / newsBREAKZ)
  http://www.bass-station.com/ethan/audio
  http://www.newsbreakz.org

  Reid Oda (Aranji / Looq Records)
  http://www.orangeage.com

  -db- (FnF)

Fearing the pleasures this might unleash, a squadron
of black helicopters intercepted the vessel at the
horizon's edge. The good ship dove for the ocean floor
as depth charges rained down from the sky! Relentless
sonic pressures pounded her hull with each detonation,
discharging waves of unending acoustical force.
Her hatches battened, her bulkheads sealed,
the Jiggletech drifted deeper.

  Azeem live hip hop
  (Future Primitive / Wide Hive / Oaklyn Records)
  http://www.widehive.com/azeem.html

  Mark Stretch (Foreign Legion / Look Records)
  http://www.lookrecords.com/marcstretch

  Barefoot (Aranji)
  http://www.orangeage.com

  Mozaic (13moontribe / djmozaic.net)
  http://www.djmozaic.net

  Origami vs. Cubik (newstylesound.com / Moksha Tribe)
  http://newstylesound.com

Beyond the reach of sunlight, the Jiggletech
found herself embraced by the coiling tentacles
of a radiant squid. Gently, this leviathan
deposited its catch on the sandy sea bottom.

  Tom Thump (Throwdown / Milk / Kinkysweet Records)
  http://www.tomthump.com

  Joe Rice (Justice League / FnF)
  http://www.justiceleague.com/agents/joe.html

  Monty Luke (DHP / FnF)
  http://www.justiceleague.com/tsm/blog

  drjd (SLA, Koinonea)
  http://i5tribe.org/dr.jd

  Redstickman (Ambient Mafia / Moksha Tribe)
  http://redstickman.homestead.com/redstickman.html

  Mr. Band live

Having jaws but no gills, the submarine's divers
ventured curiously out through the hatch, snorkles
in hand, masks and tanks at the ready. What they
found was no inky abyss; all around them were
Nereids, Neptunes and shape-shifting sea-nymphs --
a deep water garden of coral and bubbles,
beautifully lit by the phosphorescence of the
benevolent squid.

  BRAIN-BENDING SUPER-COLOSSAL LIGHTING
  by Coil & Radiant Atmospheres
  with special guest Mang on the Diskovision

  PRECISION PRESSURES
  by Know:Audio, Gateway Systems & Thick Sound

  ALTARED REALITIES by the Minx

  AQUATIC INSTALLATIONS by Marin

Scuttling her butt in this clamshell of love,
the Jiggletech never returned.

  DEPTH CHARGE 06.04.05
  more info 510 287 5917
  http://www.otherworld.ws
  http://www.redolent.org

  $12 @ the door  
  *West Oakland location 
  (call day of event for directions)

Protect your right to party. Do not post this
invitation on other lists.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Question du Jour: What brought you to SFRaves?

i subscribed to the calendar before i subbed to the list.  i'm trying
to remember how i found the calendar though.  maybe it was linked from
another site?  maybe i did a search for "raves san francisco" or
something.

so anyway, i was subbed to the calendar but i knew shit about parties.
 and i never knew where to go, so i subbed to the list and was a
lurker for several months before i ever posted.

i think i probably posted up things like "omg i love trance!" and
"does anyone know where i can buy candy beads cuz i need to make
bracelets for the next F-8 party!"

and i do believe i got involved in some flame wars here and there.

-b

Subject: Re: [sfraves] New Question du jour..."Why are we still on sfraves?"

I've just been slacking in that department lately. Haven't come up
with anything really witty and intelligent for months.

I was listening to severely cheesy trance from like '97 or so, last
night, and all I could thing was "wow, why AM I here?"

Subject: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving Q: Promoters: Why do you throw events?

A person wrote me today asking why Promoters in the Bay Area throw Parties 
- i.e. - As a promoter, what is your impetus, drive or reason for throwing 
events in lieu of doing something else?

<3

Karna

From sfraves-return-121774-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Sat Jun 04 04:16:36 2005
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-121774-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 37010 invoked by uid 1103); 4 Jun 2005 04:16:35 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 36989 invoked from network); 4 Jun 2005 04:16:35 -0000
Date: Fri, 3 Jun 2005 21:16:26 -0700 (PDT)
From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
X-X-Sender: andy@atari
To: Karina <karina@hyperreal.org>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <20050603182721.Y78340@taz3.hyperreal.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.62.0506032038500.6812@atari>
References: <20050603182721.Y78340@taz3.hyperreal.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving Q: Promoters: Why do you throw events?


On Fri, 3 Jun 2005, Karina wrote:
-&e->A person wrote me today asking why Promoters in the Bay Area throw Parties
-&e->- i.e. - As a promoter, what is your impetus, drive or reason for throwing
-&e->events in lieu of doing something else?

Because if you don't throw your own, you don't get to whine about anybody 
else's without looking like a total ass.

Because the only way to attend more good parties is to throw more 
good parties.

Because the only way to play more parties is to throw more parties.

Because my best friends get to help me do my favorite things and vice 
versa.

The nod.  Actually, fuck the nod.   The ear to ear grin of 
appreciation and the wide eyed gaze of disbelief of a night gone BOOM on 
a complete stranger's face (and then you hand them a broom - hahahaha 
SUCKER~!).

30,000 watts of dialed in sound, my favorite DJs playing, and almost no 
lights, just the way I always wanted.  So what if it cost a few bucks.

Because I was in a collective with 5 of the best local DJs in one of the 
best cities for Djs.  And the sickest most consistent visuals crew to 
boot.

Because watching your friends surf 3'ers in off the coast behind the Taco 
Bell in Pacifica while mixing vintage detroit is funny as all hell and 
nothing to be ashamed of.

Because I want renegades to keep going till the genny runs out.

Because the term 'promoter' is bunk, it should be a passion, a sustainable 
lifestyle.  The best parties are like really really really energetic house 
parties thrown by eccentric, creative people with good resources.  And 
many times, more promotion leads to worse party.  So promoter is a 
horrible word in some ways.

Because if we're all gonna die, we should take turns picking the color of 
our lightning and the sound of our thunder.

Because there are times when the most scene political thing you can do is 
throw a party that's 10 times as good at 1/3 the price.

Because I don't mind putting in the work if it means people being safer.

Because I didn't realize how much more fun it was when I helped make it 
happen till I helped.  And then I was hooked.

Because sometimes we forget to send out any promotion at all and people 
still show up tuesday night, and I'm genuinely glad to see them.

Because work is love made visible.

Because sometimes it's just your turn to throw down.

Because the more stagnant you belive the scene is, the more it reasons 
that's theres tons that can still be done that isn't.

Because when you provide you stop being a consumer and become a 
participant and I hate to say it but even that is a subversive act these 
days.  And I'll spell this out for some of you, giving LarryCo $250, 
renting an RV, banging crappy generictronica out of some dusty speaks for 
a crowd that don't all want to hear it and hanging a couple strands of EL 
wire on a chickenwire horse penis hardly qualifies.  So there.

_Our house and our house music_
andyw

p.s.	Whooo am I still in a good mood from last weekend...

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Question du Jour: What brought you to SFRaves?

I saw the movie "Groove" and I wanted to try ecstasy right away, and get
high as a kite, get massages from another guy, and make out in a chill room,
too. 

Not really. I did meet Ravin' Rizz from the list, who was doing massages for
charity, but I was too shy to ask for a massage, and when you are all hot
from dancing, you are self-conscious.

My story is that I was on Hraves (in Houston, TX) and when I moved to
California, I wanted to keep dancing so I just found the list and signed up.

Now I am in Seattle and apparently, there is no equivalent email list, just
a website, http://nwtekno.org/

Greg

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: OUCH! Supreme Court  Ruling on Medical Marijuana

--0-1534936155-1118079472=:69816
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

06/06/05, from: http://www.cnn.com/2005/LAW/06/06/scotus.medical.marijuana/index.htmlSupreme Court allows prosecution of medical marijuana
By Bill Mears
CNN Washington Bureau
Monday, June 6, 2005 Posted: 12:05 PM EDT (1605 GMT) 

WASHINGTON (CNN) -- The U.S. Supreme Court Monday ruled doctors can be blocked from prescribing marijuana for patients suffering from pain caused by cancer or other serious illnesses.

In a 6-3 vote, the justices ruled the Bush administration can block the backyard cultivation of pot for personal use, because such use has broader social and financial implications.

"Congress' power to regulate purely activities that are part of an economic 'class of activities' that have a substantial effect on interstate commerce is firmly established," wrote Justice John Paul Stevens for the majority.

Justices O'Connor, Rehnquist and Thomas dissented. The case took an unusually long time to be resolved, with oral arguments held in November.

The decision means that federal anti-drug laws trump state laws that allow the use of medical marijuana, said CNN Senior Legal Analyst Jeffrey Toobin. Ten states have such laws.

"If medical marijuana advocates want to get their views successfully presented, they have to go to Congress; they can't go to the states, because it's really the federal government that's in charge here," Toobin said.

At issue was the power of federal government to override state laws on use of "patient pot."

The Controlled Substances Act prevents the cultivation and possession of marijuana, even by people who claim personal "medicinal" use. The government argues its overall anti-drug campaign would be undermined by even limited patient exceptions.

The Drug Enforcement Agency (DEA) began raids in 2001 against patients using the drug and their caregivers in California, one of 11 states that legalized the use of marijuana for patients under a doctor's care. Among those arrested was Angel Raich, who has brain cancer, and Diane Monson, who grew cannabis in her garden to help alleviate chronic back pain.

A federal appeals court concluded use of medical marijuana was non-commercial, and therefore not subject to congressional oversight of "economic enterprise."

But lawyers for the U.S. Justice Department argued to the Supreme Court that homegrown marijuana represented interstate commerce, because the garden patch weed would affect "overall production" of the weed, much of it imported across American borders by well-financed, often violent drug gangs.

Lawyers for the patient countered with the claim that the marijuana was neither bought nor sold. After California's referendum passed in 1996, "cannabis clubs" sprung up across the state to provide marijuana to patients. They were eventually shut down by the state's attorney general.

The U.S. Supreme Court ruled in 2001 that anyone distributing medical marijuana could be prosecuted, despite claims their activity was a "medical activity."

The current case considered by the justices dealt with the broader issue of whether marijuana users could be subject to prosecution.

Along with California, nine states have passed laws permitting marijuana use by patients with a doctor's approval: Alaska, Colorado, Hawaii, Maine, Montana, Nevada, Oregon, Vermont and Washington. Arizona also has a similar law, but no formal program in place to administer prescription pot.

California's Compassionate Use Act permits patients with a doctor's approval to grow, smoke or acquire the drug for "medical needs."

Users include television host Montel Williams, who uses it to ease pain from multiple sclerosis.

Anti-drug activists say Monday's ruling could encourage abuse of drugs deemed by the government to be narcotics.

"It's a handful of people who want to see not just marijuana, but all drugs legalized," said Calvina Fay of the Drug Free America Foundation.

In its hard-line stance in opposition to medical marijuana, the federal government invoked a larger issue. "The trafficking of drugs finances the work of terror, sustaining terrorists," said President Bush in December 2001. Tough enforcement, the government told the justices, "is central to combating illegal drug possession."

Marijuana users, in their defense, argued, "Since September 11, 2001, Defendants [DEA] have terrorized more than 35 Californians because of medical cannabis." In that state, the issue has become a hot political issue this election year.

The case is Gonzales v. Raich, case no. 03-1454.

medicine at a "club" (or clinic - however you choose to view it).

shit. They'd make way more money doing that then keeping it illegal, plus 
there'd be less citizens in jail.

I'm sure there's others on here that can offer you a lot more info, but for now:
Yeah, it's that easy. Most doc's will charge $100 - $150 for a visit, and (at least my) Rx lasts for a year. Clubs tend to charge high street value for good stuff, but good stuff nonetheless. Not sure how this ruling will effect things.

Kind of related: I've read that in at least one state, you can actually by tax duty stamps from the IRS specifically for Schedule (whatever) substances- with cash (lmao). Wonder how much they made off of those. . . Funny, but I've never heard of a bust where these "stamps" were actually found. 

Chester Copperpot <chester.copperpot420@gmail.com> wrote:Yeah no shit...i read this article last week about how oregon made
some serious cash from medical
marijuana.(http://www.firstcoastnews.com/news/strange/news-article.aspx?storyid=38168)
I read an article a year or 2 ago about how the US spent like some
95 billion (or million, cant remember which) on the drug war. So why
not legalize at least marijuana, and tax it and make some money to at
least ofset those costs and focus our efforts on at least trying to
curb the more deadly/harmful drugs such as meth or crack and what not.
It's so absofuckinlutly clear on how easy this would be. I really
dont think the world will fall apart if marijuana is legalized, as a
matter of fact i think (at least in terms of pot usage and whatnot)
will remain the same. All that revenue, and more space in prisons for
real criminals and all that jazz. Why does congress have to be so
stupid? it hurts my brain just thinking about it.


-- 
Chester Copperpot

"Goonies never say die!"
"Meth Monsters are my Anti-Drug"
"I feel like I'm taking crazy pills"

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: OUCH! Supreme Court Ruling on Medical Marijuana

The answer is control.  Plain and simple.  The next
and secondary answere is money.  Paper industry
lobbying congress back in the day...make black man
look twice at a white woman...yadda fucking yadda. 
But the simple truth of the matter is govt has to
excersice forms of control on the people it is
supposed to protect...and I use that term loosly. 

So, when you take a govt that by it's nature has to
control and put money, greed and a christian/puritan
mentality and shake it all up....you get this.  A
plant that is less harmfull then tobacco, less toxic
than alcohol, could be used in a wide variety of
textile manufacturing...and it's illegal.  

Three cheers for govt!!!!  The have YOUR best interest
at heart, cause your not smart enough to make the
decision on your own.

-Dylan

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed


Supreme Court Rules on Medical Marijuana

Join Angel Raich for a Live Web Chat on the Decision

Contact your Member of Congress

Dear Henry,

You probably remember 
<http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=84657>Angel Raich, the 
woman who suffers from an inoperable brain tumor and uses medical cannabis 
to help ease her pain. You may also remember that last November, Angel took 
<http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=84658>her case against 
Attorney General Ashcroft to the Supreme Court in a matter of what is for 
her a life-or-death situation, to allow patients to cultivate and use 
medical cannabis upon the recommendation of a doctor.

The verdict is in. The Supreme Court ruled 6-3 today that Federal 
authorities can prosecute Angel and other patients who use medical 
marijuana even with their doctor's recommendation. The Court said that it's 
up to Congress to change federal law.

Join Angel and her husband Robert Raich, along with the Alliance's 
Executive Director Ethan Nadelmann for a live web chat to get Angel's 
firsthand reaction to the ruling.

When: Wednesday, June 8, 2005 at
5 PM EDT / 2 PM PDT
Where: <http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=95491>Online at 
DrugPolicy.org.

Please email 
<http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=95467>questions@drugpolicy.org 
before June 8 to submit questions, and don't forget to bookmark the chat 
address!

Get Involved

It's important to note that the ruling only affects federal law. It does 
not overturn state medical marijuana laws which protect patients from state 
arrest.

"This ruling changes nothing," said Dan Abrahamson, director of legal 
affairs for the Drug Policy Alliance. "States still have the right to pass 
legislation that protects the rights of patients to use this life-saving 
medicine. The federal government still has a choice-it can waste taxpayer 
dollars by going after sick and dying patients or go after individuals who 
pose a real danger to society."

While the ruling may be distressing news for Angel, the battle to make 
medical cannabis available to patients like Angel still continues. Congress 
now has a unique and timely opportunity to deal with the marijuana issue 
once and for all. Fax your congressperson to tell them that it's time they 
protect sick and dying patients.

<http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=95484>Take Action Now!

Learn More About the Case

In 2002, Angel Raich and Diane Monson were launched into the national 
spotlight when both seriously ill medical cannabis patients -- along with 
two anonymous caregivers who grow and provide medical cannabis to patients 
free of charge -- sued Attorney General John Ashcroft and the federal 
government. As part of our continued effort to defend the rights of sick 
and dying medical marijuana patients, Drug Policy Alliance has been helping 
to fund the Raich v. Ashcroft case. The goal in launching Raich v. Ashcroft 
was to put an end to the government's cruel and illegal raids on sick 
people who legally use medical cannabis according to state law. Today, more 
than two years after filing the lawsuit, the U.S. Supreme Court reached a 
decision in Raich v. Ashcroft.
In their opinion, the Justices have rightly recognized that marijuana does 
have medical efficacy and is necessary for Angel Raich and other seriously 
ill patients. Read the Supreme Court opinion 
<http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=85009>here, and the 
Alliance's brief on behalf of Raich 
<http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=85010>here.

[]





Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

her case</a> against Attorney General Ashcroft to the Supreme Court in a
matter of what is for her a life-or-death situation, to allow patients to

Date: Mon, 6 Jun 2005 12:17:19 -0700 (PDT)
From: Karina <karina@hyperreal.org>
To: CHUCK G <chuckg_421@yahoo.com>
cc: SFR <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <20050606173752.72153.qmail@web60825.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20050606120949.E83860@taz3.hyperreal.org>
References: <20050606173752.72153.qmail@web60825.mail.yahoo.com>
Hyperreal<-_->http: //www.hyperreal.org/ SFRaves<-_->http://www.sfraves.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
X-Spam-Rating: localhost 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: OUCH! Supreme Court  Ruling on Medical Marijuana

What I'd like to know is why the article uses wording like:

"... In a 6-3 vote, the justices ruled the Bush administration can block 
the backyard cultivation...." - 1st Paragraph

Tis not the "Bush Administration", but Congress and our representatives in 
both houses who author, pass and legislate Federal Statutes.

Tis no suprise that this ruling takes place given the current Federal Laws 
on the books. This was a known factor since the passing of Prop 216 in 
1996.

The article fails to cite the application of the Supremacy Clause in the 
US Constitution, giving the Federal Government / Federal Law 
Preemption and making the CA State Law Moot in this case (as it conflicts 
with Federal Law):

"...

[THE SUPREMACY CLAUSE Article. VI.
This Constitution, and the Laws of the United States which shall be made 
in Pursuance thereof; and all Treaties made, or which shall be made, under 
the Authority of the United States, shall be the supreme Law of the Land; 
and the Judges in every State shall be bound thereby, any thing in the 
Constitution or Laws of any State to the Contrary notwithstanding. ]

Any federal law does trump any conflicting state law
Issues like credit reporting and debt collector abuse are researched by 
millions of consumers each and every day. Commonly, there is confusion as 
to whether the law to consider is a state or federal law and which one 
will finally rule. The Supremacy Clause in the Constitution explains that 
federal law always trumps state law which means federal always wins if 
there is a conflict between the two. If there is no conflict then the 
state law will be used but if there is any question or conflict of the two 
reading as the same, then the federal rule would win.

..."

From: http://www.carreonandassociates.com/articles/supremacy-law.htm

Supposedly there are checks and balances in place, and this country is run 
by people for the people, from the people, who are supposed to represent 
the good of the common people and our interests.

What we should really be asking is, is the "War on Drugs" and the costs 
associated with it, the will of the people, and in our best interests?

...
  -- 
**************************************************************
******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************
If there is a sin against life, it consists perhaps not so
much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************
**************************************************************


On Mon, 6 Jun 2005, CHUCK G wrote:

> Date: Mon, 6 Jun 2005 10:37:52 -0700 (PDT)
> From: CHUCK G <chuckg_421@yahoo.com>
> To: SFR <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> Subject: [sfraves] NRR: OUCH! Supreme Court  Ruling on Medical Marijuana
> 
> 06/06/05, from: http://www.cnn.com/2005/LAW/06/06/scotus.medical.marijuana/index.htmlSupreme Court allows prosecution of medical marijuana
> By Bill Mears
> CNN Washington Bureau
> Monday, June 6, 2005 Posted: 12:05 PM EDT (1605 GMT)
>
> WASHINGTON (CNN) -- The U.S. Supreme Court Monday ruled doctors can be blocked from prescribing marijuana for patients suffering from pain caused by cancer or other serious illnesses.
>
> In a 6-3 vote, the justices ruled the Bush administration can block the backyard cultivation of pot for personal use, because such use has broader social and financial implications.
>
> "Congress' power to regulate purely activities that are part of an economic 'class of activities' that have a substantial effect on interstate commerce is firmly established," wrote Justice John Paul Stevens for the majority.
>
> Justices O'Connor, Rehnquist and Thomas dissented. The case took an unusually long time to be resolved, with oral arguments held in November.
>
> The decision means that federal anti-drug laws trump state laws that allow the use of medical marijuana, said CNN Senior Legal Analyst Jeffrey Toobin. Ten states have such laws.
>
> "If medical marijuana advocates want to get their views successfully presented, they have to go to Congress; they can't go to the states, because it's really the federal government that's in charge here," Toobin said.
>
> At issue was the power of federal government to override state laws on use of "patient pot."
>
> The Controlled Substances Act prevents the cultivation and possession of marijuana, even by people who claim personal "medicinal" use. The government argues its overall anti-drug campaign would be undermined by even limited patient exceptions.
>
> The Drug Enforcement Agency (DEA) began raids in 2001 against patients using the drug and their caregivers in California, one of 11 states that legalized the use of marijuana for patients under a doctor's care. Among those arrested was Angel Raich, who has brain cancer, and Diane Monson, who grew cannabis in her garden to help alleviate chronic back pain.
>
> A federal appeals court concluded use of medical marijuana was non-commercial, and therefore not subject to congressional oversight of "economic enterprise."
>
> But lawyers for the U.S. Justice Department argued to the Supreme Court that homegrown marijuana represented interstate commerce, because the garden patch weed would affect "overall production" of the weed, much of it imported across American borders by well-financed, often violent drug gangs.
>
> Lawyers for the patient countered with the claim that the marijuana was neither bought nor sold. After California's referendum passed in 1996, "cannabis clubs" sprung up across the state to provide marijuana to patients. They were eventually shut down by the state's attorney general.
>
> The U.S. Supreme Court ruled in 2001 that anyone distributing medical marijuana could be prosecuted, despite claims their activity was a "medical activity."
>
> The current case considered by the justices dealt with the broader issue of whether marijuana users could be subject to prosecution.
>
> Along with California, nine states have passed laws permitting marijuana use by patients with a doctor's approval: Alaska, Colorado, Hawaii, Maine, Montana, Nevada, Oregon, Vermont and Washington. Arizona also has a similar law, but no formal program in place to administer prescription pot.
>
> California's Compassionate Use Act permits patients with a doctor's approval to grow, smoke or acquire the drug for "medical needs."
>
> Users include television host Montel Williams, who uses it to ease pain from multiple sclerosis.
>
> Anti-drug activists say Monday's ruling could encourage abuse of drugs deemed by the government to be narcotics.
>
> "It's a handful of people who want to see not just marijuana, but all drugs legalized," said Calvina Fay of the Drug Free America Foundation.
>
> In its hard-line stance in opposition to medical marijuana, the federal government invoked a larger issue. "The trafficking of drugs finances the work of terror, sustaining terrorists," said President Bush in December 2001. Tough enforcement, the government told the justices, "is central to combating illegal drug possession."
>
> Marijuana users, in their defense, argued, "Since September 11, 2001, Defendants [DEA] have terrorized more than 35 Californians because of medical cannabis." In that state, the issue has become a hot political issue this election year.
>
> The case is Gonzales v. Raich, case no. 03-1454.
>
>
>
>
>
> ---------------------------------
> Discover Yahoo!
> Find restaurants, movies, travel & more fun for the weekend. Check it out!

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org


From sfraves-return-121814-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon Jun 06 20:23:19 2005

Date: Mon, 6 Jun 2005 13:23:17 -0700 (PDT)

Subject: [sfraves] What is your favorite Internet radio station?

--NextPart_Webmail_9m3u9jl4l_316_1118094479_0
Content-Type: text/plain
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

I thought satellite radio was useful, especially for people on the go, but I forgot about the power of streaming radio stations on the Internet.
 
It seems that you can find just about any genre to entertain you while working or while you are near a high-speed Internet connection.
 
My current favorite is Digitally Imported.
http://www.di.fm/
I like the vocal trance channel (I know, its cheesy but feel-good music).
 
They also have a drum and bass channel; cant wait to listen to that one.
 
Oh yeah, I also like C 89.5 because it is a radio station completely run by students in Seattle (Nathan Hale High School).
http://www.c895fm.com/2001/main.asp
 
What is your favorite Internet radio station?
--NextPart_Webmail_9m3u9jl4l_316_1118094479_0--

From sfraves-return-121818-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon Jun 06 23:19:20 2005
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-121818-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 75654 invoked from network); 6 Jun 2005 23:19:13 -0000
From: gregvp@comcast.net
To: Thirty Foot Smurfs!!,<ryptide@ryptide.com>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Date: Mon, 06 Jun 2005 23:19:07 +0000
Message-Id: <060620052319.7789.42A4D9EB0003AD3D00001E6D22007358349F90090A9D09@comcast.net>
X-Mailer: AT&T Message Center Version 1 (Dec 17 2004)
X-Authenticated-Sender: Z3JlZ3ZwQGNvbWNhc3QubmV0
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] What is your favorite Internet radio station?

Wow, you are right, the psy-trance on Digitally Imported is great! Now I am TOTALLY tuned to that channel--got away from the vocal trance.

This psy-trance made me remember a New Years Eve party (for 2003-2004) that was held in an artists' collective space in SF near the convention center. (What is the name of it, can't remember) It was a popular venue for a while with a large main room off to the side of the entrance, a second room with seating, and an outdoor chill space. I dont know if it is still used today. 

Anyway, at this party, while the psy-trance was throbbing in the atmosphere, there were lots of cool people, too. I met one of the original founders of the marijuana legalization movement in SF (circa 1960s)--he was selling copies of his autobiography and postcards, too. His book had the original recipe for the pot brownies. He left the party early, and asked me to "guard" his table with the paraphernalia on it. Coincidentally, he left part of a joint on the table, too, and my god was it strong. I had fun later.

I also met a local gay porn star, Markie, who used to work at the Club 220 sex club in the Tenderloin.  He was dressed in a mink coat and was getting lots of attention. There was a tremendous rainstorm that night, drenching the drunks partying over by the convention center (and getting us ravers wet, too). Although we were already wet with sweat.

I also remember dancing beside the owner of Club 220; Terrance is his name, I think. Nice guy. He was happy grooving to the Goa.

It was a weird New Years, my last in SF. Shortly thereafter, a few months later, I took off. But I will never forget the psy-trance. 


Greg

Subject: [sfraves] Best (legal) download service (for EDM MP3s)?

--NextPart_Webmail_9m3u9jl4l_22244_1118102487_0
Content-Type: text/plain
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Forgive me if I exceed my posting limit today, but I just thought of something else that other people might want to know, too.

Who has the best downloading service (legal) for electronic dance music (any genre)?

They all make you sign up with a credit card, and I don't want to join all services, I would be bankrupt quickly.

Today I downloaded WinAmp and it came with a trial for EMusic (50 free MP3s). Comcast is pushing Rhapsody or Music Now. My laptop computer came loaded with a trial version of Napster.

This is TOTAL confusion! How do you know who to pick?

Any suggestions would be appreciated. I just want to dance. 

Streaming Internet Radio is fine, but for some tracks,  you want the flexibility of ownership (especially for CD burns or portable MP3 players).

Greg
--NextPart_Webmail_9m3u9jl4l_22244_1118102487_0--

money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."

while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Erika Gies, Grist Magazine

a new environmental network.

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed


Reefer madness: Is sanity breaking out?
Despite the Supreme Court's ruling against medical marijuana and a scary 
proposed snitch law, America may finally be awakening from its decades-long 
stupor about recreational drugs.

- - - - - - - - - - - -
By Silja J.A. Talvi

SALON.COM

June 7, 2005  | The battle over the war on drugs heated up several degrees 
on Monday when the Supreme Court, in a 6-3 decision, ruled that state laws 
allowing the <http://dir.salon.com/topics/medical_marijuana/>medicinal use 
of marijuana don't protect patients from federal prosecution for use of a 
controlled substance, despite a doctor's orders. The case, Raich vs. 
Gonzales, was originally filed by 
<http://www.salon.com/politics/war_room/2005/06/06/marijuana/index.html>two 
California women who smoke pot for medical reasons.

Medical marijuana advocates were quick to point out that although the 
ruling was a disappointment, it came with a surprising acknowledgment by 
the justices that medical marijuana users had made "strong arguments that 
they will suffer irreparable harm because, despite a congressional finding 
to the contrary, marijuana does have valid therapeutic purposes."

"While we're disappointed, the validity of state medical marijuana laws was 
never at issue in this case," said Rob Kampia, executive director of the 
Marijuana Policy Project in Washington, in a press statement. "The [state] 
medical marijuana laws ... will continue to protect patients from arrest by 
state and local authorities. Because [Drug Enforcement Agency] and other 
federal agents make only 1 percent of our nation's 750,000 marijuana 
arrests every year, patients in states with medical marijuana laws retain a 
high level of protection. Congress should act today to give those patients 
complete protection from arrest."

"In his opinion, Justice Stevens stressed the need for medical marijuana 
patients to use the democratic process, putting the ball in Congress' 
court," Kampia noted. "This is especially important now because next week, 
the U.S. House of Representatives will vote on an amendment that would 
prevent the federal government from spending funds to interfere with state 
medical marijuana laws."

The good news is that Kampia and other leaders of the drug-war reform 
movement represent an increasingly informed and politically savvy group -- 
including several members of Congress -- who have spent the past several 
years trying to do something about America's draconian drug laws. As a 
result of the Supreme Court's decision on Monday, they are stepping up 
efforts to draw attention to the Hinchey-Rohrabacher amendment, which will 
be considered this month as a part of an appropriations bill and, if 
passed, would prohibit the federal government from arresting, raiding or 
prosecuting patients who are abiding by state medical marijuana laws.

These reformers have also set their sights on another obviously needed 
legislative reform: repeal of the 
<http://www.salon.com/mwt/feature/2002/05/20/aid_denial/index.html>provision 
of the Higher Education Act that prohibits or delays the availability of 
financial aid to applicants with any drug-related misdemeanor or felony 
charge. The bill to repeal the provision (H.R. 1184), introduced by Rep. 
Barney Frank, D-Mass., this session, already has 66 cosponsors in the 
House. To date, the <http://stopthedrugwar.org/>Drug Reform Coordinator 
Network estimates, at least 165,000 would-be students have been denied 
financial aid since the amendment took effect in 2000. If passed, the bill 
would represent the first full repeal of a federal drug law since 1970.

To Rep. Jim McDermott, D-Wash., denying students financial aid because they 
were busted for drug use or sales at some point in their lives looks more 
like a mental illness on a large scale than anything akin to an efficacious 
response to substance abuse. "The idea that we're going to prohibit people 
from using drugs is just a falsehood; it's just time that we stop what 
we're doing and try something else," McDermott, a nine-term veteran of 
Congress, told me at a Perry Fund 
<http://www.raiseyourvoice.com/Perry-index.html>event in Seattle last week.

As for the possibility of legalizing, regulating and even taxing certain 
illegal drugs, even the most forward-thinking of drug-war reformers have 
tended to stay away from discussing the idea in public, lest it seem too 
"radical."

But on June 2, the legalization movement gained an unlikely set of 
supporters -- specifically relating to marijuana, the most popular Schedule 
I drug. More than 500 leading economists, led by Nobel Prize winner Milton 
Friedman, called for the Bush administration to engage in "an open and 
honest debate about marijuana prohibition." Their move was in response to 
the release of a <http://www.prohibitioncosts.org/mironreport.html>report 
on the budgetary implications of marijuana prohibition by Jeffrey Miron, a 
visiting professor at Harvard University. According to Miron's research, 
the legal regulation of cannabis would conservatively save $7.7 billion in 
law enforcement and criminal justice costs, while revenues for the 
government could range from $2.4 to $6.2 billion, depending on the type of 
taxation system.

Another radical leap forward in drug-policy reform came in Washington state 
in January 2005, when the King County Bar Association passed a resolution 
supporting the statewide legalization and regulation of psychoactive 
substances. The move followed a three-year period of intensive research 
into the historical, social, racial, legal, economic and fiscal 
considerations surrounding the drug war -- both in Washington state and 
throughout the United States. The resulting 145-page 
<http://www.kcba.org/druglaw/proposal.html>report, "Effective Drug Control: 
Toward a New Legal Framework," was hailed by a wide spectrum of mainstream 
organizations, including the Church Council of Greater Seattle, King County 
Medical Society, Washington State Psychiatric Association, Washington 
Society of Addiction Medicine, and Washington Academy of Family Physicians. 
And as a result, Democratic state Sen. Adam Kline is pushing for 
legislation to examine the possibility of a new legal framework for 
regulating illicit substances.

Other state bar associations (including those in Vermont, Oregon, Maryland 
and Hawaii) are beginning their own studies of revamped approaches to the 
drug war, according to Roger Goodman, director of the King County Bar 
Association's Drug Policy Project. The reverberations of the report have 
been tremendous, says Goodman, although he admits that getting gung-ho 
prosecutors and law enforcement onboard remains the biggest hurdle.

Aside from the need for legislative reform of drug laws, substance abuse 
treatment, special drug courts, and 
<http://www.salon.com/news/feature/2005/03/24/needle_exchange/index.html>needle 
exchange and other forms of "harm reduction," activists point to the need 
for more-logical alternatives to the endless cycle of drug-related arrests 
and heavy-handed mandatory minimum sentences in the federal prison system. 
The inmate population has increased by 81 percent since 1995, and 55 
percent of federal prisoners are incarcerated because of a drug offense, 
serving an average of three years and seven months. (For African-Americans, 
the average jumps dramatically to four years and nine months.)

Former prisoners with felony drug records can't access public housing, 
federal assistance for education, and many other social services, to say 
nothing of the permanent black mark against them when it comes to finding a 
job or getting back the right to vote. Is it any wonder that so many 
federal and state prisoners end up back in jail or prison?

The ridiculously costly war on the consumption of cannabis is clearly 
misdirected, as detailed in a May 2005 
<http://www.sentencingproject.org/pdfs/waronmarijuana.pdf>report by the 
Sentencing Project. Of the nearly 700,000 marijuana arrests in 2002, a 
shocking 88 percent were for simple possession. (The number of marijuana 
arrests far exceeds the number of arrests for murder, manslaughter, 
forcible rape, robbery and aggravated assault combined.) And the Sentencing 
Project estimates that 27,000 men and women are currently locked up for a 
marijuana-related offense. Legalizing marijuana would be an appropriate 
start to a long-term vision based on rational fiscal and public health policy.

If we're so worried about our kids' experimentation with recreational 
drugs, why aren't we pouring our resources into providing accurate 
information about drugs (alcohol and cigarettes being not only the most 
commonly used but the most obviously damaging as well) and into effective 
treatment programs for those who develop a destructive habit?

Unfortunately, and this is the bad news, American drug policy is still 
being shaped by political rhetoric rather than fiscally or medically sound 
strategies for keeping people healthy and out of trouble. For the latest 
and most egregious evidence of that, look no further than H.R. 1528, 
introduced this session by Rep. James Sensenbrenner, R-Wis., and named in 
classically Orwellian doublespeak as the Defending America's Most 
Vulnerable: Safe Access to Drug Treatment and Child Protection Act of 2005.

There hasn't been anything this scary in the already frightening reach of 
the American drug war in a long time. As written, this bill would create a 
new, three-year federal mandatory minimum for parents who witness or gain 
knowledge about drug activities happening around their kids and do not 
report what they know to the cops within 24 hours, or provide requested 
assistance to law enforcement in a resulting investigation, apprehension or 
prosecution. It would also create a 10-year mandatory minimum sentence for 
parents who commit a drug crime in or near the presence of their child, add 
a new five-year mandatory minimum sentence for anyone who sells drugs to 
someone who has ever been in treatment, and increase to five years the 
mandatory minimum for the sale of drugs within 1,000 feet of a school, 
library or drug treatment facility. That means just about anywhere in urban 
centers -- and especially in the concentrated inner cities.

The bill is fundamentally aimed at subverting important Supreme Court 
decisions about the unconstitutionality of federal sentencing guidelines by 
converting those guidelines into a new framework of mandatory minimums -- 
once again, with little or no judicial discretion possible.

Civil liberties groups like <http://www.famm.org>Families Against Mandatory 
Minimums, the <http://www.aclu.org>ACLU, the Drug Reform Coordination 
Network and the <http://www.drugpolicy.org>Drug Policy Alliance are 
combining forces to raise awareness and prevent the bill from passing, but 
it's too early to say if their efforts will succeed.

Enough already. The ongoing war on drugs has reached into every echelon of 
society, dragging medicinal-pot smokers and would-be college students into 
the mix. And it has made the lives of millions of citizens more miserable 
than they ever would have been on their own as either recreational or 
habitual substance users. We certainly don't need another piece of 
regressive legislation to add to the damage by turning us into a nation of 
drug-war spies.

- - - - - - - - - - - -

About the writer
<http://www.salon.com/opinion/feature/2005/06/07/war_on_drugs/%E2%80%9Dhttp://www.well.com/user/sisu>Silja 
J.A. Talvi is a freelance journalist and essayist. She received a 2005 PASS 
award for her feature on the impact of "three strikes" sentencing in 
Washington state and is an 11-time winner of regional awards from the 
Society of Professional Journalists. She is working on a book about women 
in prison.
Sound Off
Send us a <http://www.salon.com/about/letters/index.html>Letter to the Editor

Vancouver hopes to save hundreds of lives by opening street clinics where 
heroin addicts can shoot up safely. But the White House is accusing Canada 
of going AWOL from its war on drugs.
By Mark Follman
09/08/03

By Arianna Huffington

"ungodly things."
By Steve France

man... i didn't realize how much damn fun I was gonna have!!!

So Friday night I was over @ 1015 4 the Groundscore 10 year.. OK.. i
really gotta share this 'cause it was just like so dope... I was outside
smoking in that well... like that baracaded area with the promoter when
Shimon pulled up in the cab w/ MethodOne... so she asked me & QZen 2 go
out 2 escort him 2 the DJ booth... LoL.. AS soon as we walked up 2 him
when he got in... He looked 2 me & said, "Hey mate, I remember you from a
few years ago when i was here last.. it's good 2 c U again!"...
LoLOLOLOLOLOLMAO.. Hello 2Day.. that was so cool 'cause last time he was
here & I saw im.. I'm pretty sure it was @ Phuturo or like compression...
but we didn't really hangout, so that was totally Awesome!!  YAY!

Needless 2 Say... his set was fuckin' sick... as well as Aphrodite's set,
Firce's Set, Genome's Set, & Jayvon's set... the whole night in the main
room was all HARD, DUBBY, some vocal Jungle the whole night.. lOVED IT...
the crowd was like slow @ 1st, but totally built up the rooms by 1:30AM...

In the front room was the break beats, hip hop, & all the broken beats..
ok... 1/2 the time in that room.. I felt like I was in 8th grade & high
school again 'cause alota the DJs spun like ooooooooold school yummy
goodness like NWA, oh Gosh, ummm I think I heard Sally, That girl,... I
can't remember names of groups & songs & stuff right now, but yeah man,
grrr, this is killing me 'cause I can't remember.. it was sick!!!  LoL..
my most fave was when the Syrup Girls played hella old school freestyle
hip hop like Planet Rock, Debbie Deb, Shannon... they also spun like
eeeeeeverything else, 2 Step, Hip Hop, Breaks, everything, Loved that
set!!!  OK..  in that rooom was also Felix The Dog, qZen, Wil, Clockwork,
OK... I can't remember right now 'cause yeah, but it was a Dope night @
the club...

Oh, there were only 2 rooms open the front & main... so yeah...it was
really packed & so much fun... every1 there was diggin' the music & o=in
good spirits... fuck man... so dope!!!

Oh yeah... WR= weekend review....

anywaze. Sat night went 2 Depth Charge... Good fuckin' Shit... sooooooooo
much fun... Good music all night long!!!  i HAD alota fave sets that night
actually... my most fave of the ummm... down tempo chill band w/ andy W,
Origami, & folks... LOVED IT!!!  There was also this like guitar singer @
the begining of the night in the chill room...

Loved the Amber/ Dfly tag set... man.. Sticky's set... Yumy old school
goodness....

Like I mean.. the whole night was perfect IMo... I had the most Grooviest
time hangin' w/ Family, Groovin' so hard on the floor, & ya know..
honestly.. had like these mondo touching moments with people i Love there
that night... like serously.. I had alota eye opening experiences that
night that like totally made me just Wow... so glad 2 B part of the scene
& have this Awesome Love w/ the People I Love... So Dope!!!

OK... LoL.. I know, I'm all getting PLUR right now.. oh oh oh.. did u know
that Pluralistic is a real word in the dictionary????

anywaze, I'd Love 2 be more descriptive about both events, but I'm @
school rightnow & suppose 2 do homework since my comp @ home is still
well.. a new comp should be  coming soon, & I shuld be doing homework..
hmmm.. i could type a 2 page paper in like an hour I hope... Hmmm...

I'm so mondo fucki' happy that I saw y'all over the weekend who i saw...
Danny.. I really wanna talk 2 u ASAP & your phone # is trapped in my
broken computer =(

Man.. still high from the weekend... Love It!!!!  Now if this high will
only trasfer 2 motivation 4 doin' my homework!

Wow...





-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> ObY {8O)

Subject: [sfraves] Trance & immobility...  Was: im confused

> even if you went for the trance...would you not be interested in
> hopping to other rooms to check out the other music?


i know it's not highbrow to support trance these days...  but hopping to other rooms sorta defeats
the purpose of trance, dunnit?  

Staying "there" was always the epic challenge, for me.    Maybe even an imperative.

Trance (as a mental state) requires some kind of immobility...  of body, or mind, or spirit., or
unbathed ass in yesterday's drawers... right?    If I leave the room (physically,  willingly),
doesn't that mean Dr. Jockeyphones tranced me wrong?

Not that i've heard committable trance since trance went pop.   Give me a good old break-beat any
day.  

Ride the mid-range, drop the bass.

Peace love and strawberry butt-jam,  

boom

a l i e n s  g i v e  b i g g e r   h e a d

    -    M      A      F      I      A     -









.

-----Original Message-----
From: gregvp@comcast.net [mailto:gregvp@comcast.net]
Sent: Monday, June 06, 2005 2:48 PM
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: [sfraves] What is your favorite Internet radio station?


I thought satellite radio was useful, especially for people on the go, but I
forgot about the power of streaming radio stations on the Internet.

It seems that you can find just about any genre to entertain you while
working or while you are near a high-speed Internet connection.

My current favorite is Digitally Imported.
http://www.di.fm/
I like the vocal trance channel (I know, its cheesy but feel-good music).

They also have a drum and bass channel; cant wait to listen to that one.

Oh yeah, I also like C 89.5 because it is a radio station completely run by
students in Seattle (Nathan Hale High School).
http://www.c895fm.com/2001/main.asp

What is your favorite Internet radio station?

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Question du Jour: What brought you to SFRaves?

What's up people?

I'm an old school lurker from the Socal Raves list back in the late
80's, I think.  Well before I was going to parties.  When I moved up
to the bay about two years ago, it was only logical that I get on the
SFR list to keep up with all things rave.

I must be getting older.  I'm really starting to hate the word rave.=20
Can't we all just use the word party?  Say it. . . Par - T.  See that
didn't hurt at all.

So yeah.  Dat is why I is here.

Subject: [sfraves] boy, the things you learn when you record yourself mixing

so the other day i finally got my MD recorder working again and i
recorded myself and have been listening to it a few times.

i can't believe how terrible my EQs and levels are.  why didn't anyone
else tell me how bad i suck?

now granted, my speaker setup at home isn't the greatest.  i mix off
of two small computer speakers with a little sub under my desk.  i
pray to god that's why my levels sound so wack because if i've been
mixing like this when i play out....then the people that are booking
me are crackheads.

i seriously need to get a better speaker setup at home for monitoring.
 anyone else pick up any tips from listening to your own at-home
mixes?

--=20

Subject: Re: [sfraves] boy, the things you learn when you record yourself mixing

This very reason is why I always wear 36db earplugs whenever I spin
records.  All I know is that I'm having fun, and there are these
totally silent plastic spinning discs in front of me, and cross-looking
people staring!

It's great!

You should try it.

Q-Bert and DJ Shadow jam together at Q-Bert's hacienda? I got those
speakers. and I'm willing to sell them! gimme like, tons of money, and
stuff.

something similar, because they're intended as montiors for recording
studios. Grammy-winning albums have been mixed on these and these
alone! act now and get this FREE ball of booty-wibbets!)

and yup, tips from spinning at home, ummmm, it's good to record
yourself. for the SF old schoolers DJ Science was one of the most
solid technical mixers around back in the day and as I understand it
he recorded himself like all the time. ^_^

Received: (qmail 29363 invoked from network); 7 Jun 2005 17:54:58 -0000
Message-ID: <20050607175456.56424.qmail@web81310.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Tue, 7 Jun 2005 10:54:56 -0700 (PDT)
From: Chris Jackson <cjax@sbcglobal.net>
To: Bam <invibe@gmail.com>,
  Yo Momma Wears Mickey Gloves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: 6667
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] boy, the things you learn when you record yourself mixing

I wouldn't be so hard on yourself.  Though i've never
heard you play out, the lil computer speaks are
probably where your level issues lay.  You don't have
any *live* recordings of yourself to test this theory
against?  Do you use any type of sound processing
inline with your decks/mixer??  Like a
compressor/limiter or any sort of maximizer??  A
limiter isn't such a bad idea as it lets you set a
threshold on your levels...allowing any spikes to hit
a *brick wall* of sorts.  Nothing will get past the
limit you set.  GREAT for live sets when its a little
harder to control the levels.  You know, it's good you
bring this up, because there are TONS of DJ's who have
absolutely no sense of these level issues and sound
like complete crap when playing out.  Mastering the
EQ's and levels when playing are a HUGE part of rockin
the decks proper..IMHO.

=)

c h r i s

Subject: Re: [sfraves] boy, the things you learn when you record yourself mixing

and so now, the question of the hour!

for the DJs...what do you think is the best monitoring system for
practicing at home?

i think some of the producers would suggest high end studio monitors,
which makes sense because you want to hear things as true to sound as
possible.

but

for the DJs, since most situations have poor monitoring when playing
live (ex.  just loud sound, not clean, crisp nor balanced)...is it
better to just go with big and loud rather than clean and balanced?

thoughts please.

X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.730)
X-ELNK-Trace: b815ca255710aa4c0ba167aeb931aee97e972de0d01da940779885093fab9210135e26ebd45f2817350badd9bab72f9c350badd9bab72f9c350badd9bab72f9c
X-Originating-IP: 207.101.242.2
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] boy, the things you learn when you record yourself mixing

On Jun 7, 2005, at 10:25 AM, Bam wrote:

> i can't believe how terrible my EQs and levels are.  why didn't anyone
> else tell me how bad i suck?

we were going to have an intervention, but we didn't want to lose the  
cute girl contingent at parties you play at, so we let you keep  
playing. :-)


> i seriously need to get a better speaker setup at home for monitoring.
>  anyone else pick up any tips from listening to your own at-home  
> mixes?

listen to a few of your records at the same level with flat eq's,  
especially when you get a new track. in addition to your mix in/out  
points, phrasing, etc, listen for the volume/eq of the track - yeah,  
it's another thing to remember, but knowing how to set your PF level  
and eq's BEFORE you even put the record on the deck will save you  
some time.

do this, then get a feel for what your relative pitch will be (with  
practice you should be able to get it within +/- .5%), and then you  
will be able to beat-match records at breakneck speed. (go ahead and  
write the BPM on the label if you're a wuss.)

use that extra free time to enjoy your records - dance, talk to that  
hot girl hanging out by your left monitor, yell, jump around, scratch  
(records, not yourself please)...  just don't do that retarded shit  
where you fake like you're tweaking knobs or "conduct" the crowd. i  
WILL throw something at you if i see you doing that.

listening to recordings of yourself practicing, and actually  
practicing a lot, even if you're just dorking around on the decks, is  
the key.

-pxd-

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

From: Dylan <diametric77@yahoo.com>

Cc: Yo Momma Wears Mickey Gloves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <7a86c50c0506071112695157b1@mail.gmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] boy, the things you learn when you record yourself mixing

I mostly mix in my headphones, especially when I
record.  I keep accurate tabs on my mix/eq's/levels
etc.  However, it important to switch it up
occasionally so as not to become too dependant on just
the headphones.  Every so often, I "pretend" a channel
in the headphones goes out or try to simulate some
other fuck up you might find in a club ot keep me on
my toes.  I can't tell you the times I've played with
no monitor, or the mixer only lets you hear one
channel at a time.  Keep mixing in different way to
keep yer self and yer skills in check.

Diversity is key.

-Dylan


--- Bam <invibe@gmail.com> wrote:

> and so now, the question of the hour!
> 
> for the DJs...what do you think is the best
> monitoring system for
> practicing at home?

> studio monitors,

> true to sound as
> possible.
> 
> but
> 
> for the DJs, since most situations have poor
> monitoring when playing

--0-939105060-1118169764=:87409
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

i make sure i keep proper levels by watching the level indicators on the mixer all the time. Like Chris said, most djs have no idea about levels, and maxing all levels out (like most djs do) really destroys all the dynamics in the tracks they play. 
 
But the first thing I do to make sure my levels are always straight is I only buy records that have been mixed an engineered well. This creates a consistency in my mixes that I think adds to my overall sound or style.

Chris Jackson <cjax@sbcglobal.net> wrote:
I wouldn't be so hard on yourself. Though i've never
heard you play out, the lil computer speaks are
probably where your level issues lay. You don't have
any *live* recordings of yourself to test this theory
against? Do you use any type of sound processing
inline with your decks/mixer?? Like a
compressor/limiter or any sort of maximizer?? A
limiter isn't such a bad idea as it lets you set a
threshold on your levels...allowing any spikes to hit
a *brick wall* of sorts. Nothing will get past the
limit you set. GREAT for live sets when its a little
harder to control the levels. You know, it's good you
bring this up, because there are TONS of DJ's who have
absolutely no sense of these level issues and sound
like complete crap when playing out. Mastering the
EQ's and levels when playing are a HUGE part of rockin
the decks proper..IMHO.

=)

c h r i s

Yeah, I spin mainly house that doesn't lend itself to heavy
techno-style eq tricks and crazy mixing.  After a while I got so guilty
trying to look busy for 3 or 4 minutes at a time that I just picked up
my bass and started playing it in the breaks between mixes.

My mixing suffers with that thing around my neck, but it adds something
to the sound and makes me feel like I'm better utilizing myself up
there.

-GC

Yeah, sometimes smoking....um.... tobacco is not such a great idea
when your mixing.  I've spun with levels that were almost at solid red
for several mixes.

But you know, spinning on crappy equipment can only make you better
when your playing on a real system.  At some point you have to upgrade
but I would tough it out until you can't stand it or have the money to
get real monitors.

Message-ID: <20050607192146.48754.qmail@web30515.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Date: Tue, 7 Jun 2005 12:21:46 -0700 (PDT)
From: Gabriel B <retroactivefunk@yahoo.com>
To: Yo Momma Wears Mickey Gloves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <7a86c50c0506071112695157b1@mail.gmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] boy, the things you learn when you record yourself mixing

First things first, make sure your needles are matched
and in good condition.... No matter how good you are
at your levels, if your needles are mismatched, you'll
never get your levels right. As far as monitoring,
I've used studio monitors and bookshelf speakers at
home, honestly I don't think it makes much difference,
at least as far as levels are concerned. Buying a
mackie srm-450 would be overkill, but it is whats at
most parties/clubs. Using a mixer with good level
meters and good needles are essential to a seamless
mix. IMHO

G

--- Bam <invibe@gmail.com> wrote:

> and so now, the question of the hour!
> 
> for the DJs...what do you think is the best
> monitoring system for
> practicing at home?
> 
> i think some of the producers would suggest high end
> studio monitors,
> which makes sense because you want to hear things as
> true to sound as
> possible.
> 
> but
> 
> for the DJs, since most situations have poor
> monitoring when playing
> live (ex.  just loud sound, not clean, crisp nor
> balanced)...is it
> better to just go with big and loud rather than
> clean and balanced?
> 
> thoughts please.

> On 6/7/05, Chris Jackson <cjax@sbcglobal.net> wrote:
> > I wouldn't be so hard on yourself.  Though i've
> never
> > heard you play out, the lil computer speaks are
> > probably where your level issues lay.  You don't
> have
> > any *live* recordings of yourself to test this
> theory
> > against?  Do you use any type of sound processing
> > inline with your decks/mixer??  Like a
> > compressor/limiter or any sort of maximizer??  A
> > limiter isn't such a bad idea as it lets you set a
> > threshold on your levels...allowing any spikes to
> hit
> > a *brick wall* of sorts.  Nothing will get past
> the
> > limit you set.  GREAT for live sets when its a
> little
> > harder to control the levels.  You know, it's good
> you
> > bring this up, because there are TONS of DJ's who
> have
> > absolutely no sense of these level issues and
> sound
> > like complete crap when playing out.  Mastering
> the
> > EQ's and levels when playing are a HUGE part of
> rockin
> > the decks proper..IMHO.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] boy,
      the things you learn when you record yourself mixing

I wouldn't say good level meters are essential, they're nice to have but
anyone with a good ear can get things matched fine in the mix.

-Andrew

> First things first, make sure your needles are matched
> and in good condition.... No matter how good you are
> at your levels, if your needles are mismatched, you'll
> never get your levels right. As far as monitoring,
> I've used studio monitors and bookshelf speakers at
> home, honestly I don't think it makes much difference,
> at least as far as levels are concerned. Buying a
> mackie srm-450 would be overkill, but it is whats at
> most parties/clubs. Using a mixer with good level
> meters and good needles are essential to a seamless
> mix. IMHO
>
> G
>
> --- Bam <invibe@gmail.com> wrote:

Subject: Re: [sfraves] boy, the things you learn when you record yourself mixing

Monitor systems: Any speakers with good range should do.  Though I
have found that some consumer grade speakers end up making your
records sound pretty muddy.  I own a pair of cheap Event Electronics
P5's.  They've served me well for a few years now and sound awesome
for the price that I have paid for them, which was $300 for the pair.=20
There loud and clean.  They may not make you want to puddle in front
of them but they sound good.  If you can afford the Precision 8's,
there great and offer a lot more punch.

Loud doesn't always equal better.



On 6/7/05, Unagi <djunagi@gmail.com> wrote:
> Yeah, sometimes smoking....um.... tobacco is not such a great idea
> when your mixing.  I've spun with levels that were almost at solid red
> for several mixes.
>=20
> But you know, spinning on crappy equipment can only make you better
> when your playing on a real system.  At some point you have to upgrade
> but I would tough it out until you can't stand it or have the money to
> get real monitors.
>=20
> On 6/7/05, Bam <invibe@gmail.com> wrote:
> > so the other day i finally got my MD recorder working again and i
> > recorded myself and have been listening to it a few times.
> >
> > i can't believe how terrible my EQs and levels are.  why didn't anyone
> > else tell me how bad i suck?
> >
> > now granted, my speaker setup at home isn't the greatest.  i mix off
> > of two small computer speakers with a little sub under my desk.  i
> > pray to god that's why my levels sound so wack because if i've been
> > mixing like this when i play out....then the people that are booking
> > me are crackheads.
> >
> > i seriously need to get a better speaker setup at home for monitoring.
> >  anyone else pick up any tips from listening to your own at-home
> > mixes?
> >

Subject: [sfraves] [Clairitytechnotic] Dub, IDM, Ragga, Minimal Techno - Tuesday 6/7 - Tech-On Tuesdays @ Lit Lounge!

Tech-On Tuesdays
Anything but what you usually hear in San Francisco.
06/07/2005
at Lit Lounge San Francisco
10PM to 2AM
Free!
Lately I am getting into the idea of booking DJs and
artsits that are simply incredibly passionate about
whatever it is that they are playing/doing and not
worrying so much about what genres they play. This is
where I have been going more as an event/music curator
person lately. Hope you can dig it! ;) 
DJs for 06/07/2005
Jamie (dub, ragga, and other suprizes)
Jamie is my housemate, and he has the sickest, most
comprehensive collection of dub and ragga that i have
ever seen and heard. He is constantly playing at our
place, and he is always out searching for musical
gems! Amazing collection, Good stuff!
Miss Gawker - [holdfastrecordings, spaz]
Miss Gawker is bringing out the crazy mad techno
collection for the evening. 
spaz + techno = hell yeah, bring it on! =) 
Forest Green [Dim Sum, Sister SF, CF, FnF]
probably be playing some minimal techno, techno and
idm tuesday night. i've been going through a lot of
my old minimal techno collection lately and playing
with it again. it's yummy!!! =)
Just a note: The DJs may end up playing something
totally different than what is talked about above. It
is their call, but whatever they end up playing it is
sure to be dope! ;) 
Tech-On Resident DJs:
Andy W (viberation/refined music/tech-on)
Forest Green (dim sum/sister sf/cf/fnf/tech-on)
Jason
Juan Segovia (tech-on)
Li (viberation/tech-on)
Shazbot (moksha tribe/tech-on)
Lit Lounge is located at 101 6th St. at Mission, in
San Francisco. Admission is Free! This is a 21 and
over event.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] boy, the things you learn when you record yourself mixing

I say clean. If my records are going to sound like shit on the monitors 
when I play out, I at least want to hear how awesome they really sound 
when I play them at home!

On Jun 7, 2005, at 11:12 AM, Bam wrote:

> and so now, the question of the hour!
>
> for the DJs...what do you think is the best monitoring system for
> practicing at home?
>
> i think some of the producers would suggest high end studio monitors,
> which makes sense because you want to hear things as true to sound as
> possible.
>
> but
>
> for the DJs, since most situations have poor monitoring when playing
> live (ex.  just loud sound, not clean, crisp nor balanced)...is it
> better to just go with big and loud rather than clean and balanced?
>
> thoughts please.
>
> On 6/7/05, Chris Jackson <cjax@sbcglobal.net> wrote:
>> I wouldn't be so hard on yourself.  Though i've never
>> heard you play out, the lil computer speaks are
>> probably where your level issues lay.  You don't have
>> any *live* recordings of yourself to test this theory
>> against?  Do you use any type of sound processing
>> inline with your decks/mixer??  Like a
>> compressor/limiter or any sort of maximizer??  A
>> limiter isn't such a bad idea as it lets you set a
>> threshold on your levels...allowing any spikes to hit
>> a *brick wall* of sorts.  Nothing will get past the
>> limit you set.  GREAT for live sets when its a little
>> harder to control the levels.  You know, it's good you
>> bring this up, because there are TONS of DJ's who have
>> absolutely no sense of these level issues and sound
>> like complete crap when playing out.  Mastering the
>> EQ's and levels when playing are a HUGE part of rockin
>> the decks proper..IMHO.
>>
>> =)
>>
>> c h r i s
>>
>>
>> --- Bam <invibe@gmail.com> wrote:

>From: georgeC | origami <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
