>Yeah, I spin mainly house that doesn't lend itself to heavy
>techno-style eq tricks and crazy mixing.  After a while I got so guilty
>trying to look busy for 3 or 4 minutes at a time that I just picked up
>my bass and started playing it in the breaks between mixes.
>
>My mixing suffers with that thing around my neck, but it adds something
>to the sound and makes me feel like I'm better utilizing myself up
>there.
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] boy, the things you learn when you record yourself mixing

I saw a DJ in Miami a few years back that played
timbales and congos live during his set.  This was a
cool little place called Blue and it was the managers
birthday party.  Live percussion really adds a bright
straight ahead sound that's great with lots of house
music.  He literally had the girls dancing on the bar
and ass spanking.  Of course  there wasn't much room
anywhere else to dance or spank :) 

DJ Soulman or something.

Regards,

Peter

> now granted, my speaker setup at home isn't the greatest.  i mix off

i've been having problems with that exact same setup, Brandon...  bass under the desk, and 8"
Klipsch speakers duct taped to the wall 2.5 feet from my craniobrainium (also not the greatest.) 

Then I  move the mix to headphones, and to car stereo,   and I barely know what I'm doing wrong.

Any logical solution besides  $17,000 monitors and post-production by Paul van Armanweed?   
Trying different systems is enlightening, but that can suck up a lot of time.  George Lucas swears
my speakers are just as juicy as THX,  but hmmmmm....  my shit doesn't sound like John Williams.

Recording yourself is SSSSOOOOO important though, huh?  I always forget to do it.
Sound is so frustratingly seductive.  I love that bitch.  Some day I'll figure her out.

pleasantly surprised (at the bare minimum) by what a DJ can work into
a breaks set these days. ^_^

Subject: [sfraves] Deepfog fwd:  (nrr) Quote of the Day (Wed)

you know what's really funny is i work with someone that looks and acts 
just
like that napoleon dynamite kid.  can you imagine?

anyway, i'm remembering back in the days when i used to ride the casual
carpool.  i especially like it when people freak out on me when they
discover i'm getting in the car with some stranger.  only once did 
something
ever go awry with that, and the story is second hand i heard on the 
radio,
so here's how it goes.

apparently two people got into a casual carpool car in oakland probably 
and
as they rode into the city, they could hear someone banging from the 
trunk
and it sounded like they were yelling for help, of course muffled.  
they got
to the city, went to call for help, but no one had taken down the 
license
plate number, so no go.

anyone ever hear about this?  perhaps it's an urban myth, i don't know. 
  but
hey, it's an interesting, if not horrifying, story.

  The Twilight Laser Outpost <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <7a86c50c05060809287f047c58@mail.gmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] boy, the things you learn when you record yourself mixing

Check out some of the m-audio shits..  They have some really
inexpensive powered speakers that are not totally spectacular, but will
do the job handily, especially for djing.

Right now at home I use the same sort of shite comp speaks you use and
they are fushing hell to mix on for some reason..  At the studio I use
an old pair of 8" Event monitors and a crap Alesis amp, my old studio
monitor setup.  Rocks pretty hard, I must say, and if you find some guy
selling off his mid-90s-adat-era project studio on craigslist or
something you could probably find just that sort of setup for under
$300.  

Chances are, when you play out at clubs with even passable
soundsystems, you're sounding worlds better and mixing more tightly
without even knowing it.

Cheers matey,
-GC

Message-ID: <20050608175828.44825.qmail@web51502.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Wed, 8 Jun 2005 10:58:28 -0700 (PDT)
From: mo corleone <mo_corleone2@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <7a86c50c050607102542e1b4ee@mail.gmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] boy, the things you learn when you record yourself mixing

re: crackhead promoters and their bookings

live recordings are... humbling to say the least. i
pulled my set out of the Want It Radio file a couple
weeks ago and found it to be not quite at the level of
precision i would like. check it out:

http://www.modularmedia.net/upload/Beats_Wanted.mp3

the thing about recording yourself and listening to it
is that you lose that "live performance" quality that
gives your shows that extra kick in the ass. it's hard
to get the energy of a 3D performance to come across
on a 2D recording. a crowd that is dancing and having
a good time is a lot more forgiving of a slippy beat
or goofy bit of EQing here and there... you sitting at
your computer, stationary, critiquing your mix all
alone is 100 times more brutal. 

i agree that recording yourself is a great learning
experience. it also helps me get more familiar with my
records, which is obviously much needed when you're
loading up on new shit every week. i think it's
important to figure out where you can improve without
beating yourself up too much. everyone with an ear for
rhythm has probably heard a major headliner play an
imperfect set. it's not a perfect art.

having a great time and channelling that energy back
and forth with the crowd seems to compensate for
less-than-scientific mixing in my experience. as long
as everyone's still having fun, fuck it.

love,
mo

Subject: Re: [sfraves] boy, the things you learn when you record yourself mixing

Doh im a bit guilty of that!! Well not actually cause half the time I am 
adjusting an eq or fidiling with something volume,eq,fader etc.. I think it 
adds to the whole look. Cause let me tell you it is boring watching a DJ 
that looks like a robot. Case in point.

Jeno one of the best DJ's and technically sound some would say one of the 
best DJ's in SF. But have you ever watched Jeno spin? He is fucking so 
boring I could fall asleep. But most would say he is badd ass right?

DJ Donald Glaude. One of the most animated DJ's I have ever seen Full of 
fucking energy for EVERY set small or large crowd. Mixing well not the best, 
scratching well not the best. But I would rather listen to Don spin then 
Jeno cause he adds to the whole vibe of things.

If it is an energetic type of set (I.E Pumping House) (Banging Tekno) 
Macadio = jumping around like a wild monkey. If the set is more laid back 
deep house Macadio = more swaying to the song and singing if it has lyrics 
or even on that rare occasion bored waiting for the break to mix in the next 
track or the measure to end to do a mix in.


Mac

personally I've only ever learned one of two things when I recorded
myself mixing:

1. I suck.
2. I rock.

I have to admit I've learnt I suck more often than I've learnt I rock,
but the times I've learnt I rock have been a lot more fun.

right now my mixer is completely fux0r3d, I'm so burning to record a
mix right now. I got such fucking dope records in the mail yesterday.
my drumming is almost competent at this point too. :-P

ahwellandstuff.

Subject: [sfraves] Appeals Court Reaffirms Its Tone-Deaf Approach to Music

--=====================_1494171==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Why are all the stupid people in control?

http://www.fepproject.org/news/bridgeport.html

Appeals Court Reaffirms Its Tone-Deaf Approach to Music Sampling

(June 3, 2005) - Ignoring the critical balance between creativity and
property rights that is essential to a healthy copyright system, the
U.S. Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit today reaffimed the
maverick position that it first announced last year -- that the
well-accepted "de minimis" rule in copyright law does not apply to
sound recordings.

Under the court's latest ruling in Bridgeport Music v. Dimenson Films,
even two notes sampled from a sound recording is automatically
copyright infringement. (The court acknowledged that taking one note
probably would not amount to infringement, since copyright law defines
a sound recording as "the fixation of a series of musical, spoken, or
other sounds.")

The case involves a two-second, three-note guitar riff sampled from
the song "Get Off Your Ass and Jam," which was changed in pitch and
"looped" into another song, "100 Miles." "100 Miles" was used in the
soundtrack of a movie, I Got the Hook Up. The moviemakers were the
defendants in the case. A federal trial court ruled that the copying
was de minimis and therefore not actionable under copyright law. The
Sixth Circuit reversed last year, but then agreed to grant
"rehearing."

The decision on rehearing essentially repeated last year's ruling. It
ignored not only the defendants' argument that there is no basis for
abolishing the de minimis rule for sound recordings, but also a
friend-of-the-court brief filed by the Brennan Center for Justice and
the Electronic Frontier Foundation, which pointed out that Congress
had specifically said infringement of a sound recording only takes
place when "all or any substantial portion" -- that is, something more
than a de minimis amount -- of a copyrighted sound recording is
reproduced.1

The appeals court's decision was frankly driven by considerations of
practicality. The judges thought that a "bright line" rule would be
easier for the music industry to follow than the uncertainty of trying
to predict when a sample is unrecognizable, or otherwise short enough,
to be de minimis. Music industry practice is generally to get
permission anyway, the judges said; and "the market will control the
license price and keep it within bounds."2

What this analysis ignores is the whole sense of balance that is at
the core of copyright. Not every borrowing is actionable; the law does
not concern itself with trifles. A free culture cannot thrive when
even two notes of a tune are locked up and unavailable for use without
permission of the owner -- who, in most instances, is free to deny it.
And the court's push for predictability and bright-line rules runs
contrary to the "fair use" doctrine, so basic to copyright law.
Samplers will still have fair use defenses when they take reasonable
amounts of copyrighted music without permission, especially for
"transformative" purposes.3

The Sixth Circuit judges did acknowledge that the fair use defense is
still open in this case. But their acknowledgment is a grudging one,
and the whole thrust of their opinion is toward a rigid rule that will
suppress creative sampling of sound recordings unless the samplers
seek and obtain permission, and are able to pay for it.

"Get a license or do not sample," the judges write. "We do not see
this as stifling creativity in any significant way."4 This certainly
does not sound like a court that recognizes the importance of fair
use, or any other limits on the entertainment industry's vision of a
closed, controlled, and property rights-driven culture.

NOTES

1. Brief of Amici Curiae Brennan Center for Justice and Electronic
Frontier Foundation,
http://www.fepproject.org/courtbriefs/bridgeport.pdf, p. 6.

2. Bridgeport Music, Inc. v. Dimension Films, No. 02-6521 (June 3,
2005), slip opinion, p. 8.

3. See "The Fair Use Project,"
http://www.fepproject.org/fepp/fairuseintro.html, and "The Progress of
Science and Useful Arts,"
http://www.fepproject.org/policyreports/copyright2d.pdf, pp. 8-11.

4. Slip opinion, p. 8.

--5 Year Anniversary Campout--
June 17, 18 and 19th of the year 2005

The Stilldream Collective is ready to celebrate their 5 Year Anniversary of
amazing music under the stars.  They have been working hard for the last 6
months to ensure this is going to be the best Stilldream Event of ALL time.
We want you to be there, come be part of the Stilldream Experience!

100% Confirmed Line-Up!!!

The Attack People, LIVE!
www.abiotic.net / Mankind - Minneapolis, MN
It's our pleasure to welcome for the first time At a Stilldream Event, one
of the best and fastest growing acts in the United States. Thick driving
bass meets aggressive percussion. Lush analog sounds creating moody
atmospheres. The music is heavy yet groovy. Contrasting from one extreme to
the other with ease. This is The Attack People. They are the Sound of the
Future!

Dig-Dug
USC Events, Seattle
For over 7 years, DJ Dig-Dug has been a resident DJ for the Northwests
largest electronic music event production company, USC Events. his
underlying themes of warped basslines and intelligent drum loops bring a
sense of unity to his signature sound.   DJ Dig-Dug has developed a
following based on skillsnot hype.   Get Ready!

Treavor
www.Moontribe.org, Sound of Mind - SF
While most DJs are focused on one type of electronica, Treavor is known to
make the barriers between Techno, Trance, House and Breaks seem non-existent
often fusing them into one set. This keeps Treavor one step ahead and allows
him to be able to play any time of the night at any event.  Be Prepared for
the Treavor Experience!

References: <6.2.1.2.2.20050608114729.02a59828@mail.speakeasy.org>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Appeals Court Reaffirms Its Tone-Deaf Approach to Music Sampling

On 6/8/05, Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:
> Why are all the stupid people in control?

because control is stupid! hail eris. they can't stop the rock, yanno.

> http://www.fepproject.org/news/bridgeport.html
>=20
> Appeals Court Reaffirms Its Tone-Deaf Approach to Music Sampling
>=20
> (June 3, 2005) - Ignoring the critical balance between creativity and
> property rights that is essential to a healthy copyright system, the
> U.S. Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit today reaffimed the
> maverick position that it first announced last year -- that the
> well-accepted "de minimis" rule in copyright law does not apply to
> sound recordings.
>=20
> Under the court's latest ruling in Bridgeport Music v. Dimenson Films,
> even two notes sampled from a sound recording is automatically
> copyright infringement. (The court acknowledged that taking one note
> probably would not amount to infringement, since copyright law defines
> a sound recording as "the fixation of a series of musical, spoken, or
> other sounds.")
>=20
> The case involves a two-second, three-note guitar riff sampled from
> the song "Get Off Your Ass and Jam," which was changed in pitch and
> "looped" into another song, "100 Miles." "100 Miles" was used in the
> soundtrack of a movie, I Got the Hook Up. The moviemakers were the
> defendants in the case. A federal trial court ruled that the copying
> was de minimis and therefore not actionable under copyright law. The
> Sixth Circuit reversed last year, but then agreed to grant
> "rehearing."
>=20
> The decision on rehearing essentially repeated last year's ruling. It
> ignored not only the defendants' argument that there is no basis for
> abolishing the de minimis rule for sound recordings, but also a
> friend-of-the-court brief filed by the Brennan Center for Justice and
> the Electronic Frontier Foundation, which pointed out that Congress
> had specifically said infringement of a sound recording only takes
> place when "all or any substantial portion" -- that is, something more
> than a de minimis amount -- of a copyrighted sound recording is
> reproduced.1
>=20
> The appeals court's decision was frankly driven by considerations of
> practicality. The judges thought that a "bright line" rule would be
> easier for the music industry to follow than the uncertainty of trying
> to predict when a sample is unrecognizable, or otherwise short enough,
> to be de minimis. Music industry practice is generally to get
> permission anyway, the judges said; and "the market will control the
> license price and keep it within bounds."2
>=20
> What this analysis ignores is the whole sense of balance that is at
> the core of copyright. Not every borrowing is actionable; the law does
> not concern itself with trifles. A free culture cannot thrive when
> even two notes of a tune are locked up and unavailable for use without
> permission of the owner -- who, in most instances, is free to deny it.
> And the court's push for predictability and bright-line rules runs
> contrary to the "fair use" doctrine, so basic to copyright law.
> Samplers will still have fair use defenses when they take reasonable
> amounts of copyrighted music without permission, especially for
> "transformative" purposes.3
>=20
> The Sixth Circuit judges did acknowledge that the fair use defense is
> still open in this case. But their acknowledgment is a grudging one,
> and the whole thrust of their opinion is toward a rigid rule that will
> suppress creative sampling of sound recordings unless the samplers
> seek and obtain permission, and are able to pay for it.
>=20
> "Get a license or do not sample," the judges write. "We do not see
> this as stifling creativity in any significant way."4 This certainly
> does not sound like a court that recognizes the importance of fair
> use, or any other limits on the entertainment industry's vision of a
> closed, controlled, and property rights-driven culture.
>=20
> NOTES
>=20
> 1. Brief of Amici Curiae Brennan Center for Justice and Electronic
> Frontier Foundation,
> http://www.fepproject.org/courtbriefs/bridgeport.pdf, p. 6.
>=20
> 2. Bridgeport Music, Inc. v. Dimension Films, No. 02-6521 (June 3,
> 2005), slip opinion, p. 8.
>=20
> 3. See "The Fair Use Project,"
> http://www.fepproject.org/fepp/fairuseintro.html, and "The Progress of
> Science and Useful Arts,"
> http://www.fepproject.org/policyreports/copyright2d.pdf, pp. 8-11.
>=20
> 4. Slip opinion, p. 8.
>=20
>=20
>=20
>=20
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
>=20
> House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>=20
>=20
> The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the
> money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the
> world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
> -Hunter S. Thompson
>=20
> "Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience
> while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time befor=
e
> death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think
> ghosts will do it after?"
> -Kabir
>=20
> "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the
> rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually becom=
e
> visible."
> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
>=20
>=20
>=20
>=20

http://www.gilesgoatboy.org/

Subject: [sfraves] BSP:  MOKSHA TRIBE PRESENTS GROOVE IN THE GROVE JUNE 25TH

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

MOKSHA TRIBE PRESENTS GROOVE IN THE GROVE JUNE 25TH

With spring comes rebirth, and the Moksha Tribe Collective is returning 
this summer with infectious beats and happy vibes.

Our DIY ethic and not for profit focus will continue to be in full effect!!!

The fun recommences with "Groove in the Grove," a sunny, free day party 
scheduled for Saturday, June 25th, from noon to sunset.

Your groovers for the day:

Cubik and Origami
Marcine
DV8
Sheztek VS BAM (Evilbreaks)
Faye Valentine VS DJ Dilema aka DFD
Hypnotoad

    * Virgin Day Party Location
    * Bring your own drinks
    * Respect the location and pick up your trash
    * No Pets Allowed
    * $5 entry fee.  This fee is imposed by the park authorities.
    * There is ample parking outside of the park if you wish to avoid the 
entry fee but we encourage guests to pay the $5 to show appreciation for 
use of the facility.
    * We will be taking donations.  Reminder:  Moksha Tribe is Not for Profit.
    * Donations are strictly to cover costs incurred for throwing party; as 
usual monies after expenses will go to Larkin Street Youth Services:
www.larkinstreetyouth.org

Call the Moksha Tribe announce line the day of for directions:

415-564-4768

Or add your email addy to our in-house list for directions and update on 
all Moksha events:

1. visit

<http://groups.yahoo.com/group/mokshatribeannounce/join>groups.yahoo.com/group/mokshatribeannounce/join

-OR-

2. Send email to mokshatribeannounce-subscribe@yahoogroups.com




And when you're finished dancing in the sun with Moksha be sure to attend 
the official "Groove in the Grove" after party:

Fling! And RADI8R proudly present

BETA

The launch party for RADI8R RADIO.

Don't miss the Breaks/house/techno/dnb/progressive/ambient/electro 
extravaganza provided by our friends:

Chel-C Faith
Drop
Emergent
Ganucheau
Mark Martini
Mediaboy
Unagi
VTG

8pm-late night
Free before 10:30, $5 after
142 Taylor between Eddy & Turk
<http://www.radi8r.com/>www.radi8r.com


Looking forward to seeing all of you on the dance floor. Been awhile.

Much love,

Apollo for Moksha Tribe






Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: Re: [sfraves] boy, the things you learn when you angle your speakers

Well, I never measured angles and shit, but stick 2 in front of you, and 
  mount 2 on the wall in back of you- they're not that directional.
I personally would not hook up the center for optimal stereo effect.

Put em where it sounds good- your ear is the ultimate measure-
The main idea is to have them all hitting you at the same time, meaning 
you want to have the same distance from your ear to all of them.

Man- playing Wipeout Fusion with these things was nothign less than a 
surreal experience :)

As for the bass box, placement is more key- under the desk is likely to 
create resonant/stagnant waves-
The port is already tuned for a specific range-
I personally prefer to have this sub basically standalone, aiming the 
port at a solid tall hard surface about 4 inches away.
IE- just stick it in the corner of the room, facing the speaker at one 
wall and the port at the other, equalizing the distance on both sides.

I don't recommend this setup as any sort of super-accurate monitor 
system or anything- but I find little value in things like that-
When it comes to making something sound good- to me it comes down only 
to knowing your speakers, whatever they are.
Listen to your favorite CDs on them, things you know- things of which 
you know the intricacies by heart-
I know how things sound on this system- it's powerful and goes deep 
enough to vibrate me at sub-bass frequencies- bringing out all the low 
madness.
I am simply recommending it as an *outstanding* system for the money.
(btw, the $399 list price you see is ridiculous- I picked up mine for $139)

--
jupiter accepts your offer...

aim:IMFDUP

"yankee scotty went to town and rode her like a stallion- stuck a dildo 
in his hat and won the gold medallion"

Message-ID: <20050609064417.31574.qmail@web32413.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Date: Wed, 8 Jun 2005 23:44:16 -0700 (PDT)
From: Peter Rothman <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject:  Re: [sfraves] boy, the things you learn when you angle your speakers

The optimal speaker placement depends on what you are
trying to achieve.

Speaker placement for optimal stereo performance
depends on the room and where you sit. See:

http://webphysics.davidson.edu/faculty/dmb/py115/speaker_placement.htm
(from
http://webphysics.davidson.edu/faculty/dmb/py115/MusTechS05.htm)

Home theater speaker placement is another bag
entirely, with specific requirements for a 5.1 setup:

http://forum.ecoustics.com/bbs/messages/34579/129023.html

Speaker placement for live events is another thing
again: http://www.tiem.utk.edu/~gross/sounden2.txt

Then there are exotic speaker arrangements like
ambisonics and ambiophonics.  FWIW I and a few other
guys built a medium sized (3000 watt) 4 speaker
ambisonic speaker array in a warehouse in Santa Cruz
in  the early nineties. It was pretty impressive and
we got strong directional effects within a 10 meter
sweet spot.  We also did some fun experiments putting
sine waves though it and playing with pockets of
constructive and destructive interference.  See
http://www.ambisonic.net/ and http://audio.muddle.de/

Hope this stuff is interesting even if its not very
helpful immeadiately ;)

Regards,


That other Peter

Subject: Re: [sfraves] boy, the things you learn when you angle your speakers

I use (a different) pair of Cambridge Audio computer speakers (btw,
would reccommend their "Soundworks" system) for monitors at my home
studio.  This sounds like a rather masochistic thing for somebody who's
been engineering audio for as long as I have, but actually, it works. 
I reference my mixes on a really good pair of headphones (Grado SR225)
and all is well.

The best config I have found is to put the sub directly behind my (LCD)
computer monitor, so if something weird is going on or it's
overloading, I can hear it, instead of the distortion artifacts being
masked by my desk.  I then took two small tins (hershey's cocoa tins
are about the right size), filled them with sand, placed them about 3
feet apart on the desk, and set the satellites on them.  It seems a
little nutty to mass-load tiny little speaker stands like that but I
find it really makes a difference- it cuts down on stand resonance and
helps couple the speakers to the desk.  (derh audio geekery, sorry)  

I've made so much music in there that if I felt there was really
something lacking in the reproduction, I would have bought some actual
studio monitors ages ago, but frankly, I've grown to know these little
tykes, and they've mixed some great sounds.

..plus they're the perfect yin to my Dynaudio BM15a (monitors at the
bigger studio)'s yang! ;)

Cheers matey,
-george cochrane | origami

P.S. - was listening to "Nothing Left But The Future" the other day
while doing stuff around the house- that's a rad CD, my man. 


--- Peter A Sandifer <petersandifer@sbcglobal.net> wrote:

> > Set em up in surround-style ~3 feet from each ear, and the sub 
> > thundering below?
> > Ahhhhhhh...
> 
> so this is getting kinda mathematicy.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Question du Jour: How many people are lurking on SFRaves?


Do you want everyone to post something every day? One would think that 
there'd be way too many posts to handle. Personally, if I don't have 
anything of interest to say, I'd best keep my mouth shut.

> I use (a different) pair of Cambridge Audio computer speakers (btw,
> would reccommend their "Soundworks" system) for monitors at my home
> studio.  This sounds like a rather masochistic thing for somebody who's
> been engineering audio for as long as I have, but actually, it works.
> I reference my mixes on a really good pair of headphones (Grado SR225)
> and all is well.
>
> The best config I have found is to put the sub directly behind my (LCD)
> computer monitor, so if something weird is going on or it's
> overloading, I can hear it, instead of the distortion artifacts being
> masked by my desk.  I then took two small tins (hershey's cocoa tins
> are about the right size), filled them with sand, placed them about 3
> feet apart on the desk, and set the satellites on them.  It seems a
> little nutty to mass-load tiny little speaker stands like that but I
> find it really makes a difference- it cuts down on stand resonance and
> helps couple the speakers to the desk.  (derh audio geekery, sorry)
>
> I've made so much music in there that if I felt there was really
> something lacking in the reproduction, I would have bought some actual
> studio monitors ages ago, but frankly, I've grown to know these little
> tykes, and they've mixed some great sounds.
>
> ..plus they're the perfect yin to my Dynaudio BM15a (monitors at the
> bigger studio)'s yang! ;)
>
> Cheers matey,
> -george cochrane | origami
>
> P.S. - was listening to "Nothing Left But The Future" the other day
> while doing stuff around the house- that's a rad CD, my man.
>
>
> --- Peter A Sandifer <petersandifer@sbcglobal.net> wrote:
>
>> > Set em up in surround-style ~3 feet from each ear, and the sub
>> > thundering below?
>> > Ahhhhhhh...
>>
>> so this is getting kinda mathematicy.
>

--=====================_13296828==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

ALERT: Important Medical Marijuana Vote in Congress Next Week

In the wake of Monday's Supreme Court ruling in the Angel Raich medical 
marijuana case, the US House of Representatives is now scheduled to vote on 
an important pro-medical marijuana amendment next week. If you haven't 
already used our web site to write to Congress in support of the 
Hinchey-Rohrabacher amendment, please take a moment to do so right now -- 
visit 
<http://stopthedrugwar.org/medicalmarijuana/>http://stopthedrugwar.org/medicalmarijuana/ 
to send your letter and for further information. If you have already, 
please visit 
<http://stopthedrugwar.org/medicalmarijuana/>http://stopthedrugwar.org/medicalmarijuana/ 
and click on the "tell a friend" link to get others to the web site as 
well. This is a really important vote coming at a really important time, 
and your support could make the difference.

Not all the news this week has been bad. Just one day after the Supreme 
Court ruled against us, medical marijuana supporters scored a victory in 
Rhode Island when the State Senate overwhelmingly passed pro-medical 
marijuana legislation despite the governor threatening a veto. Now it moves 
on to the State House of Representatives. Read about it tomorrow morning in 
issue #390 of Drug War Chronicle. Also appearing in the Chronicle tomorrow, 
DRCNet's own interview with Angel Raich herself! Visit 
<http://stopthedrugwar.org>http://stopthedrugwar.org to read Drug War 
Chronicle (or to subscribe if you're not already), or to learn about 
DRCNet's other programs.

Again, please visit 
<http://stopthedrugwar.org/medicalmarijuana/>http://stopthedrugwar.org/medicalmarijuana/ 
to tell your US Representative to vote yes on the Hinchey-Rohrabacher 
amendment. You can also find out how your Rep. voted on Hinchey-Rohrabacher 
last year. And use our tell-a-friend form or forward this e-mail to get 
more people to the web site sending letters in to Capitol Hill. With your 
help we can make this happen!

And remember, the Supreme Court ruling did not change anything -- state 
laws protecting medical marijuana patients from state and local law 
enforcement still stand, and as Rhode Island showed, can still pass. Don't 
let any drug warrior get away with claiming otherwise.

Subject: [sfraves] [skylab2000] new track out now


Some quick news on a rare downtempo release from skylab2000. It's a basselectro version of the Beatles song "Two of Us", and features vocals by Leah Reich. (A preview is available on iTunes)


-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"KOCH Records released the latest compilation in its "ReGrooved" electronic music series, "Beatles ReGrooved," on June 7, 2005. 

The Beatles continue to exert a hold on the musical imaginations of both fans and artists worldwide with each new generation discovering the genius of their work on their own terms. 

So it is fitting to find 14 classic Beatles songs re-imagined and "ReGrooved" by some of the biggest names in the electronic world on this unique and fascinating compilation. "Beatles ReGrooved" is the follow-up to 2004's critically praised and successful "Classics ReGrooved," which upon release immediately shot to #1 on the iTunes Music Store Electronic Chart. 

Featuring electronic kingpins such as John Selway, skylab2000, MystiQuintet, EROS and Jay Atwood, "Beatles ReGrooved" will appeal to longtime fans as well as aficionados of the chill out and down tempo scenes. 

Now available in major stores and on iTunes."


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 

There are still some summer dates open for skylab2000, so if you do a club or event, please contact us. Easy and reasonable to have skylab2000 play at your event! 

Check out http://skylab2000.com

for ten miles winds smell of blood in the fresh battlefield.

outside Ohdub Castle, we stand in the rising sun.

Subject: [sfraves] DJ RAP ATTACKS! 

--=====================_36885406==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit


DJ RAP ATTACKS!

Drum 'n' bass is one of electronic dance music's lost causes, a British 
attempt to reunite hip-hop with dance floors and digital futurism that 
today has hit the nadir of its 15-year evolution. DJ Rap is one of 
electronic dance music's brightest stars, a force of nature who has 
transcended drum 'n' bass to become an all-genre spinner and crossover 
artist whose profile only seems to get higher. So why is Rap  after 
successfully recording dance-pop for Sony, appearing in television 
commercials for Twix candy bars, and becoming one of the most visible women 
in dance music  revisiting the dark, dejected, and relatively defunct 
sound of d 'n' b?

"The same reason dogs lick their balls," she answers defiantly. "Because I 
can."

Actually, under the guise of punk-ish rebellion and do-it-yourself 
determination, Rap is returning to the hyperkinetic, rumble-and-roll sound 
of the British underground to avenge herself upon some of the U.K. scene's 
old haters. Her one-finger salute is Bulletproof, a hybrid mix-CD split 
80/20 between her own productions and remixes and a few other artists' 
tracks. It says she can still bring the beats and battle with the best, 
even if she's moving on. The disc comes on like a buzzing swarm of 
180-beats-per-minute drums, loose-firing rave synths, metal-guitar loops, 
and, of course, tectonic bass  evil, ghetto bass. It's all a bit angry, 
albeit cathartic, like the soundtrack to a Matrix flick, circa 2010. And 
Rap's not dodging any bullets, Keanu Reeves-style. She's just letting them 
bounce off. "Ever since I started doing music," she says, while being 
primped by two stylists for a photo shoot at Avalon Hollywood, "I've always 
gone outside the box."

Famously, the U.K. drum 'n' bass scene engineered its own demise by 
selfishly fracturing into crews, eschewing cooperation and co-promotion, 
and digging deeper underground. Instead of sharing music, many 
DJs-turned-producers hoarded it, thinking that having an exclusive track 
would make them more desirable on the high-paying club circuit, which was 
worth more to them than a club hit. Rap, after getting in on the genre's 
ground floor and seeing it rise to stadium-DJ status, was in the middle of 
it all when things collapsed under the weight of ego in the late '90s.

"The heyday for me was 1990 through '97," she says. "After that, I got a 
little bitter. Here I was, having earned my chops, and not one person wants 
to share a tune with me. I like to call it the assholes club. I don't want 
to be a hater, but I really didn't get any love."

Born Charissa Saverio in Singapore in 1969, Rap eventually settled in the 
U.K., where as a teenager she discovered the late-'80s rave scene. She 
began producing drum 'n' bass even before there was a name for it: Some 
called it "hardcore," others just "breaks." Many hailed the new sound  
with its Jamaican heritage and heavy reliance on funk and rap loops  as 
the U.K.'s answer to American hip-hop. Rap began spinning vinyl as well as 
making it, appearing on pirate radio, DJing at clubs, and becoming a name 
brand in a scene producing such breakout stars as Goldie, Roni Size, and 
LTJ Bukem.

After signing with Sony, she surprised the breaks world with the 1999 
pop-house album Learning Curve, released to decent reviews and sales 
(500,000 copies worldwide). A few mix-CDs after Learning Curve, Rap seemed 
ready to leave drum 'n' bass behind. In 2002, she modeled for Calvin 
Klein's global "Dirty Denim" campaign and moved to L.A. to escape the U.K. 
dance industry and concentrate on being Rap instead of merely the queen of 
drum 'n' bass. In 2003, she spun records in that Twix commercial. Last 
year, she recorded a  gasp!  house-music mix-CD sold by Armani Exchange. 
She also got a new manager, the notoriously business-savvy, Washington, 
D.C.-based Kurosh Nasseri, and things began to click.

"The first thing he did was cut down on my gigs and got me rested and got 
me inspired in the studio," she says. "I wanted to get back on top."

These days, she's holding down a jet-set residency at New York's Crobar 
club, playing occasional house-music sets at L.A.'s intimate Monday Social, 
and finishing her next artist album, which she describes as "crossover 
electronic." Rap is loving life, even though it's a relatively obscure one 
in this starstruck town, even though her home studio gear was stolen last 
winter by a former coproducer. Sponsors such as Apple, M Audio, and Yamaha 
stepped up with free replacements. It's all good.

"I'm not here to be famous," she says. "I just want to have a nice home and 
garden and be peaceful."
And yet, her latest mix doesn't play at all like a soundtrack for feng-shui 
decorating or a white-flag-raising hymn; rather, it rocks like a battle 
cry. "It's like, fuck you," she says. "I am bulletproof."
[]


http://www.lacitybeat.com/article.php?id=2190&IssueNum=105





Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_36885406==.ALT--

Okay SFRaves-

 The countdown is on.

 In twelve days I will, at long last, turn twenty-one.

  My days of HJBC are long over (but not forgotten), the wild nights of 
my candy-kid youth now compacted into a single bead, fur and 
glitter-filled box.

 A new era is beginning... and I want to start it off right.

  Given that I've been in school land and not going out as much, I'm a 
bit out of the loop, so what's a booty-shaking, disco-loving, 
homo-house-adoring girl to do?

 Dates:
*Wed, June 22nd (actual birthday)
*Fri, June 24th
*Sat, June 25th

  And ideas? I could care less about the people honestly. I just want me 
some deliciously funky house to boogie to. : )

 heart,
  Alida

Subject: [sfraves] Oh yeah... Wed night Review: Qool, Studo Z, & WINk

Due 2 some babysitting issues & the kid getting picked up late which
caused me 2 commute 2 the city later than I was suppose 2.. I kinda
actually miss my class.. so it was kinda aaarrrrggghh...  I mean.. i got
in2 the City by literally 8:30 & was like, "well.. class end in an hour,
roll sheet was probably picked up already... bleh"!

I ended up @ 111 Minna 4 the Qool Happy Hour... all I gotta say is Wow...
I never knew people got that sloshed after work.. LoL.. Hello 2day.. but
naw man... the DJ was spinning this Groovy ass Proggy House & Breaks set..
YUM!!!  I met up MC Child & chilled w/ my Bro 4 a while.. YAY!!

Then I went 2 Studio Z 4 the Suicide Prevention fund raiser... Mista Jonas
was on the decks playin' some funky house & Oooh Jonas.. I Loved It!!! 
Muse went on after him & played some Hip Hop & Jungle... YUMMY!!! It was
Dope walkin' around lookin' @ the art & talkin' 2 the neo groovy hip
people there!!!  TIM.. I LOVE THE PAINTING!!!

Then I walked 2 Butter 4 some ;) WINK... it was CooL.. there was this
semi-preview screening  of this movie called "15" I think.. it was Dope..
Sir Bam was on the decks playin' this Groovy 80's set!!  Dude... again...
Thanks 4 Prince!!!  Loved it!!  & Taylor!!!  I missed her so much!!  Now
Butter was fun... my Homie Big J (the bartender I've been tellin' ya about
over the years )made me this drink & man... WOW!!  It got me nice &
buzzed!!!

Well... I had 2 like leave around 10:45 2 get over 2 BART.. but man.. it
was such a fun night!!!

YAY!!!!


-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> ObY {8O)

Hmmmm.  Booty-shakin', homo-house, the funk.  I recommend Fag Fridays at 
the Endup.  Residents Neon Leon, David Harness, Rolo and Pete Avila  -- 
pretty much a quarter of the early SF house scene.  Crowd welcoming.

http://www.fagfridays.com/discoplayers.htm

while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] SFRaves Calendar: Please add your events by 12noon today

Dear SFRavers,

If you have events to add to the SFRaves calendar, please add them to the 
calendar by 12noon today to be included in this week's edition.

Need to know how to add yourself and the events to the calendar?

Connect w/ FREE Event Info & Calendar,  Publication & Promotion @  SFRaves 
Calendar!

     * The SFRaves Calendar is a decade young :) (March 1995 -> March 2005)
       Please send all input, requests, suggestions, Development & QA 
comments regarding the SFRaves Calendar to karina@hyperreal.org.
       For More Information: please refer to the SFRaves Calendar FAQ
     * 2005-06-10 : SFRaves Calendar Stats: SFRaves Calendar User 
Registration has skyrocketed to 325 groups and 2302 people as of June 
2005!

     * Subscribe the SFRaves Calendar Mailing List:
           o 1) * To subscribe to the SFRaves Calendar list, send an email 
message to: sfraves-calendar-subscribe@hyperreal.org
           o 2) Connect with the SFRaves Calendar - FREE Promotions, Group 
& People Profiles, Event Self publication: 
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/
           o 3) Register to create an account @ 
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/add_person_form
           o 4) If applicable, add a Group for your Collective, Production 
Crew, Label, Event Promotion, et al: 
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/groups/create_group_form
           o 5) Add/Publish and Event to the SFRaves Calendar: 
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/add_event_form

Thank you.

In love and light,

Karina

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  The Rotting Soul of the San Francisco 49ers

--=====================_21216171==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Edge of Sports
June 8, 2005

The Rotting Soul of the San Francisco 49ers

By Dave Zirin

There is an old expression that "the fish rots from the
head." Right now the San Francisco 49ers are stinking
like a salmon in the sun. Their more general fall from
grace has been a matter of public spectacle, as the
"Team of the 1980s" has become a mismanaged, cap-
strapped embarrassment. Yet the stench that envelops
the Niners invaded the rest of our lives last week with
the leaking of a media training video meant to "guide
players on how to deal with San Francisco's unique and
diverse community." A noble goal, to be sure. San
Francisco is home to significant Asian, Pacific Island
populations, and is synonymous with Lesbian, Gay,
Bisexual, and Transgender community and culture. The
video, however, was not aimed to help players with
cross-cultural understanding - but instead an exercise
in rank bigotry.

How to talk to the Bay Area Asian community? There is a
mock interview with a actor playing a Hop-Sing "bucked
tooth Asian man". How to reach out to LGBT football
fans? There is a mockery of Gay weddings and clucking
about "bending for the soap" in the county jail. Even
worse, the team's PR department enlisted players such
as Julian Peterson to act in the video, with the All-
Pro linebacker playing a "bum begging for food"-
homelessness being just another hilarious sight on the
Bay Area landscape.

"I'm sitting here dumbfounded," said Rose Pak, head of
the Chinese Chamber of Commerce. "You know, this is the
21st Century. And this is San Francisco, a city where
30% of residents and 40% of schoolchildren are Chinese
Americans. In this day and age, for a home-based major
sports group to be so insensitive ... their behavior so
disgusting is beyond words."

Particularly noxious are the comments of the video's
director, former Niners PR Director Kirk. Reynolds.
Reynolds said that, 'This was the only way I felt I
could get the players' attention." The Niners
themselves have compounded this by defending the video,
which basically proves Reynolds' point. Peterson said,
"It was supposed to be an in-house thing" and safety
Tony Parrish compared its 'sarcasm and wit' to the Dave
Chappelle show on Comedy Central.

These comments drew a pained response from Hall of Fame
college basketball coach John Thompson. Thompson said
on his DC radio show, "I would have walked out of that
video on general principle not only because of the so-
called humor but more because the ORGANIZATION is
showing through that video what they think of me as a
man - especially as a Black man - saying that the only
way they can get through to me, the only way they can
get me to listen, is by playing to jokes, playing to
bigotry and stupidity. [That organization] is saying
everything about the way they think about me and my
intelligence by showing this.... Any player who now is
defending this garbage is also defending their own
treatment as something less than a fully developed
man."

Thompson is absolutely right. He is right to criticize
the players for not putting their foot through the
video screen. He is also right that the root of the
problem lies with the team, not a wayward employee or
insensitive players. This is also the assessment of a
certain team consultant named Dr. Harry Edwards.
Edwards was the chief organizer of the 1968 Olympic
Project for Human Rights, and the author of the classic
book The Revolt of the Black Athlete. In the late
1960s, he stood for principles of mass revolt and
equality by any means necessary. In more recent years,
he has said and stood for far less, most notably being
a paid advisor for the Cosby show, and an ESPN Sports
Century talking head. But with the release of this
video, Edwards could not be silent, saying, "This was
not locker room humor; this was front office personnel.
The athletes who took part in this skit were asked to
do so by the fourth-ranking front office person in the
organization".

This culture of intolerance on an organizational level
is deeply embedded. In November 2002, Niners running
back Garrison Hearst was asked if he would ever accept
a Gay teammate. Hearst did not equivocate. "Aww, hell
no!' the All-Pro said. 'I don't want any faggots on my
team. I know this might not be what people want to
hear, but that's a punk. I don't want any faggots in
this locker room." Fullback Fred Beasley further gave a
window into the organizational culture saying, "If
people really know what's going on in the locker room
and what we joke about every day, it would be a big
deal each and every day. It's not a big deal to us."
Then former team president Terry Donahue - the most
powerful man in the organization - sneered it off
saying, "Frankly, we're way too busy trying to block
and tackle and hit passes to be involved in a social
issue. I think we're just going to move on.'

Residents of the Bay Area shouldn't have let them 'move
on' then, and sure as hell shouldn't let them move on
now. As Thom Lynch, president of the SF LGBT Center
said, "The 49ers benefit from their relationship with
the city, but they have responded by belittling and
ridiculing its diversity."

There is nothing inherently racist or homophobic about
professional sports, or even the NFL. Yet too often the
politics of oppression are given free reign to wander,
fester, and nest. Every sports fan in the Bay Area who
doesn't share the idea that homelessness, Gay rights,
and Asian minstrelsy are punch lines has an obligation
to stand up. Let the team know that they may be named
the 49ers, but this ain't 1849.

Dave Zirin is the News Editor of the Prince George's
Post in Prince George's County Maryland, for which he
writes the column Edge of Sports. His work can be read
at www.edgeofsports.com. To have his column sent to you
every week, just e-mail edgeofsports-
subscribe@zirin.com.

Contact the author at dave@edgeofsports.com

http://www.edgeofsports.com/2005-06-08-134/index.html



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] SFR PDA Calendar V 3.0

--0-963839877-1118525670=:16032
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: QUOTED-PRINTABLE

Dear SFRaves Community -

The SFR PDA Calendar is available for mobile devices, Devices running Palm=
=20
OS Software, PDAS running various other Operating Systems & Smartphones=20
supported by Avant Go Software.

Please help me test the calendar output. To test and use the SFR PDA=20
Calendar, please review the following information:

SFRaves.org PDA Calendar v. 3.0

REQUIREMENTS: To use the SFRaves.org PDA Calendar and AvantGo.com, you
need a PDA which runs Palm OS 4.x + / 5.x +; OR A PDA or a smartphone,=20
and a desktop internet connection.

The AvantGo mobile internet service works on nearly all Palm OS=AE (palmOne=
,=20
Sony, Handspring, etc.), Pocket PC (HP, Dell, Toshiba, etc.), Win CE, and=
=20
Symbian Series 60 (Nokia 3650, etc.) devices.

SETUP: Easy as 1, 2, 3:

1. Register & Download Avant Go Software @
https://my.avantgo.com/register/account_form_1.html

2. Select Content / Add the SFRaves PDA Calendar Avant Go Channel Content=
=20
by loading the following URL when logged into the Avant Go Website:

http://avantgo.com/mydevice/autoadd.html?title=3DSFRaves.org%20Calendar&url=
=3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Fwww.sfraves.org%2Fcalendar%2Fsfrcalpda.txt&max=3D175&depth=
=3D0&images=3D0&links=3D0&refresh=3Dalways&hours=3D2&dflags=3D127&hour=3D0&=
quarter=3D00&s=3D00

3. Sync Your Device once you have added the SFRaves PDA Calendar Avant GO=
=20
Channel from your desktop, Desktop Cradle, wireless connection or=20
Wi-Fi service.

Specifications and Requirements:

Device Requirements

Note: The absence of a particular device from this list does not mean that=
=20
it is incompatible with AvantGo; it simply means that it has not been=20
tested.

Palm:Palm OS Version 4.x or prior running on the following devices: Palm=20
III, Palm IIIx, Palm IIIe, Palm IIIc, Palm V, Palm Vx, Palm VII, Palm=20
m100, Palm Zire, Palm Tungsten W, Handspring Visor, Handspring Treo,=20
Symbol SPT 1500, Symbol SPT 1700, TRG Pro. Memory Requirements: At least=20
428KB of free memory, plus additional space for data.

Palm OS 5:Palm OS Version 5.x running on the following devices: Palm=20
Tungsten T/C/T2/T3/E/T5, Palm Zire 21/31/71/72; Treo 600/650, Sony CLIE=20
NX, NZ, UX series. Memory Requirements: At least 999KB of free memory,=20
plus additional space for data.

Windows CE:Version 2.x or later using SH3, MIPS, or ARM processors,=20
running on the following devices: Casio Cassiopeia 2400, E10, E100; Compaq=
=20
Aero 2100, 1500; Philips Nino 500, Velo 500; HP Jornada 420, 680; Sharp=20
Mobilon Pro 5000. Memory Requirements: 605KB-920KB of free memory, plus=20
additional space for data.

Pocket PC:Windows CE version 3.0 or later using SH3, MIPS, or Strong ARM=20
processors, running on the following devices: HP/Compaq iPAQ series, Dell=
=20
Axim series, Toshiba eSeries, Casio Cassiopeia E115, HP Jornada 540=20
Series. Memory Requirements: 605KB-920KB of free memory, plus additional=20
space for data.

RIM BlackBerry Devices with RIM browser 3.7+. Memory Requirements: No=20
software installation required.

Symbian OS v 6.1 (Series 60) Mobile Phones: Symbian OS running on the=20
following mobile phones: Nokia 3600 series, 7650. Memory Requirements: At=
=20
least 1200KB of free memory, plus additional space for data.

Symbian OS (UIQ) Mobile Phones: Symbian OS running on the following mobile=
=20
phones: Sony-Ericsson P800, P900, P910. Memory Requirements: At least=20
1135KB of free memory, plus additional space for data.

Symbian OS (UIQ) Mobile Phones: Symbian OS running on the following mobile=
=20
phones: Sony-Ericsson P800, P900, P910. Memory Requirements: At least=20
1135KB of free memory, plus additional space for data. Desktop=20
Requirements

Operating systems: Window 98 SE, Windows 2000 SP4, Windows XP Pro, Windows=
=20
XP Home; Macintosh OS 8/9 (Palm OS 4 devices only).

Browsers: Windows: Netscape Navigator 6.0 (or greater), or Microsoft=20
Internet Explorer 4.0 (or greater). Macintosh OS: Netscape Navigator 6.0=20
(or greater), or Microsoft Internet Explorer 4.5 (or greater).

Software: Palm: HotSync Manager 3.0 (or greater). With Macintosh OS=20
desktop (Palm only): HotSync 2.6.1 or greater. Windows CE: ActiveSync 3.0=
=20
or greater. Pocket PC: ActiveSync 3.1 or greater. Symbian OS (Series 60):=
=20
PC Suite. Symbian OS (UIQ): PC Suite

Connectivity: Symbian OS Series 60: Requires an IR or Bluetooth connection=
=20
to an Internet-connected laptop or desktop computer

Account Management:
https://my.avantgo.com/account/

Avant Go User Support:
http://avantgo.custhelp.com/cgi-bin/avantgo.cfg/php/enduser/entry.php

Avant Go User Guides: http://www.avantgo.com/doc/ami.html

What is Avant Go?  http://www.avantgo.com

- Avant Go is PDA software with dual interfaces: a web application
interface coupled with the functionality of Avant Go Sofware to sync any
device running Palm OS. Avant Go provides access to online web content via
Avant Go web Channels. These channels point to content which is hosted and
maintained by outside sources. SFRaves.org PDA Calendar content source is
@ http://www.sfraves.org/calendar/sfrcalpda.txt

With AvantGo, you can get the SFRaves Calendar as an Avant Go Channel=20
specially formatted for your PDA or smartphone on the go!

It is simple to to sign up and download the software. AvantGo is Free!
No wireless connection is necessary. Just sync 'n go from your desktop.

If you do have a wireless capability on your PDA or smartphone, or Wi-Fi=20
hotspot service, use it around town for updates. Your can sync the=20
data in realtime with phones that support this type of=20
functionality.

What is the SFRaves.org PDA Calendar?

- A condensed ascii text format of the SFRaves.org Calendar, coupled with
the functionality of Avant Go Software and a Palm OS Device, PDA or=20
SmartPhone.

DETAILED INSTRUCTIONS:

TO ACCESS THE SFRAVES.org PDA CALENDAR:

1. AVANT GO USERS

NEW USERS: Sign Up / Register HERE:=20
https://my.avantgo.com/register/

EXISTING USERS: Login HERE:=20
https://my.avantgo.com/home/ or https://my.avantgo.com/login/index.html

2. Once Registered and Signed In: Go to the following AvantGo URL to add=20
the SFRaves.org PDA Calendar to your account and PDA device, Wireless=20
Device or Smart PHone:

http://avantgo.com/mydevice/autoadd.html?title=3DSFRaves.org%20Calendar&url=
=3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Fwww.sfraves.org%2Fcalendar%2Fsfrcalpda.txt&max=3D175&depth=
=3D0&images=3D0&links=3D0&refresh=3Dalways&hours=3D2&dflags=3D127&hour=3D0&=
quarter=3D00&s=3D00

For the RAW ASCII SOURCE of the File, You can also copy the text to your=20
device by downloading the most current copy of the SFR PDA Calendar @

http://www.sfraves.org/calendar/sfrcalpda.txt


Release Notes:

Various Devices have different memory requirements & limitations for=20
display and storage of this file. Please leave at least 100k available=20
memory on your device to download the SFR PDA Calendar source. Please note=
=20
the size may vary due to the number events displayed at any given point of=
=20
the SFR PDA Calendar Update.

Most PDAS, Smartphones and other Wireless Devices vary in support for file=
=20
size, type and memory allocation. Depending on the size of this file, the=
=20
SFR PDA Calendar may also be a condensed to display on various device=20
types.

This version includes expanded support for newer devices, Smartphones and=
=20
other Mobile Device types.

Please send feedback and bugs to karina@hyperreal.org

Regards,

Karina

Subject: Loveparade San Francisco 2005 Newsletter

  Loveparade, the world's largest electronic music festival
triumphantly returns to San Francisco on Saturday, September 24,
2005. Mark your calendars now for what promises to be one of the
pre-eminent electronic music events in the world.

  A full "Loveweekend" of festivities is planned. Beginning Friday,
September 23rd and running through Sunday, September 25th, with the
main event, the Loveparade on Saturday, September 24th. This year's
event promises to be even bigger and better than last years, with an
expected 75,000 attendees dancing up San Francisco's Market Street to
our new festival location at the Civic Center.

  The Float Application for this years event is now online. The
deadline for entries is JUNE 30TH! Go to our online float application
{http://www.loveparadesf.org/forms/float.php} to apply for a float
for this years event.

  Thanks to our Travel Sponsors who have secured us special rates for
Loveparade San Francisco attendees. Please go to our travel deals
page {http://www.loveparadesf.org/travel_deals.php} to find contact
information for participating hotels. Make sure you remember to tell
them you are coming to Loveparade San Francisco to secure the special
rate....better get there soon they are getting booked up fast!

  To stay updated on Loveparade San Francisco 2005 including official
events, float applications, sponsors, partners, as well as travel and
festival details, please visit our website at www.loveparadesf.org
{http://www.loveparadesf.org}

Loveaprade San Francisco would like to thank the following sponsors:

  {http://www.friendster.com/} {http://www.apple.com/itunes/}
{http://www.ingrooves.com/}

  {http://www.sfweekly.com/} {http://www.eastbayexpress.com/}
{http://www.djmixed.com/}

  {http://www.eventvibe.com/} {http://nitevibe.com/}
{http://www.remixmag.com/}

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  ALERT: Important Medical Marijuana Vote in Congress

--=====================_18767390==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

ALERT: Important Medical Marijuana Vote in Congress


1. Call Your Congressional Representative.  Urge their support of the 
Hinchey-Rohrabacher Amendment to the Justice Appropriations bill.

Next Tuesday at noon, Congress will have their first opportunity to act on 
an invitation extended by 6 Supreme Court Justices to protect medical 
marijuana patients.  Call your U.S. Representative on Monday or Tuesday 
morning and urge their support on the Hinchey-Rohrabacher Amendment to the 
Justice Appropriations bill.

The Hinchey-Rohrabacher medical marijuana amendment would prevents the U.S. 
Department of Justice -- including the Drug Enforcement Administration -- 
from wasting taxpayer money to arrest, prosecute or otherwise undermine 
state medical marijuana laws.

CALL YOUR U.S. REPRESENTATIVE.  Urge their support of the 
Hinchey-Rohrabacher Amendment to the Justice Appropriations bill.  Members 
of Congress' offices can be reached through the U.S Capitol Switchboard at 
(202) 224-3121 or through the online congressional directory at 
http://clerk.house.gov/members/index.html



             Script Text Option 1:  Formal

Hello, my name is ______________.  I am a constituent of Representative

___________________.

                         I am calling today to urge Representative 
________________ to vote in favor of the Hinchey-Rohrabacher Amendment to 
the Justice Appropriations Bill on Tuesday.

It is important to remember that this amendment does not legalize medical 
marijuana.  It simply prevents the Department of Justice from using funds 
to prevent 10 states from implementing State laws authorizing the use of 
medical marijuana in those states.

             Script Text Option 2:  Emotional

Hello, my name is ______________.  I am a constituent of Representative
___________________.

                         I am calling today to urge Representative 
________________ to vote in favor of the Hinchey-Rohrabacher Amendment to 
the Justice Appropriations Bill on Tuesday.

As noted by the majority of US Supreme Court decision in Gonzales v. Raich, 
just because the federal government has the power to arrest patients, 
doesn't mean its wise to do so.  Demonstrate compassion and a respect for a 
culture of life.  Vote to protect patients' right to live and die with dignity.



2. Call Nancy Pelosi, House Minority Leader, to urge her to use her power 
to help whip the Democratic vote on the Hinchey amendment!

Pelosi's Phone Numbers:
San Francisco: (415) 556-4862
Washington, D.C.: (202) 225-4965

Script Text:

Hello, my name is ______________.  I am a  ___________  resident.

                         I am calling today to urge Representative Nancy 
Pelosi to use her power to help whip the Democratic vote on the 
Hinchey-Rohrabacher Amendment to the Justice Appropriations Bill on Tuesday.

Pelosi represents the tens of thousands of patients in California who 
depend on medical marijuana. Demonstrate compassion and a respect for a 
culture of life by protecting these patients from federal actions.

-- 
Rebecca Saltzman
Executive Assistant
Americans for Safe Access
(510) 251-1856
www.safeaccessnow.org



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Like house music? Thank Lee Michaels

Sunday, June 12, 2005

By Lauren FitzPatrick
Staff writer

Back in the day, Lee Michaels made you jack to the sound of the 
underground. You just didn't know it was him.

The man who now sits in the Will County state's attorney's office as head 
spokesman dreamed up an idea that made listeners all over jack  or dance 
frantically  to blended beats and music, and made Chicago synonymous with 
this new form: house music.

It was a revolutionary idea for radio, one that appealed to a wide 
audience. Five nightclub disc jockeys of different ethnicities came from 
all over the Chicago map, each bringing his own style, his own sound to the 
airwaves of WBMX-FM (102.7), a defunct station now known as V103.

They were called the Hot Mix 5, and they put their station over the top, 
while changing the way radio DJs spun records.

Michaels' instincts kicked in as his station was running neck and neck with 
its urban competition, WGCI-FM (107.5). He figured he had to come up with a 
sound unique to the smaller WBMX to seduce young listeners.

"I was always a big fan of how music was blended in discotheques," he said.

The idea was simple: Take popular club DJs who cover the tastes of a wide 
audience, mix them up, showcase their skills first every Saturday night, 
then every weekend, then every day.

The Hot Mix 5 was born from five solid DJs whose mixes were strung together 
by a young energetic host.

"I wanted to have a diversified reflection of the Chicago market," Michaels 
said. "The concept was very simple: Their unique talent of blending music 
together technically was going to be part of the magic of what we were 
going to do on the air."

So with Farley "Jackmaster" Funk, Mickey "Mixin" Oliver, Scott "Smokin" 
Silz, Ralphi Rosario and Kenny "Jammin" Jason, WBMX spanked WGCI-FM in the 
ratings.

"It was unheard of during that time for a station like WBMX to play a 
pretty diverse group of music," he said.

CONTINUED:  http://www.dailysouthtown.com/southtown/yrtwn/swest/121swyt5.htm





Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

no, you don't understand. my penis is about 325 feet long. and it
didn't just sort of run out of juice. I've never used fucking Viagra,
give me some credit. it actually FELL OFF. it landed on my leg,
crushed my ankle, sent me to the hospital with broken bones, rampaged
through downtown san francisco knocking down buildings and smashing
cop cars, got shot at, fled to the pacific ocean, swam to seattle,
killed an entire pod of killer whales that attacked it on the way --
marine biologists had been studying this particular pod for over
thirty years -- and got in a fight with a giant octopus the minute it
arrived in the Puget Sound. of course then when it came on land in
Seattle it was already fighting the octopus, so the devastation it
caused in Seattle made the damage to downtown San Francisco look like
child's play. meanwhile I'm watching all this on CNN from a hospital
bed while my leg is in a cast. "giant penis ravages pacific northwest.
we go now to wolf blitzer." and of course for the first time in my
life the nurses are actually sexy. two of them (TWO OF THEM!) make
jokes about how since my leg is in a cast my girlfriend's going to
have to "get creative" and here I am, do nurses hit on me when my dick
is actually in the same state? oh no, that would be too easy, but now
my cock is wrestling a giant octopus in Seattle, that's when the saucy
nurses show up. must have been one of the most frustrating experiences
of my life, and to top it off the city of SF, the city of Seattle, the
marine biologists who were studying the killer whales, the National
Geographic Society (who was funding the research) and a number of
property management companies from both cities are all after me in
court now, not to mention the EPA -- both killer whales and giant
octopi are endangered species, and my cock eventually won the fight --
which in addition to levying me with fines and threatening me with
jail time is also trying to get my cock classified as a violent animal
and thus have me charged with the violation of numerous leash laws in
municipalities all up and down the Pacific coast (which to me seems
kind of petty).

so yeah, just wanted to clarify that, it never ran out of juice, it
literally fell off, although it might be more accurate to say that it
escaped and went on a rampage. (and I don't even want to get on the
subject of how they eventually reattached the damn thing.)

>September 23rd and running through Sunday, September 25th, with the
>main event, the Loveparade on Saturday, September 24th. This year's
>event promises to be even bigger and better than last years, with an
>expected 75,000 attendees dancing up San Francisco's Market Street to
>our new festival location at the Civic Center.

abilities to try and catch more attention across the
globe.  If all you have for me are negative responses,
I simply will not respond.  Constructive criticism is
always welcome.  My website is....

www.thescythianproject.com

Check out some tunes!  There are plenty there!

Thanx,
John

P.S.:  I'm really looking forward to see what goes
down in your scene.

Like house music? Thank Lee Michaels

Sunday, June 12, 2005

By Lauren FitzPatrick
Staff writer

Back in the day, Lee Michaels made you jack to the sound of the=20
underground=2E You just didn't know it was him=2E

The man who now sits in the Will County state's attorney's office as head=20=

spokesman dreamed up an idea that made listeners all over jack =AD or danc=
e=20
frantically =AD to blended beats and music, and made Chicago synonymous wi=
th=20
this new form: house music=2E

It was a revolutionary idea for radio, one that appealed to a wide=20
audience=2E Five nightclub disc jockeys of different ethnicities came from=
=20
all over the Chicago map, each bringing his own style, his own sound to th=
e=20
airwaves of WBMX-FM (102=2E7), a defunct station now known as V103=2E

They were called the Hot Mix 5, and they put their station over the top,=20=

while changing the way radio DJs spun records=2E

Michaels' instincts kicked in as his station was running neck and neck wit=
h=20
its urban competition, WGCI-FM (107=2E5)=2E He figured he had to come up w=
ith a=20
sound unique to the smaller WBMX to seduce young listeners=2E

"I was always a big fan of how music was blended in discotheques," he said=
=2E

The idea was simple: Take popular club DJs who cover the tastes of a wide=20=

audience, mix them up, showcase their skills first every Saturday night,=20=

then every weekend, then every day=2E

The Hot Mix 5 was born from five solid DJs whose mixes were strung togethe=
r=20
by a young energetic host=2E

"I wanted to have a diversified reflection of the Chicago market," Michael=
s=20
said=2E "The concept was very simple: Their unique talent of blending musi=
c=20
together technically was going to be part of the magic of what we were=20
going to do on the air=2E"

So with Farley "Jackmaster" Funk, Mickey "Mixin" Oliver, Scott "Smokin"=20=

Silz, Ralphi Rosario and Kenny "Jammin" Jason, WBMX spanked WGCI-FM in the=
=20
ratings=2E

"It was unheard of during that time for a station like WBMX to play a=20
pretty diverse group of music," he said=2E

CONTINUED:  http://www=2Edailysouthtown=2Ecom/southtown/yrtwn/swest/121swy=
t5=2Ehtm





Moksha Tribe:  www=2Emokshatribe=2Eorg

House Music 101:  http://livingart=2Ecom/raving/articles/housemusic101=2Eh=
tm


The US is:  "=2E=2E=2Ea nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all t=
he=20
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the=20=

world who tries to make us uncomfortable=2E"
-Hunter S=2E Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive=2E  Jump into experience=20=

while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before=
=20
death=2E  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think=20=

ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the=20=

rest of society=2E It makes audible the new world that will gradually beco=
me=20
visible=2E"
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) Quote of the Day (Mon)

thanks to will for forwarding my quotes last week.  had some unexpected
internet debacle, but things seem to have fallen back into place for the
time being.

today's quote is a dialogue from stephen king's dark tower 5, which i'm
7/8 of the way through.  for those of you that didn't keep up with the
series, or never read it, roland the gunslinger is searching for the dark
tower, and in his travels, has come upon father callahan, one of the
central characters in one of his other well known books, salem's lot.

i apologize in advance if anyone finds it offensive, it just seemed an
interesting little exchange to me.

--

"Your Man Jesus seems to me a bit of a son of a bitch when it comes to
women," Roland said.  "Was He ever married?"

The corners of Callahan's mouth quirked.  "No," he said, "but his
girlfriend was a whore."

"Well," Roland said, "that's a start."

- Dark Tower V, Wolves of the Calla, pg 484-485.

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Jackal & Hyde - Live PA! - DNA Lounge

if you like the sounds of breaks and electro, do not miss this show!

check out Jackal & Hyde's newest material on their Myspace page:
http://www.myspace.com/jackalandhyde

it goes boom!!!


Evil Breaks & StrategiK present:
Jackal and Hyde Live
Sunday June 26th, 2005
@ DNA Lounge (375 11th st)

the first 100 people get in 2 for 1, and the door is an amazingly low
price of only $5.
$2 off all drinks till 11pm, thanx to DNA.


Jackal and Hyde - Live (Hallucination/Scheme Addict Records) West Palm Beac=
h, FL
-special visuals provided

Jackal & Hyde have been called "the purveyors of the hardcore-electro
sound" (electro-core), a combination of industrial laden electro
beats, and psychotic keys. Jackal & Hyde was formed in 1998 by
partners Scott Weiser, and Todd Walker in an effort to combine a
harder edge sound with the dancefloor sensibility of Electro or
"Techno-Bass". Besides their original work, Jackal & Hyde's sound has
been requested for multiple remix productions including Kid Rock, Love
& Rockets, and Biochip C. Scott Weiser, who is most recognized for his
work in I.B.M. (Industrial Bass Machine), and the duo Dynamix II, who
have written such dancefloor classics as "Give The DJ A Break" and
"Feel The Bass", has been writing and producing dance music for over a
decade. Scott's influences range anywhere from classic Industrial to
Classical, while partner Todd Walker's influences come from Miami
Ghetto Bass and Industrial Dance. As Jackal & Hyde, Scott and Todd
push the boundaries of dance music and set the standards for the new
school of electro.


J-Break (Cyberian Knights/Afterdark Records) Tampa, FL

J-Break has been rocking the decks all across North America and
Europe, playing his signature style of breaks and electro. After his
debut mix cd, "Bio:Mechanik" on Subculture Records, Jackal & J-Break
founded the electro label, Cyberian Knights Recordings, to release
"This is the Sound of Underground," as heard on the Baby Anne "Mixed
Live: Las Vegas" mixed compilation on Moonshine. J-Break has done
numerous studio collaborations with international renown artists
Infiniti, Fixx, Johnny Cage, and Josef Plante, to name a few. Be on
the lookout for J-Break this fall as he hits the road for his
"Barcelona, Spain" CD Release Tour.


Along with local Breakbeat superstars:

Tung (Brass Tax/Subalicious)

Aaron Jae vs. Bam vs. M.O.D. (Evil Breaks/SFBreaks.org)
-Special 3 by 4 old school funky set

Influence vs. Jay Vigor (Beatsfactory.com/Strategik/London Breakz)
-2 by 4

Capt'n Kirk (Space Cowboys)

Jackal and Hyde will also be bringing their own visual specialist all
the way from Florida to help put on one of the most memorable
performances you will EVER witness. And on top of the already super
ridiculously cheap price of this amazing show, Evil Breaks will be
giving away tons of free tickets to members of its mailing list, so if
you're not a member, sign up now.

Jackal and Hyde Live
Sunday June 26th, 2005
@ DNA Lounge (375 11th st)
first 100 2 for 1
$2 off all drinks till 11
$5 entry=20
--=20
--------------------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.evilbreaks.com


June 17th:  Breakin' Tha House @ Red Eye Lounge
June 24th:  Subscience 2 Year
June 25th:  Moksha Tribe Day Party
June 26th:  Jackal & Hyde @ DNA Lounge
July 3rd:  Thrust w/ Lee Coombs @ Mighty
July 16th:  Clandestine
July 22nd:  Evil Breaks TBA

problems is the day you have stopped leading them.  They have either lost

Subject: Re: [sfraves] BSP: Jackal & Hyde - Live PA! - DNA Lounge

So I picked up a couple of their records a few years back and was
immediately in love with their sound, about a year later I was at a NYE
party in Utah and this awesome live act came on but I was just like, man,
this sounds like jackal and hyde which stupid me didn't realize they were
actually playing the show.  This is going to be an awesome show and for $5
and $2 drinks til 11.. I'll see you at the bar :)

-Rayn
