Subject: [sfraves] UNKNOWNS- SEND ME YOUR MIXTAPES!

-------------------------------1118785112
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Er...  or I guess mix CDs is what you crazy youngin's are calling it these 
days. ;  )

So yes, in case you heard- the rumor is true.

The nutty SFRP  kids that brought you Connecting The Bay, Relic, 
Amalgamation, AEC and a host of  other fun parties are back in full force.... and we're 
planning another party  for you guys the weekend of July 15/16th.

Here's where you come in: being  that this is SFR and we're doing the party 
for you all, and we all know there  are a billion and one (okay, maybe two 
dozen and one) bedroom DJS on here, we  want to give you a shot. This is your 
party, shouldn't you be able to play at  it?

Send us your mixes so we can all uuwww and awww over them and wonder  why you 
haven't yet been discovered and aren't playing all over Europe already.  If 
you fit the bill, we'd love to add you to the line-up. :  )
 
Hell, even all you super star DJs  out there can send a sample in. We'd be 
more than happy to listen to those  too!

Please note, though, that we will be listening to them at our next  meeting, 
so we need these tapes in the mail in the next couple of days in order  to 
reach us by Monday. If you can't get it in the mail, you can always try to  
e-mail it to me or drop it by to one of us in person or in our mailboxes.   Reply 
back and I'll send you the addy to send the mixes to.

Also, if you  want to get involved/come to the meeting, shoot me an e-mail 
and I'll give you  the details. We're always looking for fresh blood. >;  D

heart,
Alida


-------------------------------1118785112--

Subject: [sfraves]  BSP: [[[ *~STILLDREAM~* ]]] This is it, its this weekend! - Tickets in stores now

[[[[[[ *~STILLDREAM~* ]]]]]]
--5 Year Anniversary Campout--
June 17, 18 and 19th of the year 2005

The Stilldream Collective is ready to celebrate their 5 Year Anniversary of
amazing music under the stars.  They have been working hard for the last 6
months to ensure this is going to be the best Stilldream Event of ALL time.
We want you to be there, come be part of the Stilldream Experience!

100% Confirmed Line-Up!!!

The Attack People, LIVE!
www.abiotic.net / Mankind - Minneapolis, MN
It's our pleasure to welcome for the first time At a Stilldream Event, one
of the best and fastest growing acts in the United States. Thick driving
bass meets aggressive percussion. Lush analog sounds creating moody
atmospheres. The music is heavy yet groovy. Contrasting from one extreme to
the other with ease. This is The Attack People. They are the Sound of the
Future!

Dig-Dug
USC Events, Seattle
For over 7 years, DJ Dig-Dug has been a resident DJ for the Northwests
largest electronic music event production company, USC Events. his
underlying themes of warped basslines and intelligent drum loops bring a
sense of unity to his signature sound.   DJ Dig-Dug has developed a
following based on skillsnot hype.   Get Ready!

Treavor
www.Moontribe.org, Sound of Mind - SF
While most DJs are focused on one type of electronica, Treavor is known to
make the barriers between Techno, Trance, House and Breaks seem non-existent
often fusing them into one set. This keeps Treavor one step ahead and allows
him to be able to play any time of the night at any event.  Be Prepared for
the Treavor Experience!

Mystre (www.djmystre.com, Reverb Records - SF)
Dyloot (www.skillsdj.com, Deep Voices - Berkley
Serch (www.theserch.com, www.m13graphics.com - Chicago)
Nick Tornetta (Future Tracks, www.nicktornetta.com - Seattle)
Detonate (Good Beat, www.klubstompers.com - Seattle)
Sarah Shoxx (Shoxx Wear, www.klubstompers.com - Seattle)

Effendi (www.klubstompers.com - Seattle)
Icon (www.djicon.com, Reverb - SF)
B-Smarter (Equalize, Sparxx - Seattle)
Michael Liu (www.illuminationrecords.com, San Jose)
Mubali (Mistress of Evil Recs, Trishula Recs, Germany)

Subject: [sfraves] WR: 1015, BIG, Rhythm Method, Haight Street Fair, Compression,
      & End Up

OK... lemme try 2 do this in short... LoL...

Saturday evening to night:

-On BART.. rode the whole 1/2 trip w/ this Awesome Girl, Marnae, & I swear
man.. we totally beared our souls 2 each other & actually shared our lives
w/ each other w/in 1/2 hour 2 each other.. it was Dope & I swear... ooh
Wow... I hope we hang out again!

-5th St Posse... went 2 their pad & actually hung out w/ every1 who was
there! So fun!

-1015.. got there early 4 this meeting thingie thingie.. Salso was
playingin the front room.. saw some bay raves kiddies waiting outside 4  1
of the DJs who was spinning there that night...

-Cat Club... the BIG {Bruthas In Grime) crew well.. I dunno if this is a
monthlie there or what.. but like OK.. there was Grime spinning in the
front room when i got there that turned 2 hip hop then back 2 Grime again
when lexxus hit the decks... in the back, there was a mash up of Jungle,
Breaks, Hip Hop, Grime, & Raggae... it was sick.. like Subtek got there
kinda in the middle of it all, I think Megatron was up there a few times
spinning, I can't remember the names of the other DJs up there.. bu it was
Dope!  MC Child was holdin' it down w/ the mic!!  LoL... 7 this all
happened in the hour & 1/2 I was there.

-Rhythm Method... since i was walkin' towards Van Ness 2 catch a bus...
stopped in.. E$KR was on the decks throwin' down some hard dubby Jungle
tunes.. Loved it!!!  It was fun seeing some famil faces & dancin 4 a
bit...

Got 2 the City Crash Pad 4 the night around 12:30, didn't fall asleep 'til
2:30. woke up @ 4AM.. LoL.. & now starts the 24 Hr adventure:

6AM-8PM: OK.. Haight Street Fair was Dope... Honestly.. I dunno how the
whole fair was considering I had 2 work @ the Masonic Stage... oh my gosh
man.. all the band that performed were SICK!!!  Jeno's band that he
manages, Slot Macine, was Dope!  I mean.. they're kids ages 8-12 & they
threw down w/ the punk rock tunes! The lead singer.. this Dope lil' Boy,
even played key board & sang @ the same time like 2 songs...

But my most Fave band of the day was Switchback (www.switchbackband.com)
from LA.. I mean.. they were the only band there that played w/ Raga & SKA
Grooves in some of their songs & they were sick!!!  YAY.. I got a free CD
& Shirt from them... I mean... it was like refreshing on Sunday 2 hear
them 'cause it was slightly diff from what the othr bands music.  Well.. &
the Reggae Band that closed our stage!

Oh Yeah... all the DJs that spun in between bands were sick!  Music ranged
from like India-ish kinda trance, 2 Booty Club House, Booty House, House,
Breakbeats, & Jungle!  YUM!

8PM-9:30PM: went 2 this mini lil after party around the corner on Page
street... Felix the Woof was spinning Acid House & Breaks on the decks &
we just seriously chilled on the sofa like zombies...

10PM-2AM: Got over 2 Compression @ the Cellar... OK.. so dope... if y'all
ain't been there lately.. you'd be totally surprised w/ the way it looks
now.. neato! Mal opened.. nice set, Femme Fatale continued, & Lexxus
closed... oh my goodness man.. I was in fuckin' Heaven!!  I Loved it! It
got pretty packed also!!  Not mondo packed, but packed!!!

2AM-4AM: Went 2 End Up w/ some Compression Stragglers.. it was fun!! 
LoL... ummm.. it was Deep House w/ some Disco House on theside... very
yummy!!

So that was my weekend.. in short.. good music.. Groovy People.. Mondo
fuckin' Groovy times!!!  YAY!!!

Hope U all had a nice weekend!

YaY!




-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> ObY {8O)

We live on Ocean Beach.  If a tsunami hits here we toast.


CRESCENT CITY, Calif. -- A major earthquake struck about 80 miles off the 
coast of Northern California on Tuesday night, prompting a tsunami warning 
along the Pacific coast.

The U.S. Geological Survey said the 7.0 magnitude quake struck at about 
7:50 p.m. Pacific time about 90 miles west-southwest of the coastal 
community of Crescent City.

A tsunami warning is in effect from the California-Mexico border all the 
way north to Vancouver Island, British Columbia.

Residents are being evacuated from low-lying areas of Crescent City.

Copyright 2005 by <http://www.foxreno.com/news/2455821/detail.html>The 
Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, 
broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] tsunami

seems like the warning was canceled.  still, better to be
prepared.

(4 minutes ago)
http://news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story&u=/afp/20050615/sc_afp/usearthquake_050615054047

LOS ANGELES (AFP) - A major earthquake measuring 7.0 on the
Richter Scale struck off the coast of California, triggering a
brief tsunami warning along the US West Coast, seismologists
said.

But while the large temblor rattled nerves along the
earthquake-prone coast from Mexico to Canada, there were no
immediate reports of any damage or injuries and authorities
said there was no threat of a tsunami.

The quake struck 10 kilometers (six miles) beneath the Pacific
Ocean, 146 kilometers (91 miles) west-southwest of the
California coastal town of Crescent City at 7:50 pm (0250 GMT
Wednesday), according to the US Geological Survey.

The Pacific Tsunami Warning Center (PTCW), a US
government-funded body that monitors tidal waves in the Pacific
Ocean only, issued a warning that a tsunami might be on the
way, but quickly cancelled it.

warning on  TV and took my kids to higher ground (Twin
Peaks.)  There was a few hundred people up there doing
the same thing.  Amusingly I had a CD with the Sven
Van Hees track "Tsunami" on it in my car so we
listened to that.

was a little adventure anyway.  And BTW how come our
new fancy tsunami warning system (there are several
horns down near Ocean Beach) didn't go off?  Hmm.

At 11:06 PM 6/14/2005, Peter Rothman wrote:
>I live a bit south from you near the zoo.  We saw the
>warning on  TV and took my kids to higher ground (Twin
>Peaks.)  There was a few hundred people up there doing
>the same thing.  Amusingly I had a CD with the Sven
>Van Hees track "Tsunami" on it in my car so we
>listened to that.
>
>Felt a bit dorky after the warning was lifted, but it
>was a little adventure anyway.  And BTW how come our
>new fancy tsunami warning system (there are several
>horns down near Ocean Beach) didn't go off?  Hmm.
>
>Regards,
>
>Peter


I was listening to music with my earphones on so I would never have heard 
the warning.  Many  will go out blissfully ignorant of impending disaster 
in this fashion :-)  My neighbor came over and rang the doorbell and my 
partner, who was on the computer, heard the bell and received the warning 
from her.  Then all my neighbors bailed.  We, or I (my partner was running 
about) decided to stay.  Actually I nearly went up to the beach.

I've pretty much decided that if, like, a nuke, tsunami or whatever is 
coming and I've got a half hour to leave I'm going to stay in my home with 
my birds,  drop some E, smoke a joint,  and go down with the ship :-)

Love,

Apollo

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] :BSP: Koroma Returns to Thump XM Radio-Avalon 6.17.05(fri)

6/17/05(Friday)

XM Satellite Radio-Avalon 9:00pm

Hey Peoples!
Just wanted to let ya know once again I'll be on Thump Radio XM. So if you
missed the first show here a chance to catch me again on another Thump
show.  Big thanks to everyone that tuned in.... and of course the Thump
Crew.
So if you don't have XM Satellite no worries, you can use the link below to
hear the mix.
 Koroma

 www.koroma.com/music/wbtlnet.m3u

The International Air Waves receives a surprise return visit by Koroma.
Making his first appearance on Thump Radio's "The Move", Koroma returns
again this month too debut his 2005 mix CD entitled "Written Between the
Lines" Koroma's style of Tribal and Progressive, shines through brilliantly
with his latest mix compilation. If you don't know who this man is. You
better tune in and find out, because not knowing is "Easier Said Than Done"

> It's finally here, Subscience's 2 year anniversary
> celebration event! They are
> celebrating their 2nd year of running by exhibiting
> over 40 local talents
> representing almost every major breaks and drum &
> bass crew in the Bay Area and
> beyond.

seven, if you count her twin sister.

gonna see her again? And what's up with all this "who's single" and

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: House votes on Marijuana

--0-1288935631-1118877652=:23971
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

06/15/05
 
>>> Guess it's what I'd expect from a "Republican" Congress. . . 
- Chuck
 
House again defeats medical marijuana use (Reuters) 
 
06/15/05
 
http://news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story&u=/nm/20050615/pl_nm/usa_congress_marijuana_dc_1
 
WASHINGTON (Reuters) - The House of Representatives on Wednesday refused to allow cancer patients and other severely ill people to smoke marijuana to ease pain, as opponents argued the measure was a back-door attempt to legalize the substance. 
 
By a vote of 264-161, the House rejected a measure that would have stopped federal law enforcement authorities from prosecuting medical marijuana users in 10 states that allow it when prescribed by doctors.

This marked the third time since 2003 that the House has defeated the initiative. This year, supporters picked up 13 votes.

Proponents of the controversial legislation hope to build Republican support and could try for another House vote next year. Only 15 Republicans out of 231, supported the measure.

"While we're disappointed that the amendment did not pass, a record 161 House members voted today to stop arresting medical marijuana patients," said Rob Kampia, executive director of the Marijuana Policy Project in Washington.

The House debate came about one week after the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that the federal government -- not the states -- had the power to regulate drug use.

Rep. Mark Souder (news, bio, voting record), an Indiana Republican who worked to defeat the marijuana initiative, accused supporters of "hiding behind a few sick people to try to in effect legalize ... marijuana in this country."

"The rhetoric about marijuana as a treatment for medical purposes was probably dreamed up at some college dorm," he said.

Rep. Maurice Hinchey (news, bio, voting record), a New York Democrat, countered that the measure would not encourage the recreational use of marijuana or legalize it nationwide. "It would give relief to people suffering from horrific diseases and allow their doctors to decide which drugs will work best," Hinchey said.

Supporters were trying to attach the measure to a $57.5 billion bill to fund several federal agencies next year, including the Department of Justice.

Smoking marijuana can ease nausea caused by cancer treatments and can stimulate appetite in patients too sick to eat. Religious groups and some medical organizations have supported its use for patients suffering from cancer, AIDS, glaucoma and other severe illnesses.

Rep. Dana Rohrabacher (news, bio, voting record), a conservative California Republican, called on the House to respect state laws, including California's, which allow medical marijuana.

"Let's not have a power grab by the federal government at the expense of these poor patients and the right of doctors to make these decisions and not politicians," Rohrabacher said.

Alaska, California, Colorado, Hawaii, Maine, Montana, Nevada, Oregon, Vermont and Washington have similar laws allowing the use of medical marijuana.

On Tuesday, the Bush administration urged the House to defeat the marijuana measure, saying Congress should not "circumvent the recent Supreme Court decision." It added that "states should not have the authority to independently designate a substance that has not been recognized by the Food and Drug Administration as an approved medicine."

Souder said smoking marijuana is unnecessary now that a federally-approved prescription drug, Marinol, is available to treat nausea and vomiting associated with cancer chemotherapy.

But Angel Raich, a Californian with an inoperable brain tumor and other medical problems who brought the marijuana case to the Supreme Court, on Monday said she has severe reactions to prescription drugs. "I need cannabis every two hours to survive," she said.

Rep. Lynn Woolsey (news, bio, voting record), a California Democrat who supported the amendment, told House colleagues that her now deceased mother used marijuana to treat glaucoma.

--0-1288935631-1118877652=:23971--

thousand years and has been passed only by direct transmission while in =
altered states of consciousness.=20

through a live ritual designed to create a psychic state where the =

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: NESARA? 

Yo, I haven't posted in a long time because I've been up in Vancouver, BC studying. Recently I have come accross a very facinating political phenomina and I was wondering how many you all at SFraves know about NESARA. (National Economic Security and Reformation Act). I remember how politically savy a lot of you SFravers were so I thought I'd pass this along and find out who knows about it and who doesn't. 

Apparently the Act (if passed by congress):
Forgives credit card, mortgage, and other bank debt due to illegal banking and government activities. Abolishes income tax 
Abolishes IRS; creates flat rate non-essential "new items only" sales tax revenue for government 
Increases benefits to senior citizens 
Returns Constitutional Law 
Establishes new Presidential and Congressional elections within 120 days after NESARA's announcement 
Monitors elections and prevents illegal election activities od special interest groups 
Creates new US Treasury currency, "rainbow currency," backed by gold, silver, and platinum precious metals 
Returns Constitutional Law to all our courts and legal matters. 
Initiates new U.S. Treasury Bank System in alignment with Constitutional Law 
Eliminates the Federal Reserve System 
Restores financial privacy 
Retrains all judges and attorneys in Constitutional Law 
Ceases all aggresive, US government military actions worldwide 
Establishes peace throughout the world 
Initiates first phase of worldwide prosperity distribution of vast wealth which has been accumulating for many decades 
Releases enormous sums of money for humanitarian purposes 
Enables the release of new technologies such as alternative energy devices 

Pretty cool eh? If you want to read more about it check out this link
http://www.nesara.us/pages/history.html

----------MailBlocks_8C7418A50334596_660_3D09_MBLK-M19.sysops.aol.com

I hadn't heard about this at all but it's very interesting. I'll get into the material some more when I have some time. The only thing I see that I don't like is abolition of income tax in favor of sales tax, because usually that leads to a bigger burden on poor and working people, but overall the plan sounds very good. Pretty far-reaching stuff. 
 
In a related vein, who in SF Raves knows that the Wizard of Oz offers an allegory about the gold standard? "Follow the yellow brick road" is a reference to using gold as a standard instead of inflationary paper money. 
 
Happy Friday!  
jonnyr

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: NESARA? 

> In a related vein, who in SF Raves knows that the Wizard of Oz offers an allegory about the gold standard? "Follow the yellow brick road" is a reference to using gold as a standard instead of inflationary paper money.
>
> Happy Friday!
> jonnyr

There are plenty of articles that say the entire 'Wizard of Oz' was a
social/political commentary for that time: the current presidential
election, state of economy (gold vs. paper), common people
vs. bureacrats, stuff like that.

I don't have time to google it, but I'll bet if you do you'll pull up a 
mass of articles talking about this stuff.

take care,

>         Sex is at the core of life itself. Creation, Will, and the spiritual life all gain their fuel from sexual energy. There is an ancient tradition of esoteric work that seeks to access this source of unlimited potential for the alchemical transformation of the Being.
>
>         This Toltec shamanic teaching has remained hidden for over one thousand years and has been passed only by direct transmission while in altered states of consciousness.
>
>         Koyote will continue this tradition, and pass on this teaching through a live ritual designed to create a psychic state where the Sacred Serpent within
>         you can activate your creativity and spiritual transformation.
>

>

>

>         Koyote has worked with various shamanic and magickal traditions throughout his life, including the Thelemic tradition and the Toltec Indian Tradition of Mexico. He conducts transformative workshops throughout the United States and Latin America where he passes on the knowledge he has received from all these various sources. Koyote also incorporates music, video and theater into his work to achieve a total inmersive experience.
>
>
>
>

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  DIE WARZAU'S LATEST BLOG

--=====================_11869000==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

DIE WARZAU'S LATEST BLOG

(BTW they have a new release out:  "Convenience" on their old record label 
Pulseblack)

Hack Adolf Eichmann

Current mood: Mildly cartoonish.

In 1961, The author Hannah Arendt went to Jerusalem for the New Yorker 
Magazine to report on the trial of Otto Adolf Eichmann, the Nazi war 
criminal. Israeli agents in had captured him about a year earlier in 
Argentina where, if you believe the DC comics historical documents, Adolph 
Hitler's Brain was being transfered into the body of a radioactive 
superhero by the Ultrahumanite to fight the Justice Society. Arendt figured 
out why the Axis supervillians weren't all that interested in Eichmann.

Her initial reaction to Eichmann was "nicht einmal unheimlich"  not 
even sinister. She stated that "The deeds were monstrous, but the doer ... 
was quite ordinary, commonplace, and neither demonic nor monstrous." He 
looked like a regular guy, easy to understand, superficial, mediocre. She 
was amazed that this man could send millions of people to their deaths. 
What she saw in him was not evil or aggression or hate. It was just 
thoughtlessness. It was almost as though he lacked the capacity for 
independent thought. He just did, and did well, his job.

So 45 or so years later, we're still wondering about what Arendt called 
"The Banality of Evil." I'm not going to throw around the Nazi analogy, 
that's not what this is about. It's the first place people go sometimes 
when they want to describe evil. This is really more about How you can make 
evil happen. What is the recipe. For better or worse, that's certainly one 
of them- to make ordinary people act from thoughtlessness, ignoring the 
importance and the impact of what they are doing. Whether it's because it's 
your job, or your tradition or just what everyone else is doing. To not 
think about what we do.

In the papers recently there was a lot of talk about Microsoft helping the 
Chinese government to censor the internet, by creating censorship tools on 
MSN networks public spaces so that words that the Chinese Government 
thought were dangerous could be treated like profanity and removed. 
Internet access in China is controlled and monitored. It became pretty 
clear pretty quickly that this had no real chance of succeeding, however. 
It turns out that words like "freedom" and "democracy" and "human rights", 
even though they are forbidden words (you will get an error message on MSN 
spaces if you attempt to use them in Chinese), they can be used easily like 
this:

1. Use Hushmail (www.hushmail.com), or Mailinator (www.mailinator.com) to 
creat a new temporary email address.
2. Install Tor and Privoxy (http://www.tor.eff.org./) Tor is a 
pseudo-random, encrypted router that sends your surfing through a list of 
severs to your destination, thus keeping your origin private. This will 
prevent you from being found out by through a "dns leak"
3. Go to this URL: http://spaces.msn.com/?mkt=en-us
4. Sign up using your new email. Use as little information as is necessary 
and do not use your real name
5. Enter the settings for your new blog.
Enter a title in field 1, the url you would like in field 2, and in section 
4 check and accept the MSN terms of service.
6. click the button that says Create your space (in english)
7. Click the button on the next page that says "go to your space"
8. View the edit page for your MSN Spaces account settings (in English), 
add the characters &mkt=zh-cn to the end of the URL in the 
browser. This makes the interface turn into the chinese one.
9. You can now enter banned words in chinese.

Microsoft is one of the biggest companies in the world, probably more adept 
at managing these kinds of tools than any company ever and yet, still, free 
speech took only a few days to pop back up again. It's interesting to think 
about what happened. It turns out that it is the originating language that 
determines the filters, so that this switch actually works. How could 
anyone have missed this? It seems absurd to think they would have. It would 
mean that potentially hundreds of people (maybe more) missed something that 
was sitting right in front of their face. It means that people who do this 
for a living made a mistake that any high school webmaster would know 
better not to. How did everyone fuck up?

I don't believe anyone did. Web developers and computer programmers make 
bad Eichmanns. I think that what we saw happen here is a high level 
agreement to restrict the freedoms of a group of people thousands of miles 
away failed because no one could depend on a bunch of computer programmers 
to just shut up and do their fucking job when they knew it was a shitty job 
to do. So yes, here's a hack for chinese speaking people who want to freely 
access the internet, but is it really hacking when the door was left open? 
Is someone really breaking in if you open the door for them because you 
know they belong inside?

How far are we away from the day when a company might say "yes, we would 
make a lot of money if we did (crappy thing) but I don't think we could 
ever get our employees to agree to do (crappy thing)?" At the end of the 
day we have a choice and the computer makes it easy for us to make that 
choice. Should we think like them or like ourselves? Like an Eichmann or a 
Hacker?




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] (BSP) Sun July 3rd :: Deep Impact 

Deep Impact, a NASA Discovery Mission, is the first space mission to 
probe beneath the surface of a comet and reveal the secrets of its 
interior. The hyper-speed impact between space-borne iceberg and 
copper-fortified probe is scheduled for approximately 1:52 a.m. EDT on 
Independence Day (10:52 p.m. PDT on July 3). The potentially spectacular 
collision will be observed by the Deep Impact spacecraft, and ground and 
space-based observatories. 
http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/deepimpact/main/

Subject: [sfraves] Silent lastnigt!!! WOW!

So lastnight was totally special man!!  Oh My Goodness, Hello 2day.. had
the Dopest time @ Il Pirata that I've had in a while in that place!

OK... so like this was trippy, i probably should like totally mention this
1st 'cause it was so interesting.. some drunk guy in the middle of RAW's
set well.. he decided it be fun 2 like bring a while pint of beer/ ale
whatever in the middle of the dancefloor where people are ummm..
dancing... & I bumped in2 him by accident & his beer spilled all over him,
glass broke on the floor, & he really wanted 2 kick my ass & I was like in
shock & there were like some homies standing by like watching him I guess
they would jumped in if he tried somehting... but man!  Hello 2Day.. who
fuckin' drinks pint glasses on the dance floor like that man in like a
boucy fucki'n crowd?  I mean.. I know alota people do that i guess.. but
it's stupid!!  I've seen alota drink spill that way... LAME! SO Boo on
that fuckin' LuSH!!!!

OK.... so the night started out w/ this kinda Silent Crew Mash up...
Kinetik got on the decks 1st, played some nice hard, dubby stuff!!!  Loved
it... pretty much set the mood 4 the whole night of what 2 expect...
Profressor Dan, ooooooh,,, Professor Dan, he used 2 live like here back in
the day, then moved away 2 Denver 2 B w/ his Family yada yada yada, he
comes here periodically 2 spin... Dope... but lastnight was the 1st time I
saw him in like oh my gosh, 3 years almost... fuck man.. so Dope!

So Professor went on & played some OG tracks.. oh gosh man.. Nice!!!  Hard
Scary Jungle.. Loved it!

Oh wait... there was this like LIVE DNB Band that had 2 drum sets & a bass
player.. it was neat... I mean... it was totally interesting!!

Mal went on next & like totally tore it up... he played his usual hard
Jungle set taht I Love... Thank God man... when Mal spins MEllow (for him
that is) it scares me actually... LoL

Then there was a B2B set w/ Professor Dan & again... it was just alota
hard shit, OG tracks from producers he spun & Lexxus, he played like
mmmmm... he brought it a notch down & was just strait Dub... oh.. there
was alota Vocals in alota the tracks DJs spun.. it was Dope!!  Oh my
gosh... like when Kinetik spun Drowning by Ak1200... Loved it!

OK.. RAW's set was Sick... I mean... he went like hard & hmmm...  RAW was
Sick.. he spun some hella hard Jungle, goin' kinda soft & dubby @ times &
busted out alota hip hop throughout his set, & a pinch of Raggae in his
set as well... but man.. it was Dope!! Loved it!

I gotta 2 hang w/ the Cheffesor once again! Loved That Dude!!! IN all
honestly.. he made or like help me figure out a few life decisions I been
contemplating the past few months now, so yeah.. LoL.. I'll save that 4
another post!!!

It was a Good night... what was especially  So Dope was I met this Dude,
Euriah, from LA who was up here 4 school scouting, & we hella kicked it
man... Dope kid!!!  YAY!!!  We were hella kickin' & talkin'... he's gonna
be the next Steven Spielberg!

Dope!




-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> ObY {8O)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] your weekend reports?

This weekend I took a chance on 1015 to hit up the Get Freaky party and
was blown away.  I've never seen a crowd or a vibe like I saw there Friday
night ever, starting with the very very minimal pat down from security. 
(ever meaning at 1015)  I bounced around a lot until the psytrance started
going downstairs and pretty much got stuck there until I left at around 4.
 I wish I could report on who I listened to but I dunno, I gave up on
trying to remember who was spinning in what room and what time at parties
and just dance a lot :)  I just remember I felt underdressed as it seemed
like a definite Burning Man kinda crowd with lots of great costumed
people.

Saturday I.. its a blur :)  I was asleep before midnight though I assume..
I don't know, I have no memories after around 9 pm but from what I'm told
we hit up 5 more bars in what was a day of alcohol excess.  Had a great
time though, tons of live music everywhere, lots of beautiful sunshine and
too many friendly bartenders.

>From what I hear about Stilldream from one of my friends who went, she was
nothing short of extatic about how the party went off.  Made me wish I was
there even though I had a lot of fun still doing other things.

-Rayn

Subject: [sfraves] House Music Site Predicts Kelly Osbourne and Paris Hilton will
  Give Genre a Boost

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed



  Oh joy!!!!  House music is saved by Paris Hilton :'(



House Music Site Predicts Kelly Osbourne and Paris Hilton will Give Genre a 
Boost


FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE

TORONTO, Canada/ June 12, 2005 --

House Music Site http://www.MostMusic.Blogspot.com Predicts that Kelly 
Osbourne and Paris Hilton will Help House Music Go Mainstream.

It's been some time since House Music has been a Mainstream Category with 
Mainstream Radio Airplay. But that could all change in 2005. Already Kelly 
Osbourne has brought some Mainstream star power to the genre with the 
release of her House Music CD "Sleeping in the Nothing" and her #1 Hit "One 
Word".

Not only has Osbourne released a straight ahead Dance/House Music CD, but 
she's also recruited top Songwriter Linda Perry to bring some much needed A 
List talent to the genre. Perry has already worked her magic on CDs by Lisa 
Marie Presley, Pink, and Christina Aguilera to name a few.

And the Media Attention on the House Music genre can only get more heated 
when Entertainment News Magnet Paris Hilton releases her new House/Dance 
Music CD in the Fall. Her Single "Screwed" is already getting action on DJ 
setlists.

If Osbourne and Hilton succeed in turning on younger CD buyers to House 
Music, the genre could yet see another day as a Mainstream Category.

Http://www.MostMusic.BlogSpot.com invites reader feedback. Please post your 
"Comments" on the site or e-mail the webmaster with your feedback and 
suggestions.
House Music Site Predicts Kelly Osbourne and Paris Hilton will Give Genre a 
Boost






Tribenet: 
<http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k>http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

--=====================_14154593==.ALT--

Pronunciation: 't=E4-l&
Function: noun
Etymology: Sanskrit tAla, literally, hand-clapping
: one of the ancient traditional rhythmic patterns of Indian music --=20
compare RAGA

------=_Part_2656_18145070.1119311155782--

rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."

> House Music Site Predicts Kelly Osbourne and Paris Hilton will Give 
> Genre a Boost
>
>
> FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
>
> TORONTO, Canada/ June 12, 2005 --
>
> House Music Site http://www.MostMusic.Blogspot.com Predicts that Kelly 
> Osbourne and Paris Hilton will Help House Music Go Mainstream.
>
> It's been some time since House Music has been a Mainstream Category 
> with Mainstream Radio Airplay. But that could all change in 2005. 
> Already Kelly Osbourne has brought some Mainstream star power to the 
> genre with the release of her House Music CD "Sleeping in the Nothing" 
> and her #1 Hit "One Word".
>
> Not only has Osbourne released a straight ahead Dance/House Music CD, 
> but she's also recruited top Songwriter Linda Perry to bring some much 
> needed A List talent to the genre. Perry has already worked her magic 
> on CDs by Lisa Marie Presley, Pink, and Christina Aguilera to name a 
> few.
>
> And the Media Attention on the House Music genre can only get more 
> heated when Entertainment News Magnet Paris Hilton releases her new 
> House/Dance Music CD in the Fall. Her Single "Screwed" is already 
> getting action on DJ setlists.
>
> If Osbourne and Hilton succeed in turning on younger CD buyers to 
> House Music, the genre could yet see another day as a Mainstream 
> Category.
>
> Http://www.MostMusic.BlogSpot.com invites reader feedback. Please post 
> your "Comments" on the site or e-mail the webmaster with your feedback 
> and suggestions.
> House Music Site Predicts Kelly Osbourne and Paris Hilton will Give 
> Genre a Boost
>

>> House Music Site Predicts Kelly Osbourne and Paris Hilton will Give 
>> Genre a Boost

>> FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
>>
>> TORONTO, Canada/ June 12, 2005 --
>>
>> House Music Site http://www.MostMusic.Blogspot.com Predicts that 
>> Kelly Osbourne and Paris Hilton will Help House Music Go Mainstream.
>>
>> It's been some time since House Music has been a Mainstream Category 
>> with Mainstream Radio Airplay. But that could all change in 2005. 
>> Already Kelly Osbourne has brought some Mainstream star power to the 
>> genre with the release of her House Music CD "Sleeping in the 
>> Nothing" and her #1 Hit "One Word".
>>
>> Not only has Osbourne released a straight ahead Dance/House Music CD, 
>> but she's also recruited top Songwriter Linda Perry to bring some 
>> much needed A List talent to the genre. Perry has already worked her 
>> magic on CDs by Lisa Marie Presley, Pink, and Christina Aguilera to 
>> name a few.
>>
>> And the Media Attention on the House Music genre can only get more 
>> heated when Entertainment News Magnet Paris Hilton releases her new 
>> House/Dance Music CD in the Fall. Her Single "Screwed" is already 
>> getting action on DJ setlists.
>>
>> If Osbourne and Hilton succeed in turning on younger CD buyers to 
>> House Music, the genre could yet see another day as a Mainstream 
>> Category.
>>
>> Http://www.MostMusic.BlogSpot.com invites reader feedback. Please 
>> post your "Comments" on the site or e-mail the webmaster with your 
>> feedback and suggestions.

Subject: [sfraves] Re: your weekend reports?

At 06:25 PM 6/20/2005, you wrote:
>stilldream review?

If hearing Binary Finary 5 times and other ancient played out trance hits 
up to 3 times each in one weekend with mixing if you were lucky floats your 
boat then this certainly was the place to be..

Absolutely no techno on the system except for Disconnect, but he opened the 
weekend at 8pm on Friday before I got there (and anyone else).   The Attack 
People in my opinion from the techno angle dropped the ball (Ian didn't 
show up).  I was at their December performance at the OW and it was much 
better.   This time it was club techno at best and much more close to 
cheese anthems.  Maybe Dustin took a look at the crowd and pimped out the 
rave tunes, but I lost interest rather quickly.. I hate saying this about 
my g-tech homies.. ;)

Ambient Mafia represented nicely..

So yeah... I feel bummed when I heard that in previous years there was a 
bunch of techno and when finally checking it out I had to "painfully" sit 
through hours of trance..  There is a chance I missed something while 
sleeping, but well.. not much of that went on.. :)

Ok ok ok.. So I'm opinionated on the music tip, but I had a great time. The 
place was nice, the weather turned out well, and I made a few new friends 
and got to hang out with old ones I haven't seen in a while, so I can't 
complain.  Overall it was quite the productive weekend, so yeah.. kudos to 
the Stilldream folks..  MORE TECHNO.. It is good...

Mmm.. New techno track here:
http://egr.egregious.net/egrv-02/

Best,
--Mike

Egregious
"Spiritual renewal through music for those outside the heard."
http://www.egregious.net/

Subject: [sfraves] (BSP) Sun July 3rd :: Deep Impact

Deep Impact, a NASA Discovery Mission, is the first space mission to
probe beneath the surface of a comet and reveal the secrets of its
interior. The hyper-speed impact between space-borne iceberg and
copper-fortified probe is scheduled for approximately 1:52 a.m. EDT on
Independence Day (10:52 p.m. PDT on July 3). The potentially spectacular
collision will be observed by the Deep Impact spacecraft, and ground and
space-based observatories.
http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/deepimpact/main/

:: Sunday July 3rd from Noon - 8pm ::
Cannabass is back with another day party on Treasure Island, to bring
you a day of Chicago House, Dirty House, Breaks, Drum & Bass, Ragga,
Breakcore and Latin Downtempo

Andrew Phelan (djandrewphelan.com)

Simas

The park has bbq grills and picnic tables so bring shit to cook up and
drink up, but please be respectful of the space so that we can continue
to use it.

Directions:

Hillcrest Rd becomes Treasure Island Rd
Treasure Island Rd becomes Avenue Palms
Right on California
Left on Avenue H
If you hit houses, you went too far on H
It's on the corner of H and 9th
(We're behind the soccer field)
By Bus: Take the 108 to Avenue H and 9th St

Message-ID: <20050621171342.64186.qmail@web60317.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Tue, 21 Jun 2005 10:13:42 -0700 (PDT)
From: georgeC | origami <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <BAY103-F1731B4F0DE7638A71C83CD85E80@phx.gbl>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Stilldream review - Re: [sfraves] your weekend reports?

> >--- Bam <invibe@gmail.com> wrote:
> >
> > > stilldream review?

My partner-in-crime and I got out of bed WAY late on Saturday, made a
leasurely breakfast, and packed *very* light for a campout- like only 3
or so outfits each, just a couple of Tasty Bites, 6 of Tecate, 5th of
vodka- hell, we were only camping one night.

After a 4.5 hour drive as promised, we found ourselves at the bottom of
a rather hardcore fire trail, littered with rain ruts and big rocks. 
While I would have been excited were I at the top of that hill on a
mountain bike, it was pretty rough coming up that sucker in a FWD
manual-drive Civic!  OK, so I let my girlfriend drive..

Once we made it to the top, we flashed our VIP passes at the door and
made our way to the Ambient Mafia camp, which was stashed far to the
side of the field, in a grove of trees, behind a glowstick-festooned
barbed-wire fence.  It appears they were well bolstered against the
trance onslaught to come.

Immediately I found myself a little faded, a lot relaxed, and hugged by
many.  As the night came on, I found myself oddly drawn to the candy
kids, whose raw enthusiasm, jumping-around antics and taste for sparkly
bracelets made me smile.  I even saw a van with the words "x TRANCE
RAVER x" stuck on the back window.

When in rome, do as the romans do, I say.  At least, I say it when I'm
able to speak, which soon enough I was having trouble doing through my
blissy smile and slitted eyes as I snuggled in a sleeping bag under the
stars on a hammock some very clued-in sort had brought (find me at C&S
this year rocking one, you will!  Hmmm!).

Cubik and I played the best set we've ever played that night.  It was
pure unabashed, totally technically smooth, creative fun.  The rest of
the Mafia's music was wonderful too- I remember great sets from
Boomerang Fidget, Daps, Hickory, and Red Stickman.  There were other
great sets too, I just don't remember them.

Oh yeah!  Michael Liu kicked mad ass and The Attack People did a really
quite good techy-housey-psyish live PA.

The next morning I was very surprised to see that the trancey kids had
all gotten up long before me (or stayed up all night?), struck camp,
even cleaned up pretty respectably, and left.  We got our shit
together,   hugged a gang of people, and left.

Overall, it was far more fun than I thought it was going to be.  Trying
to sleep with 130dbs of trancey pumpy bass thrumming through your
pillow = not so good.  However, what exactly was I trying to sleep at a
trance campout for anyhow?  My girl stayed up all night running around
with her girlfriends, bless her heart.

Campout # 123510 down, only 423491 to go this summer!  *falls over*

Trance,
-george c | origami
-newstylesound.com
-djorigami.com
-foldedsf.com

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] more Jackal & Hyde - DNA Lounge this Sunday - $5

i know, i keep BSPing this party, but it's only because i'm EXTREMELY
excited that Jackal & Hyde are coming through SF with a live PA.  i've
been a huge fan of their work for years!

for a sample of what to expect:

Jackal & Hyde - Darkstar
http://mp3.juno.co.uk/MP3/SF174483-01-01-01.mp3

Jackal & Hyde - Give it all you got 2000 (remix/remake of old
Afrorican b-boy jam)
http://mp3.juno.co.uk/MP3/SF67099-01-01-02.mp3

For more audio samples of their newer material, check their Myspace page:
http://www.myspace.com/jackalandhyde

AND to top things off, they'll be brining their own visuals with stuff
like this:
http://www.hallucination.com/_subsites/jackalandhyde.com/art.html

this is $5 people and the show will most definitely be worth going to
work tired and hungover on Monday.

-------
Evil Breaks & StrategiK present:
Jackal and Hyde Live
Sunday June 26th, 2005
@ DNA Lounge (375 11th st)

the first 100 people get in 2 for 1, and the door is an amazingly low
price of only $5.
$2 off all drinks till 11pm, thanx to DNA.

Jackal and Hyde - Live (Hallucination/Scheme Addict Records) West Palm Beac=
h, FL
-special visuals provided

Jackal & Hyde have been called "the purveyors of the hardcore-electro
sound" (electro-core), a combination of industrial laden electro
beats, and psychotic keys. Jackal & Hyde was formed in 1998 by
partners Scott Weiser, and Todd Walker in an effort to combine a
harder edge sound with the dancefloor sensibility of Electro or
"Techno-Bass". Besides their original work, Jackal & Hyde's sound has
been requested for multiple remix productions including Kid Rock, Love
& Rockets, and Biochip C. Scott Weiser, who is most recognized for his
work in I.B.M. (Industrial Bass Machine), and the duo Dynamix II, who
have written such dancefloor classics as "Give The DJ A Break" and
"Feel The Bass", has been writing and producing dance music for over a
decade. Scott's influences range anywhere from classic Industrial to
Classical, while partner Todd Walker's influences come from Miami
Ghetto Bass and Industrial Dance. As Jackal & Hyde, Scott and Todd
push the boundaries of dance music and set the standards for the new
school of electro.

J-Break (Cyberian Knights/Afterdark Records) Tampa, FL

J-Break has been rocking the decks all across North America and
Europe, playing his signature style of breaks and electro. After his
debut mix cd, "Bio:Mechanik" on Subculture Records, Jackal & J-Break
founded the electro label, Cyberian Knights Recordings, to release
"This is the Sound of Underground," as heard on the Baby Anne "Mixed
Live: Las Vegas" mixed compilation on Moonshine. J-Break has done
numerous studio collaborations with international renown artists
Infiniti, Fixx, Johnny Cage, and Josef Plante, to name a few. Be on
the lookout for J-Break this fall as he hits the road for his
"Barcelona, Spain" CD Release Tour.

Along with local Breakbeat superstars:

Tung (Brass Tax/Subalicious)

Aaron Jae vs. Bam vs. M.O.D. (Evil Breaks/SFBreaks.org)
-Special 3 by 4 old school funky set

Influence vs. Jay Vigor (Beatsfactory.com/Strategik/London Breakz)
-2 by 4

Capt'n Kirk (Space Cowboys)

Jackal and Hyde will also be bringing their own visual specialist all
the way from Florida to help put on one of the most memorable
performances you will EVER witness. And on top of the already super
ridiculously cheap price of this amazing show, Evil Breaks will be
giving away tons of free tickets to members of its mailing list, so if
you're not a member, sign up now.

Jackal and Hyde Live
Sunday June 26th, 2005
@ DNA Lounge (375 11th st)
first 100 2 for 1
$2 off all drinks till 11
$5 entry=20
--=20
--------------------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.evilbreaks.com

June 24th:  Subscience 2 Year
June 25th:  Moksha Tribe Day Party
June 26th:  Jackal & Hyde @ DNA Lounge
July 3rd:  Deep Impact @ Treasure Island
July 3rd:  1015 w/ Boy George
July 15th:  Last Call @ Modifortress
July 16th:  Clandestine
July 22nd:  Evil Breaks TBA

From: georgeC | origami <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
To: SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Last minute vintage Origami live set @ the Attic in SF tonight!

A long time ago (2003) in a galaxy far, far away (the OweDub,
oaktizzle), I played a set at a great halloween party called Spectre. 
I worked my little brain to the bone for about a week straight writing
and setting up an entirely new, unique live pa set for the party, that
veered from instrumental hip hop (a new thing for me at the time) to
stoner breaks, electro, and everything in between.  I played my ass
off.  A lot of people who knew me as a house guy were rather flummoxxed
and got the f*** down.

Tonight, I've been extended a gracious offer to play with this crazy
set of music again, this time at The Attic, a rather charming little
dive bar in San Francisco.  The night is Daps and Cubik's downtempo
night, happens many Tuesdays at this spot, always a lot of fun.

I don't know when my set is exactly but I do know that I'll be playing
this music and hopefully setting a few hipsters on fire with my melted,
corroded 808s and free-jazz rhodes piano loops.  Come out, this music
probably will never be heard again.  I may screw up royally- it's been
years since I wrangled with this messy plate of nutty sound and blunted
atmospheres- you have my permission to laugh, cry, dance, have a
religious experience if you will.

Heck, concieve a baby in the bathroom to it if the mood strikes you.

Also playing are the on-point and sexxxxtastic duo of Daps and Cubik,
on the ones and twos.

The Attic
3336 24th St, between Mission and Valencia
10p-2a
Free!

Love and sonic massage,
-george C | origami
-newstylesound.com
-djorigami.com
-foldedsf.com

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

MOKSHA TRIBE PRESENTS GROOVE IN THE GROVE JUNE 25TH

With spring comes rebirth, and the Moksha Tribe Collective is returning 
this summer with infectious beats and happy vibes.

Our DIY ethic and not for profit focus will continue to be in full effect!!!

The fun recommences with "Groove in the Grove," a sunny, free day party 
scheduled for Saturday, June 25th, from noon to sunset.

Your groovers for the day:

Cubik and Origami
Marcine
DV8
Sheztek VS BAM (Evilbreaks)
Faye Valentine VS DJ Dilema aka DFD
Hypnotoad

    * Beautiful Virgin Day Party Location in Sunnyvale, just 45 minutes 
from SF:
http://baytrail.abag.ca.gov/vtour/map3/access/Syvlblds/syvlblds3.htm
    * Bring your own drinks
    * Respect the location and pick up your trash
    * No Pets Allowed
    * $5 entry fee.  This fee is imposed by the park authorities.
    * There is ample parking outside of the park if you wish to avoid the 
entry fee but we encourage guests to pay the $5 to show appreciation for 
use of the facility.
    * We will be taking donations.  Reminder:  Moksha Tribe is Not for Profit.
    * Donations are strictly to cover costs incurred for throwing party; as 
usual monies after expenses will go to Larkin Street Youth Services:
www.larkinstreetyouth.org

Call the Moksha Tribe announce line the day of for complete directions:

415-564-4768
Web Enabled Cell Phones:  moksha.mp


Or add your email addy to our in-house list for directions and update on 
all Moksha events:

1. visit

<http://groups.yahoo.com/group/mokshatribeannounce/join>groups.yahoo.com/group/mokshatribeannounce/join

-OR-

2. Send email to mokshatribeannounce-subscribe@yahoogroups.com




And when you're finished dancing in the sun with Moksha be sure to attend 
the official "Groove in the Grove" after party:

Fling! And RADI8R proudly present

BETA

The launch party for RADI8R RADIO.

Don't miss the Breaks/house/techno/dnb/progressive/ambient/electro 
extravaganza provided by our friends:

Chel-C Faith
Drop
Emergent
Ganucheau
Mark Martini
Mediaboy
Unagi
VTG

8pm-late night
Free before 10:30, $5 after
142 Taylor between Eddy & Turk
<http://www.radi8r.com/>www.radi8r.com


Looking forward to seeing all of you on the dance floor. Been awhile.

Much love,

Apollo for Moksha Tribe
Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org






Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Ah...it's gltb (I'm so confused) weekend cuming upon us again.  Or, as I 
say "Miller Time."  So I thought I'd throw some tubesteak into the 
mix.  What's old is new again...fresh.  Dj Bus Station :-)   Queer 
Pride.  Slutty, sleazy pre-AIDS vibe.


Gay heritage night
DJ Bus Station John's bathhouse-disco revival at the Tubesteak Connection 
takes aim at the gay culture cul-de-sac.


By Marke B.

WE QUEERS ARE always looking ahead. We eagerly latch onto newfangled gizmos 
like the Internet, digital film, fauxhawk haircuts, bias-cut jeans, and 
home-remixers in an effort to express our sexuality while advancing our 
politics. And for all the lip service about "honoring our past," we have a 
tendency to selectively edit out the more "unseemly" parts of it. Give us 
Phyl and Del for the front pages  but please keep the Crisco and poppers 
to yourself.

Our future, however, seems to be a mess. In one year's time, we've gone 
from holding worldwide pep rallies celebrating a fulfilled destiny of 
legalized sodomy and same-sex marriage to fighting a media barrage that's 
laid bare our apparent addictions to crystal meth, unsafe sex, and online 
hookups. In response, it seems that much of gay club culture is attempting 
to "sanitize" any overt queer sexual expression by burying it beneath a 
storm of heterosexual video imagery coupled with the same old remixes of Cher.

So what are we to make of the sudden emergence of a wildly popular DJ and 
promoter whose photocopied flyers feature a dancing, Baby Jane'd Bette 
Davis superimposed on a grainy Super-8 double-dicking? Whose sets mix 
early-'80s downtown NYC no-wave and disco obscurities with the synthetic 
Hi-NRG sounds of San Francisco's fabled cha-cha palace the Trocadero 
Transfer? Who worships at the keys of pre-Fairlight synthesizers but 
refuses to log on to the World Wide Web?

One smart sissy star, that's what. And his name is Bus Station John.

Harnessing the current electroclash vogue to channel gay historical 
dissonance into a dance-floor confrontation with the whole of our past, DJ 
Bus Station John pulls no punches with his disco politics. Aiming to 
re-create the slutty, sleazy, pre-AIDS bathhouse era with his music, his 
visuals, and his vibe at regular club nights the Tubesteak Connection (at 
Aunt Charlie's) and the Rod (Underground SF), he reanimates a lost, 
necessary part of our culture too often buried in shame and desperate 
yearning. Bus Station John dares to fete the heyday of truck-stop, 
bathhouse, and tearoom encounters, honoring it as the often fun-filled 
grassroots resistance movement it was, the only form of communal validation 
then available for many gay men.

But for those of us whose musical cerebellum often overshadows our 
pier-sized libidos, Bus Station John also reprazents. His mystical 
crate-digging layers homocore fetishism for the marginal over a roots 
ideal, with a generous nod to the same underground analog railroad that 
techno gods Derrick May and Carl Craig and early-Eurodisco enthusiasts 
Dimitri from Paris and Gilles Peterson have ridden to DJ superstardom. (Bus 
Station John would cringe at these contemporary comparisons, but, rather 
charmingly, his rage-filled lumping of all recent dance music permutations 
into a single "house music all night wrong" category is what fuels his 
creative lust for anachronistic vengeance.)

After years of suffering through that Great Erasure of queer dance quirks 
known as circuit music, we finally have a vinyl archaeologist of our own, 
one who nails the spirit of DIY activism in his stacks yet keeps the floors 
packed. The great gay ghost of Larry Levan may be double-parked in Paradise 
Garage, but down here in the queer underground, Bus Station John's still 
taking the free-love message to the streets. Revenge of the clones, meet 
the return of the queen.

Bay Guardian: You seem to be in direct rebellion against a gay community of 
methed-up, apathetic circuit queens on steroids looking for the latest 
anonymous Internet encounter. Is that safe to say?

Bus Station John: I don't see what I do as conscious rebellion, just my 
natural reaction to the steady decline of gay culture and nightlife over 
the last 20 years. I'm old enough, at 44, to have tasted the end of the 
golden age, the pre-AIDS era that I celebrate in the music I play  
specifically the late '70s and early '80s, when some fantastic dance music 
was being produced. While Stonewall had definitely flung open the closet 
door, there was still that exciting sense of being a sexual outlaw, moving 
on a special plane apart from the mainstream.

Now we've gone from being a unique underground subculture to a marketing 
niche. Just check out how the archetypal gay male has changed over the last 
couple of decades. First we had the Castro Clone: the mustachioed, 
Levi-clad, free-loving, crotch-popping, hanky- and keyring-sporting icon of 
the old school. He was a stylistic expression of sexual freedom and 
identity. His current replacement? An overly preened and pumped label whore 
working the latest pinhead haircut smeared with "product," and undermining 
all those hours at the gym with a pair of hideous insect eyebrows better 
suited to Marlene Dietrich. Hmmm ... maybe I am rebelling after all!

BG: That certainly seems to be the gay man's current media image, but how 
does it relate to gay bar culture, which can be viewed historically as a 
reaction against the outside world?

BSJ: A visit to a gay bar today is less the sexual cruising odyssey of 
yesteryear than a visit to a well-lit aviary full of retail-bred magpies 
and their chirpy gal pals from the office. All eyes are fixed on 
relentlessly heterosexual video images of hoochies grinding their 
collective jugs and cameltoes into the camera lens, their meager talents 
propped up by an army of dancers as they frantically feign "havin' a 
par-tay." Why are we watching this in a gay bar, anyway? Suppose we pull 
the plug and look at each other. Now that would be revolutionary.

BG: Is that what inspired you to do your own thing?

BSJ: When you know how much better things have been, I think it's hard not 
to imagine how much better they can be. That's why I finally decided to 
create my own scene. I was tired of having no place to go after the 
dot-commoners and greedy landlords blanded out San Francisco  and even 
more tired of complaining about it.

My nights are audiovisual tributes to the old-school gay demimonde, when 
our culture was at its creative, aesthetic, and sexual peak. There was a 
short but amazing window of time when incredibly imaginative, engaging, and 
sometimes crazy electronic music was coming out of New York, San Francisco, 
Europe, and even Montreal, made principally by and for gay men.

These songs were the result of many hours of sweat over primitive, often 
homemade, synthesizers without the use of computer software or samplers. 
They transcended the disco clichs of the day by featuring one-of-a-kind 
hooks and arrangements, often paired with delightfully idiosyncratic 
vocals. As a DJ, my mission has been to rescue these gems from oblivion and 
re-create the special vibe of the gay bars, discotheques, and bathhouses of 
the day.

BG: So you're basically using electronic music not as a path to the 
unknown, technological future, but as a window onto a utopian, mostly 
forgotten fleshpot past. That's all well and good within the confines of 
your parties, but how can that translate to a wider shift within the 
community itself? In other words, how do you think your clubs can change 
the gay world?

BSJ: I'm not so sure about changing the world, but I think the parties I've 
created have definitely filled a void in SF's nightlife. The Tubesteak 
Connection in particular attracts fags, dykes, and trannies who are 
typically broke, creative, urban savvy, scruffy chic, and looking for love, 
sex, and kindred spirits. They're over the mediocrity of the status quo, 
they've been starving for something different for a long time, and I love 
turning them on to this great music they might not have otherwise known 
existed. It's part of their gay heritage.

I also want to get the word out to "men of a certain age" that you don't 
have to be young and hip to enjoy what I do  though it does get pretty loud!

In a sense I think I'm providing a musical bridge between two distinct 
queer generations, an emotionally important connection that was decimated 
both by AIDS and the lust to harness our "demographic" 's spending power to 
the popular market. By restoring this connection, I'm hoping to inform and 
empower us to make our sexuality our own again. I hope for a world where 
freaks can be freaks  and can proudly walk the streets of San Francisco 
again without feeling any pressure to fit into the latest fashionable 
"scene" shoved down our throats by whatever liquor or "lifestyle" ads are 
currently barraging our community.

BG: About AIDS: You must know that by bringing to the fore the bathhouse 
era, you're forcing a new generation to contemplate a segment of the gay 
past they may view as "dirty," in the sense that many young gay men 
erroneously see that particular historical period as the "cause" of AIDS. 
What's your take on some of the controversy you've stirred up because you 
champion the men and the music of that time?

BSJ: About 95 percent of what I spin is on used vinyl. Sometimes I look at 
my records and wonder about their previous owners. Many were gay men  DJs 
and disco-lovers whose music ended up in thrift stores and bargain bins, 
their collections broken up and scattered like ashes to the wind. Sometimes 
I find names stamped or handwritten on the labels. I think of these men and 
try to honor them. I believe part of them is resurrected every time I play 
their songs.

You know, those men who are no longer with us, the first to succumb to the 
epidemic  they didn't know what they were dealing with. We on the other 
side of the first wave of AIDS know better. Caring for yourself and your 
gay brothers enough to get rubbers and use them  that's hot. Rocket 
science it is not.

BG: Are you finding that people are glomming on to the message in the music 
of your clubs?

BSJ: Well, initially I envisioned my first club, the Tubesteak Connection, 
as a sleazy venue for alternaqueer men to cruise and pick each other up at 
 which of course it still is. But the comment I hear most from newcomers 
is "I had so much fun" or "I love your music," which is incredibly 
gratifying and lovely, so I adjusted my vision a bit to up the inclusivity 
factor. Now we're an internationally known nightspot for queers of all 
genders who get it. And I think they really are getting it.

My favorite evenings happen when every sort of San Franciscan is 
represented, from the electroclash kid to the disco granny, the trannyfag 
to the aging drag, the milquetoast accountant to the incognito TV 
personality. And I love that drugs aren't a big part of my parties. People 
get high enough on the music, the vibe, each other. When everyone's dancing 
enthusiastically to anachronistic rarities from a gay past they're 
rediscovering together, that's the icing on the cake.

Straight people aren't unwelcome, provided they have a clue. But if they're 
just out slumming 'cause they heard it was the trendy thing and they're 
looking to be entertained by the latest queer minstrel show, this isn't the 
place for them. The same goes for Queer as Folk Castro queens with their 
cell phones glued to their ears. I'd rather retire the club than see it 
co-opted into "the Bar on Turk Street."

BG: What do you do about the people who come but just don't "get it"?

BSJ: Oh, believe me, I have a stash of secret weapon music I can whip out 
that will ensure they flee back to from whence they came.

Marke B. is a big fag. He writes the biweekly Super Ego clubs column for 
the Bay Guardian and sleeps around a lot. Flame him at 
<mailto:superego@sfbg.com>superego@sfbg.com.


Where to find Bus Station John

Frisco Disco vs. the Tubesteak Connection Sat/25, 10 p.m.-2 a.m., Arrow 
Bar, 10 Sixth St., SF. $5. (415) 255-7920.

Lips Stick Sun/26, noon-8 p.m., Soluna Cafe and Lounge, 272 McAllister, SF. 
$5. (415) 621-2200.

Mikes on Bikes (bicycle Pride Parade contingent) Sun/26, parade kickoff 
10:30 a.m., Market Street, SF. (415) 905-8854 (24-hour info and 
preregistration hotline).

The Rod Second Saturdays, 10 p.m.-2 a.m., Underground SF, 424 Haight, SF. 
$5. (415) 864-7386.

The Tubesteak Connection Thursdays, 10 p.m.-2 a.m., Aunt Charlie's Lounge, 
133 Turk, SF. $4. (415) 441-2922.

The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: Re: [sfraves] question du jour: your worst party bust

Actually happened about a month ago now.

Was at a desert party, and the cops showed up around 2 in the morning.
They shut down the party, and were actually gonna let the party keep
going around 3am.. until...

They busted a dealer, who was underage, and was drunk...

Party got shut down, they started braching everyone. I was with my
girlfriend, who had drove, and neither of us were in any sort of
condition to drive. Luckily I knew a lot of people who were working
crew, and was able to kick it and just help tear down until I was able
to drive.

Finally got outta there around 5:30 in the morning. It was actually a
really good time hanging out, but still sucked major balls.

list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 57564 invoked from network); 22 Jun 2005 20:49:55 -0000
Date: Wed, 22 Jun 2005 13:49:46 -0700 (PDT)
From: Terry Estioko <terry@saturn5.com>
X-X-Sender: terry@atari
To: Deepfog <sfgroove@deepfog.com>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <37262.205.56.210.196.1119467538.squirrel@deepfog.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.62.0506221311001.22709@atari>
References: <37262.205.56.210.196.1119467538.squirrel@deepfog.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] question du jour:  your worst party bust

On Wed, 22 Jun 2005, Deepfog wrote:

> i suspect a lot of people will have a lot to say about this and i hope you
> all speak up.  and i've got a few questions in the wings related to this
> so ... here goes.
>
> what's your worst party bust experience?  and i know we've all been
> through a lot of them!

Hrm...I was just discussing this with my gf recently, the 'worst' (most 
dramatic, at least) would be the original Harmony 5 year aniversary on 
that ranch north of vacaville. This was mm...about '96.

So much production thrown into that party, big multiple stages, 
international talent (techno-swedes, bayer-mull-lekenbush, et al.) A few 
thousand kids in through the gate. Oops, sound complaint and cars start 
piling up, extending out to the frontage road where it becomes quite 
visible from the freeway.

At about 1am an entire fleet of squad cars bust out onto the property, 
and surround the party full lights on, in formation, like star wars 
x-wing fighters n' shit ('gold leader standing by'). Officers on foot 
sweep the party, I have no idea how many people were arrested, it was 
pretty nuts. Promoters evacuate en haste, I quarratine myself to the 
security tent (I knew them) and waited it out so I could take gear down 
and get the hell out of there. It wasn't so terribly bad as it was 
dramatic. OOHHHaahhhh!

There have also been a number of COTS (Children of the Sun) busts that 
have been...um..er, interesting. I know several people that got 
arrested from them. COTS took getting busted as an artform ;-) I have some 
really funny stories from Isaac, I'm not sure if I'm allowed to say them 
publicly, tho.

And my scariest...would be a Balance UG, '97 I think, off some alley in 
SOMA. It was scary because at about 1am a paddywagon shows up and they 
start loading it up w/ gear/people. I freak the fuck out because I have 
my visuals gear there, and now my shit's getting impounded and I'm going 
to jail. The cops impounded the decks, sound, everything they could find as 
'evidence'. So I manage to unplug all my shit in the chaos and hide it in 
a row of washer/dryers in the back of the warehouse. Then I manage to slip 
out w/o getting arrested, and come back a couple hours later to get my 
shit.

Ahhh, the memories =)

-terry



---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

i'm kind of jazzed about this because this guy is one
of my partner's favorite producers of modern electro,
and  he's coming to SF this week so i'm passing this
along.

Silicon Scally- aka Carl Finlow- Warp, Soma, 20/20
vision, Satamile.. on Thursday, June 23 at Rx Carl
Finlow will be performing a  live set for his USA mini
tour. Dark noir Electro Breaks from one of the 
leading producers in this scene, coming all the way
from Paris . This show will  also
be in support of his recent release "Dark Matter" on
Satamile records. 
Go to www.satamile.com for samples. DJ sets by Dj
Ripple, Sara Walker,  Satamile
and more. .. 


Go find a flyer on haight street and this is a 5$
without it is a 7$, i think.

From sfraves-return-122143-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Jun 22 22:45:49 2005
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-122143-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 6667 invoked by uid 1103); 22 Jun 2005 22:45:47 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm

Received: (qmail 6648 invoked from network); 22 Jun 2005 22:45:47 -0000
From: gregvp@comcast.net
To: "Deepfog" <sfgroove@deepfog.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
Date: Wed, 22 Jun 2005 22:29:57 +0000
Message-Id: <062220052229.12060.42B9E6650007F65100002F1C22058864429F90090A9D09@comcast.net>
X-Mailer: AT&T Message Center Version 1 (Dec 17 2004)
X-Authenticated-Sender: Z3JlZ3ZwQGNvbWNhc3QubmV0
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="NextPart_Webmail_9m3u9jl4l_12060_1119479397_0"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] question du jour:  your worst party bust

--NextPart_Webmail_9m3u9jl4l_12060_1119479397_0
Content-Type: text/plain
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

It was a Moksha tribe party in a residential neighborhood in San Francisco. Can't remember the name of the party, but it was one of the early ones (second Moksha Tribe party, I think). They had great blacklight artwork (from Joey) premiering at this party. It was such a good vibe until the bust. Since then of course they have learned where to have these parties although you never know for sure.

Anyway, the coppers showed up because a neighbor made a noise complaint. So, they turned down the music to comply but apparently it wasn't enough so the cops came back again later.

Apollo was at the front door along with Joey, I think, and Apollo was such a professional at handling these cops. Kept them outside the party, at the door, which was a good thing. What a smooth talker! Inside, the crew was trying to keep everyone calm and silent and law-abiding. 

I had my roommate with me, and it was his first rave, so he was freaking out. He wanted to leave immediately. But one of the crew kept him inside, all she had to do was say, "How do you think it would look if people tried going outside right now? You think they would let you leave freely without a search?" And she calmed him down with that thought. Cause yes, it would be suspicious if people started heading for the very door where the cops are standing! 

When all was clear, we left the party for home, but according to a later review (by Osby, I think) the event turned into a kind of chill, ambient mixture (a quiet rave) where people spent the night talking and enjoying themselves in spite of the bust!

Anyway, that was my only major bust experience. The only other time that cops came to a party (another Moksha UG in Oakland), I hardly noticed because I was getting down in a separate room from the main floor and apparently the music didn't get turned down enough for me to notice!

Greg

Anyone here at that 1995 party thrown by Terrance Alan? Where SFPD
invaded in full riot gear? Where they arrested dozens of people and
busted several heads to boot? That's the worst I ever heard of.  It
eventually resulted in the formation of the San Francisco Entertainment
Committe. And guess who's president of the committee...

Sean

References: <062220052229.12060.42B9E6650007F65100002F1C22058864429F90090A9D09@comcast.net>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] question du jour: your worst party bust

i don't really have any good bust stories.   though two come to mind.

one, an urban wasteland party under a freeway overpass next to the
traintracks in oakland.  i know many on this list were there.  i just
remember the crew telling us not to go back the way we came because
cops were there waiting on the other side.  so instead, we had to walk
down the tracks, then cut across and around.  basically going around
the cops.  never did see one.

two, was at a party called...more hands and feet.  i think that was
it.  either cosmic beats or cRave threw the party and it was at their
venue over by 550 barnaveld.  cops show up and tell everyone to leave.
 but everyone had been shuttled there from a parking area back over by
550.  so there we were....about 200 or so candy ravers walking on the
sidewalk, under the freeway, past 500 barnaveld, over to our cars.=20
was kinda fun, actually!

oh wait, one more story!  the last Area 51 when it was split into two
parties.  i was at the party at the Sweets Ballroom in Oakland.  DJ
irene was on and the music shuts down.  it was about 11pm or so.  we
are informed that the party is over, but they are going to let Meat
Beat Manifesto play and then everyone has to go.  Meat Beat tore it up
and i loved it.  then i ended up at the renegade afterparty in
Milpitas.

but the best thing about that night was while the music was off and
the future of the party was in question, i bumped into Madame Mercury.
 and we got to talking and i asked her how she got started DJing.  and
it was that conversation with her that made me decide to try my hand
at DJing.  i bought my tables and mixer the next month when i got a
bonus from work.  if the cops hadn't come and they hadn't turned the
music off, i wouldn't have had that conversation with her.  and i most
likely wouldn't have bought my decks.  and i wouldn't be playing
records today.

so thank god for the cops busting the party.  ;)

On 6/22/05, gregvp@comcast.net <gregvp@comcast.net> wrote:

ince then of course they have learned where to have these parties although =
