At 03:29 PM 6/22/2005, gregvp@comcast.net wrote:
>It was a Moksha tribe party in a residential neighborhood in San 
>Francisco. Can't remember the name of the party, but it was one of the 
>early ones (second Moksha Tribe party, I think). They had great blacklight 
>artwork (from Joey) premiering at this party. It was such a good vibe 
>until the bust. Since then of course they have learned where to have these 
>parties although you never know for sure.
>
>Anyway, the coppers showed up because a neighbor made a noise complaint. 
>So, they turned down the music to comply but apparently it wasn't enough 
>so the cops came back again later.
>
>Apollo was at the front door along with Joey, I think, and Apollo was such 
>a professional at handling these cops. Kept them outside the party, at the 
>door, which was a good thing. What a smooth talker! Inside, the crew was 
>trying to keep everyone calm and silent and law-abiding.

Yes Greg.  I remember the night vividly :-)  The party was Deviance.  The 
cops came back at least four times I remember, and the last was headed by a 
captain who was about to seize the equipment and arrest the DJs. Figured it 
was time to rearrange things then..



>I had my roommate with me, and it was his first rave, so he was freaking 
>out. He wanted to leave immediately. But one of the crew kept him inside, 
>all she had to do was say, "How do you think it would look if people tried 
>going outside right now? You think they would let you leave freely without 
>a search?" And she calmed him down with that thought. Cause yes, it would 
>be suspicious if people started heading for the very door where the cops 
>are standing!
>
>When all was clear, we left the party for home, but according to a later 
>review (by Osby, I think) the event turned into a kind of chill, ambient 
>mixture (a quiet rave) where people spent the night talking and enjoying 
>themselves in spite of the bust!

The party went on until 6 or so.  It was a big chill event and rather 
nice.  I was upset because the police came just as things were going 
off;  but it was cool to have a chance to talk with peeps.  I don't believe 
in shutting down a party unless the police throw you out.  Too many high 
kids are placed in harms way, so I look for some reasonable accommodation.


>Anyway, that was my only major bust experience. The only other time that 
>cops came to a party (another Moksha UG in Oakland), I hardly noticed 
>because I was getting down in a separate room from the main floor and 
>apparently the music didn't get turned down enough for me to notice!

These Oakland cops were really little Fascists (they were actually 
small).  We waited until they went and then started the party up 
again.  Went till dawn :-)  This was, however, a personal nightmare for me 
because at the same time the cops were there a guest had some bad reaction 
to an overdose of cough meds and it looked like the worst might 
happen.  The EMT took a look and said he was in no danger and Danny very 
kindly took him to the bathroom to throw up.


Love,

Apollo

<http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k>http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k

ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become

Subject: [sfraves] (NRR) File-Swapping May Be Here to Stay

http://abcnews.go.com/Technology/wireStory?id=872800


Copyright-Friendly File-Swapping May Be Here to Stay
Regardless of Pending Supreme Court Ruling

By ALEX VEIGA 
The Associated Press

LOS ANGELES Jun 22, 2005  Four years after it
shuttered the original Napster with a legal assault,
the recording industry is taking a different approach
to online file-swapping: If you can't beat 'em, join
'em. 

Recording companies have begun taking steps to
legitimize the peer-to-peer technology that lets
computer users share songs, video and other files with
one another online. 

However the U.S. Supreme Court rules in a
file-swapping decision expected as early as Thursday,
the technology appears irrepressible.

In the last few months, major record labels have
signed licensing deals with companies working to field
file-swapping services that would block unauthorized
files from being traded online. 

"There's only two options here," said Michael Goodman,
an analyst at The Yankee Group market research firm.
"You either license it and you find a way to license
it and monetize it or you don't license it and it gets
traded anyway." 

Some 330 million tracks were purchased online last
year from online stores such as Apple Computer Inc.'s
iTunes. But around 5 billion were downloaded from free
file-sharing networks, he said. 

Meanwhile, recording companies have sued 11,700
computer users for file-swapping. Of those, 2,500
cases have been settled, typically for about $3,000
each. 

The Supreme Court is considering whether companies
behind unrestricted file-sharing services Grokster and
Morpheus should be liable for copyright infringement.
The case's outcome could speed the way for licensed
peer-to-peer services. 

Even so, it remains to be seen whether those
industry-endorsed alternatives can attract people who
now tap open file-swapping networks using such
programs as eDonkey, BitTorrent and Kazaa. 

"When it comes down to it, why is somebody going to
pay for something they can get for free?" said Mac
Padilla, 21, a student who lives in Los Angeles. 

The industry may know the answer at least in part as
early as next month, when Peer Impact, one of the
licensed file-swapping services, is slated to launch. 

(cont.)

http://abcnews.go.com/Technology/wireStory?id=872800

love & light~

Heidi

Subject: RE: [sfraves] question du jour:  your worst party bust

Anyone remember the Full Moon event at the water temple on Edgewood road
[circa 93ish] that was busted by CHP in riot gear while Garth was playing
that dope Original Rockers track [the name is escaping my rotting brain]??
That was cool!  Well..not the bust, but the song has a sample that sounds a
lot like "cops..cops..cop-cop-cops...look over there".  Soooo coincidental
that the cops came over the hill/ridge at that moment.  Still one of my fav
songs EVER!  Still gives me chills when I pull it out and play it for shits
n' giggles..

=)

chris
 

-----Original Message-----
From: Apollo [mailto:apollo@speakeasy.org] 
Sent: Wednesday, June 22, 2005 4:10 PM
To: gregvp@comcast.net; Deepfog; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] question du jour: your worst party bust

At 03:29 PM 6/22/2005, gregvp@comcast.net wrote:
>It was a Moksha tribe party in a residential neighborhood in San 
>Francisco. Can't remember the name of the party, but it was one of the 
>early ones (second Moksha Tribe party, I think). They had great blacklight 
>artwork (from Joey) premiering at this party. It was such a good vibe 
>until the bust. Since then of course they have learned where to have these 
>parties although you never know for sure.
>
>Anyway, the coppers showed up because a neighbor made a noise complaint. 
>So, they turned down the music to comply but apparently it wasn't enough 
>so the cops came back again later.
>
>Apollo was at the front door along with Joey, I think, and Apollo was such 
>a professional at handling these cops. Kept them outside the party, at the 
>door, which was a good thing. What a smooth talker! Inside, the crew was 
>trying to keep everyone calm and silent and law-abiding.

Yes Greg.  I remember the night vividly :-)  The party was Deviance.  The 
cops came back at least four times I remember, and the last was headed by a 
captain who was about to seize the equipment and arrest the DJs. Figured it 
was time to rearrange things then..



>I had my roommate with me, and it was his first rave, so he was freaking 
>out. He wanted to leave immediately. But one of the crew kept him inside, 
>all she had to do was say, "How do you think it would look if people tried 
>going outside right now? You think they would let you leave freely without 
>a search?" And she calmed him down with that thought. Cause yes, it would 
>be suspicious if people started heading for the very door where the cops 
>are standing!
>
>When all was clear, we left the party for home, but according to a later 
>review (by Osby, I think) the event turned into a kind of chill, ambient 
>mixture (a quiet rave) where people spent the night talking and enjoying 
>themselves in spite of the bust!

The party went on until 6 or so.  It was a big chill event and rather 
nice.  I was upset because the police came just as things were going 
off;  but it was cool to have a chance to talk with peeps.  I don't believe 
in shutting down a party unless the police throw you out.  Too many high 
kids are placed in harms way, so I look for some reasonable accommodation.


>Anyway, that was my only major bust experience. The only other time that 
>cops came to a party (another Moksha UG in Oakland), I hardly noticed 
>because I was getting down in a separate room from the main floor and 
>apparently the music didn't get turned down enough for me to notice!

These Oakland cops were really little Fascists (they were actually 
small).  We waited until they went and then started the party up 
again.  Went till dawn :-)  This was, however, a personal nightmare for me 
because at the same time the cops were there a guest had some bad reaction 
to an overdose of cough meds and it looked like the worst might 
happen.  The EMT took a look and said he was in no danger and Danny very 
kindly took him to the bathroom to throw up.


Love,

Apollo

From: Terry Estioko <terry@saturn5.com>

To: Chris Jackson <cjax@sbcglobal.net>

Subject: RE: [sfraves] question du jour: your worst party bust

On Wed, 22 Jun 2005, Chris Jackson wrote:
>
> one, an urban wasteland party under a freeway overpass next to the
> traintracks in oakland.  i know many on this list were there.  i just
> remember the crew telling us not to go back the way we came because
> cops were there waiting on the other side.  so instead, we had to walk
> down the tracks, then cut across and around.  basically going around
> the cops.  never did see one.<
>
> Hahaha.  I remember that!  I JUST got done playing when they were driving
> up.  I was trying to hide my record bag the whole walk back to the
> car...damn party poopers..

Man, totally remember that one, it was so Dope =)

It was right next to a series of railroad tracks, and at one point a train 
swings by and slows to a crawl, just trying figure out what to make of us. 
Later on, train comes back, this time stops on the tracks 
directly behind the DJ, and let's out his 
horn/whistle/whatever...WHOOWHOOOOOO!!! Crowd goes crazy, he give a thumbs 
up or some form of approval (couldn't tell for sure). Next thing I know 
girlies are on the train dancing, train operator starts giving people 
rides, it was a very surreal scene.

At some point, Johnny Law comes looking for us, approaching from the south 
end of the overpass. Migurski and I get wise and go in the opposite 
direction, then hop onto the overpass and walk over the party as it was 
being busted.

Yeah, good one =)

-terry

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] question du jour: your worst party bust

I was at a party called "Firecracker" @ Buzz in DC (it was a 4th of July 
shindig). Place was positively PACKED (around 3000 + heads easily). Actually 
the police didn't shut it down - fire marshalls did due to overcrowding. I 
remember trying to get from one room to the next when the music shut down at 
around 12am...buzzkilling many folks.

Wound up at an afterparty where I kissed one of the prettiest women I have 
ever seen to date - so in the end it wasn't all that bad, lol.

~M



>From: Bam <invibe@gmail.com>
>Reply-To: Bam <invibe@gmail.com>
>To: Deepfog <sfgroove@deepfog.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] question du jour: your worst party bust
>Date: Wed, 22 Jun 2005 16:04:58 -0700
>
>i don't really have any good bust stories.   though two come to mind.
>
>one, an urban wasteland party under a freeway overpass next to the
>traintracks in oakland.  i know many on this list were there.  i just
>remember the crew telling us not to go back the way we came because
>cops were there waiting on the other side.  so instead, we had to walk
>down the tracks, then cut across and around.  basically going around
>the cops.  never did see one.
>
>two, was at a party called...more hands and feet.  i think that was
>it.  either cosmic beats or cRave threw the party and it was at their
>venue over by 550 barnaveld.  cops show up and tell everyone to leave.
>  but everyone had been shuttled there from a parking area back over by
>550.  so there we were....about 200 or so candy ravers walking on the
>sidewalk, under the freeway, past 500 barnaveld, over to our cars.
>was kinda fun, actually!
>
>oh wait, one more story!  the last Area 51 when it was split into two
>parties.  i was at the party at the Sweets Ballroom in Oakland.  DJ
>irene was on and the music shuts down.  it was about 11pm or so.  we
>are informed that the party is over, but they are going to let Meat
>Beat Manifesto play and then everyone has to go.  Meat Beat tore it up
>and i loved it.  then i ended up at the renegade afterparty in
>Milpitas.
>
>but the best thing about that night was while the music was off and
>the future of the party was in question, i bumped into Madame Mercury.
>  and we got to talking and i asked her how she got started DJing.  and
>it was that conversation with her that made me decide to try my hand
>at DJing.  i bought my tables and mixer the next month when i got a
>bonus from work.  if the cops hadn't come and they hadn't turned the
>music off, i wouldn't have had that conversation with her.  and i most
>likely wouldn't have bought my decks.  and i wouldn't be playing
>records today.
>
>so thank god for the cops busting the party.  ;)
>
>On 6/22/05, gregvp@comcast.net <gregvp@comcast.net> wrote:
> > It was a Moksha tribe party in a residential neighborhood in San 
>Francisco. Can't remember the name of the party, but it was one of the 
>early ones (second Moksha Tribe party, I think). They had great blacklight 
>artwork (from Joey) premiering at this party. It was such a good vibe until 
>the bust. Since then of course they have learned where to have these 
>parties although you never know for sure.
> >
> > Anyway, the coppers showed up because a neighbor made a noise complaint. 
>So, they turned down the music to comply but apparently it wasn't enough so 
>the cops came back again later.
> >
> > Apollo was at the front door along with Joey, I think, and Apollo was 
>such a professional at handling these cops. Kept them outside the party, at 
>the door, which was a good thing. What a smooth talker! Inside, the crew 
>was trying to keep everyone calm and silent and law-abiding.
> >
> > I had my roommate with me, and it was his first rave, so he was freaking 
>out. He wanted to leave immediately. But one of the crew kept him inside, 
>all she had to do was say, "How do you think it would look if people tried 
>going outside right now? You think they would let you leave freely without 
>a search?" And she calmed him down with that thought. Cause yes, it would 
>be suspicious if people started heading for the very door where the cops 
>are standing!
> >
> > When all was clear, we left the party for home, but according to a later 
>review (by Osby, I think) the event turned into a kind of chill, ambient 
>mixture (a quiet rave) where people spent the night talking and enjoying 
>themselves in spite of the bust!
> >
> > Anyway, that was my only major bust experience. The only other time that 
>cops came to a party (another Moksha UG in Oakland), I hardly noticed 
>because I was getting down in a separate room from the main floor and 
>apparently the music didn't get turned down enough for me to notice!
> >
> > Greg
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > -------------- Original message --------------
> >
> > > i suspect a lot of people will have a lot to say about this and i hope 
>you
> > > all speak up. and i've got a few questions in the wings related to 
>this
> > > so ... here goes.
> > >
> > > what's your worst party bust experience? and i know we've all been
> > > through a lot of them!
> > >

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1

Hey Man,
 
Let's take a stab @ it. Muffled to me means kept down, or supressed. Are you looking for more amplitude, or is it peaking/distorted/clipping?
 
I'll go out on a limb and assume you've fucked with the levels already. Are you running your mixer to a comp, or another device? If it's a comp, what kind of soundcard are you using? Also, if you're recording on your comp, what software are you using? 
 
That should be enough to get us started. 
 
Peace
 
Chuck

> >
> >oh wait, one more story!  the last Area 51 when it
> was split into two
> >parties.  i was at the party at the Sweets Ballroom
> in Oakland.  DJ
> >irene was on and the music shuts down.  it was
> about 11pm or so.  we
> >are informed that the party is over, but they are
> going to let Meat
> >Beat Manifesto play and then everyone has to go. 
> Meat Beat tore it up
> >and i loved it.  then i ended up at the renegade
> afterparty in
> >Milpitas.
> >
> >but the best thing about that night was while the
> music was off and
> >the future of the party was in question, i bumped
> into Madame Mercury.
> >  and we got to talking and i asked her how she got
> started DJing.  and
> >it was that conversation with her that made me
> decide to try my hand
> >at DJing.  i bought my tables and mixer the next
> month when i got a
> >bonus from work.  if the cops hadn't come and they
> hadn't turned the
> >music off, i wouldn't have had that conversation
> with her.  and i most
> >likely wouldn't have bought my decks.  and i
> wouldn't be playing
> >records today.
> >
> >so thank god for the cops busting the party.  ;)

h

Subject: Re: [sfraves] recording question

--0-556848428-1119506427=:91168
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Matt:
 
IMHO (standard disclaimer so I don't get bitchmade by someone that actually knows what they're talking about):
 
Cable loose? j/k it's happened though. Sounds like you've got this card:
http://creative.com/products/product.asp?category=1&subcategory=206&product=10315
 
24 bits should cut it, but I prefer something a little more direct:
http://pg.photos.yahoo.com/ph/chuckg_421/detail?.dir=9a8e&.dnm=a5f8.jpg&.src=ph
 
If you'd rather go balls out:
http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/tg/detail/-/B0002M6ACS/qid=1119505779/sr=8-2/ref=pd_bbs_2/103-8591958-1347858?v=glance&n=507846
 
-or for that matter:
http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/tg/detail/-/B0002H0GT6/qid=1119505808/sr=8-2/ref=pd_bbs_2/103-8591958-1347858?v=glance&n=507846
 
In the meantime, try opening up the recording properties window by double clicking the speaker down by your clock on the start bar. Expand it if you don't see the icon.  If you go to Options--> Properties, you can highlight the Adjust Volume for Recording button, then check all prudent boxes below. After you hit OK, the recording levels will come up. Make sure they're all turned up including not only the line in, but the master & wav levels as well. Mute the mic to prevent feedback (I think), and make sure you're plugged into the line in jack in lieu of the mic jack. I don't know if that makes a difference or not but it's how I have mine rigged. You might have a Creative speaker icon for the card too. If so, fuck with it. 
 
Once recorded, 'google mastering a cd.
 
Here's a decent resource:
http://www.homerecording.com/
 
And a pretty cool forum on computer recording:
http://www.homerecording.com/bbs/forumdisplay.php?forumid=14
 
You've probably tried all this but good luck anyways. I'm a bit stoned right now so let me know if any of these links don't work. 
 
peace
 
chuck

back the recording it sounds flat. the amplitude is
not great either.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] recording question

Oh- you just need to buy an anti-muffler/super-crisper setup-

Seriously, terms like that are what audiophilidiots use after they invest  
in $50 power cables.
"Wow do you hear that warmth and presence?"
I dunno wtf is wrong with what you're doing, but achieving CD quality from  
even the cheapest consumer-level sound card is easy these days.
It's always just a matter of setting the output levels correctly, setting  
the input sensitivity correctly, and recording at the proper bitrate/depth.
Any compression etc you need to do can be done *after* that-
That card btw (the SB Live) is one of the finest ever made...
And wtf is roxio spin doctor?
A good free simple recording tool is audacity:
http://audacity.sourceforge.net/

-SS

> a

> that the cops came over the hill/ridge at that moment.  Still one of my
> fav

> n' giggles..

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Apollo [mailto:apollo@speakeasy.org]
> Sent: Wednesday, June 22, 2005 4:10 PM
> To: gregvp@comcast.net; Deepfog; sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] question du jour: your worst party bust
> 
> At 03:29 PM 6/22/2005, gregvp@comcast.net wrote:
> >It was a Moksha tribe party in a residential neighborhood in San
> >Francisco. Can't remember the name of the party, but it was one of the
> >early ones (second Moksha Tribe party, I think). They had great
> blacklight
> >artwork (from Joey) premiering at this party. It was such a good vibe
> >until the bust. Since then of course they have learned where to have
> these
> >parties although you never know for sure.
> >
> >Anyway, the coppers showed up because a neighbor made a noise complaint.
> >So, they turned down the music to comply but apparently it wasn't enough
> >so the cops came back again later.
> >
> >Apollo was at the front door along with Joey, I think, and Apollo was
> such
> >a professional at handling these cops. Kept them outside the party, at
> the
> >door, which was a good thing. What a smooth talker! Inside, the crew was
> >trying to keep everyone calm and silent and law-abiding.
> 
> Yes Greg.  I remember the night vividly :-)  The party was Deviance.  The
> cops came back at least four times I remember, and the last was headed by
> a
> captain who was about to seize the equipment and arrest the DJs. Figured
> it
> was time to rearrange things then..
> 
> 
> 
> >I had my roommate with me, and it was his first rave, so he was freaking
> >out. He wanted to leave immediately. But one of the crew kept him inside,
> >all she had to do was say, "How do you think it would look if people
> tried
> >going outside right now? You think they would let you leave freely
> without
> >a search?" And she calmed him down with that thought. Cause yes, it would
> >be suspicious if people started heading for the very door where the cops
> >are standing!
> >
> >When all was clear, we left the party for home, but according to a later
> >review (by Osby, I think) the event turned into a kind of chill, ambient
> >mixture (a quiet rave) where people spent the night talking and enjoying
> >themselves in spite of the bust!
> 
> The party went on until 6 or so.  It was a big chill event and rather
> nice.  I was upset because the police came just as things were going
> off;  but it was cool to have a chance to talk with peeps.  I don't
> believe
> in shutting down a party unless the police throw you out.  Too many high
> kids are placed in harms way, so I look for some reasonable accommodation.
> 
> 
> >Anyway, that was my only major bust experience. The only other time that
> >cops came to a party (another Moksha UG in Oakland), I hardly noticed
> >because I was getting down in a separate room from the main floor and
> >apparently the music didn't get turned down enough for me to notice!
> 
> These Oakland cops were really little Fascists (they were actually
> small).  We waited until they went and then started the party up
> again.  Went till dawn :-)  This was, however, a personal nightmare for me
> because at the same time the cops were there a guest had some bad reaction
> to an overdose of cough meds and it looked like the worst might
> happen.  The EMT took a look and said he was in no danger and Danny very
> kindly took him to the bathroom to throw up.
> 
> 
> Love,
> 
> Apollo

Hmm.. I have to say it would be the infamous "chicken ranch incident".  Underground, out at a farmhouse between Sacramento and Galt.  Setup in a barn/garage out back.  Apparently the people throwing it knew the owners/rented the place.  Strange party, they had a really crappy punk band on prior to any EDM.  Once the band was done, the deejays setup.  All was going quite well.
 
Around 1AM, Dragnfly got up and tore the roof off of the barn, and about midway through her set about 15 cornfed Sac County Sherrif bust into the barn, and shut it down.  Being thoroughly Yagerized, a friend and I figure we'll just go hang out in the field and wait for the drama to cool so I could drive without hitting a cow/tree/chicken coup.
 
Little did we know, there was a "special" guy living in a tiny one-room shack out at the back of the property. By special, I mean the olympics AND bates motel.  Scary.  He was literally carrying a pitchfork.  After we get confronted by this cretan, and try to talk our way out of him holding us hostage... Dina comes barreling down the driveway in her truck with about 10 other candy-clad kids in the back so we run away from billybob and jump in.  Saved our lives.
 
True story... all of it. :)
 
Toferman

From: georgeC | origami <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
To: matthew johnson <mpj_bay@yahoo.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <20050623032540.50840.qmail@web51711.mail.yahoo.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] recording question

The outs from the reciever could be the culprit- having all that extra
shit in the signal path is a less-than optimal thing.  Here is the
optimal setup:

Mixer's "booth" or "monitor" outs running to the reciever (control
monitor volume with "monitor" knob on mixer).

Mixer's "master" or "main" outs running to the sound card.  If the
connector type is different, avoid using a bunch of adapters- ideally,
have a decent cable with the correct terminations on each end.  Guitar
Center or the like will have it.  Don't be afraid to spend a little
money on it if you have to to get something of decent quality.  Cables
(to a point) can make a great deal of difference.

On mixer, make sure level meters hover around dbu 0 (usually found in
the middle or 1/3rd of the way down the meter), unless rely on mixer
clipping for part of your sound (unless you know you do, you probably
don't).

In your recording app (and I second Scott's suggestion about Audacity
as a good free recorder/editor), make sure the level meters are
hovering around 0 (this will be the top of the range)  You want to get
your signal close to, but not hitting, zero.

If you aren't getting enough signal, find a happy medium between
boosting levels on your mixer and boosting input gain on your
soundblaster's control panel app.  The input circuits on the
soundblaster are nearly always going to be of lower quality than your
mixer's, but you want to make sure that you're not overdriving the
mixer itself, or overworking its gain circuits.  Just listen critically
and you'll hear harshness if you push one or the other too far.

If you're clipping the living shit out of the soundcard, turn the
output volume down on the mixer.

If you make your way through this process and the sound still doesn't
thrill, the soundcard is most likely to blame.  That is, assuming the
sound coming out of the mixer, into headphones/speakers is good, and
that your reciever doesn't have "loudness" or much eq enabled on it,
skewing the way you're hearing your mix through the speakers.  Run the
reciever "flat" (no eq, no procesessing of any kind) when recording so
you can make real decisions about the sound as you record.

If the card is to blame, look into something a little more "pro audio".
 There are literally dozens of better-than-consumer audio
cards/interfaces on the market that will offer better sonics than the
SBL for less than $200.  

Cheers, happy recording,
-george C | origami
-newstylesound.com
-djorigami.com
-foldedsf

>>>>Oh- you just need to buy an anti-muffler/super-crisper setup- Seriously, terms like that are what audiophilidiots use after they invest 
in $50 power cables.
 
Ouch! Did you read the rest?

Nathan Seven <scosol@scosol.org> wrote:
Oh- you just need to buy an anti-muffler/super-crisper setup-

Seriously, terms like that are what audiophilidiots use after they invest 
in $50 power cables.
"Wow do you hear that warmth and presence?"
I dunno wtf is wrong with what you're doing, but achieving CD quality from 
even the cheapest consumer-level sound card is easy these days.
It's always just a matter of setting the output levels correctly, setting 
the input sensitivity correctly, and recording at the proper bitrate/depth.
Any compression etc you need to do can be done *after* that-
That card btw (the SB Live) is one of the finest ever made...
And wtf is roxio spin doctor?
A good free simple recording tool is audacity:
http://audacity.sourceforge.net/

-SS

On Wed, 22 Jun 2005 23:00:27 -0700, CHUCK G wrote:

> Matt:
> IMHO (standard disclaimer so I don't get bitchmade by someone that 
> actually knows what they're talking about):
> Cable loose? j/k it's happened though. Sounds like you've got this card:
> http://creative.com/products/product.asp?category=1&subcategory=206&product=10315
> 24 bits should cut it, but I prefer something a little more direct:
> http://pg.photos.yahoo.com/ph/chuckg_421/detail?.dir=9a8e&.dnm=a5f8.jpg&.src=ph
> If you'd rather go balls out:
> http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/tg/detail/-/B0002M6ACS/qid=1119505779/sr=8-2/ref=pd_bbs_2/103-8591958-1347858?v=glance&n=507846
> -or for that matter:
> http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/tg/detail/-/B0002H0GT6/qid=1119505808/sr=8-2/ref=pd_bbs_2/103-8591958-1347858?v=glance&n=507846
> In the meantime, try opening up the recording properties window by 
> double clicking the speaker down by your clock on the start bar. Expand 
> it if you don't see the icon. If you go to Options--> Properties, you 
> can highlight the Adjust Volume for Recording button, then check all 
> prudent boxes below. After you hit OK, the recording levels will come 
> up. Make sure they're all turned up including not only the line in, but 
> the master & wav levels as well. Mute the mic to prevent feedback (I 
> think), and make sure you're plugged into the line in jack in lieu of 
> the mic jack. I don't know if that makes a difference or not but it's 
> how I have mine rigged. You might have a Creative speaker icon for the 
> card too. If so, fuck with it.
> Once recorded, 'google mastering a cd.
> Here's a decent resource:
> http://www.homerecording.com/
> And a pretty cool forum on computer recording:
> http://www.homerecording.com/bbs/forumdisplay.php?forumid=14
> You've probably tried all this but good luck anyways. I'm a bit stoned 
> right now so let me know if any of these links don't work.
> peace

Subject: Re: [sfraves] recording question

He says that the "amplitude is not great either". So obviously the
problem is that his recording level isn't set correctly. On the
computer you should be as close to 0db as possible without going over
it and on the receiver/mixer you should aim for around +6db peaks
depending on sound and equipment quality.

After you are done recording it, fix the DC offset and add some
compression using software.

Steve Osteen

On 6/23/05, CHUCK G <chuckg_421@yahoo.com> wrote:
> >>>>Oh- you just need to buy an anti-muffler/super-crisper setup- Serious=
ly, terms like that are what audiophilidiots use after they invest
> in $50 power cables.
>=20

> Nathan Seven <scosol@scosol.org> wrote:
> Oh- you just need to buy an anti-muffler/super-crisper setup-
>=20
> Seriously, terms like that are what audiophilidiots use after they invest
> in $50 power cables.
> "Wow do you hear that warmth and presence?"
> I dunno wtf is wrong with what you're doing, but achieving CD quality fro=
m
> even the cheapest consumer-level sound card is easy these days.
> It's always just a matter of setting the output levels correctly, setting
> the input sensitivity correctly, and recording at the proper bitrate/dept=
h.
> Any compression etc you need to do can be done *after* that-
> That card btw (the SB Live) is one of the finest ever made...
> And wtf is roxio spin doctor?
> A good free simple recording tool is audacity:
> http://audacity.sourceforge.net/
>=20
> -SS
>=20
> On Wed, 22 Jun 2005 23:00:27 -0700, CHUCK G wrote:
>=20
> > Matt:
> > IMHO (standard disclaimer so I don't get bitchmade by someone that
> > actually knows what they're talking about):
> > Cable loose? j/k it's happened though. Sounds like you've got this card=
:
> > http://creative.com/products/product.asp?category=3D1&subcategory=3D206=
&product=3D10315
> > 24 bits should cut it, but I prefer something a little more direct:
> > http://pg.photos.yahoo.com/ph/chuckg_421/detail?.dir=3D9a8e&.dnm=3Da5f8=
.jpg&.src=3Dph
> > If you'd rather go balls out:
> > http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/tg/detail/-/B0002M6ACS/qid=3D11195057=
79/sr=3D8-2/ref=3Dpd_bbs_2/103-8591958-1347858?v=3Dglance&n=3D507846
> > -or for that matter:
> > http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/tg/detail/-/B0002H0GT6/qid=3D11195058=
08/sr=3D8-2/ref=3Dpd_bbs_2/103-8591958-1347858?v=3Dglance&n=3D507846
> > In the meantime, try opening up the recording properties window by
> > double clicking the speaker down by your clock on the start bar. Expand
> > it if you don't see the icon. If you go to Options--> Properties, you
> > can highlight the Adjust Volume for Recording button, then check all
> > prudent boxes below. After you hit OK, the recording levels will come
> > up. Make sure they're all turned up including not only the line in, but
> > the master & wav levels as well. Mute the mic to prevent feedback (I
> > think), and make sure you're plugged into the line in jack in lieu of
> > the mic jack. I don't know if that makes a difference or not but it's
> > how I have mine rigged. You might have a Creative speaker icon for the
> > card too. If so, fuck with it.
> > Once recorded, 'google mastering a cd.
> > Here's a decent resource:
> > http://www.homerecording.com/
> > And a pretty cool forum on computer recording:
> > http://www.homerecording.com/bbs/forumdisplay.php?forumid=3D14
> > You've probably tried all this but good luck anyways. I'm a bit stoned
> > right now so let me know if any of these links don't work.
> > peace
> > chuck

> > >irene was on and the music shuts down.  it was

> > >are informed that the party is over, but they are
> > going to let Meat

> > afterparty in
> > >Milpitas.
> > >
> > >but the best thing about that night was while the
> > music was off and
> > >the future of the party was in question, i bumped
> > into Madame Mercury.
> > >  and we got to talking and i asked her how she got
> > started DJing.  and
> > >it was that conversation with her that made me
> > decide to try my hand
> > >at DJing.  i bought my tables and mixer the next
> > month when i got a
> > >bonus from work.  if the cops hadn't come and they
> > hadn't turned the
> > >music off, i wouldn't have had that conversation
> > with her.  and i most
> > >likely wouldn't have bought my decks.  and i
> > wouldn't be playing
> > >records today.
> > >

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) Quote of the Day (Thu)

so far i've really enjoyed reading the stories about party busts and yes,
i do remember the party they threw up at the crystal springs water tower. 
i thought, what a place to throw a party, if it doesn't get busted.  i'll
have another question for you but i'll wait till monday to give people
time to reply to the first question.

i don't really know where i'm going with this chef's quote of the day
series because i don't really know that many famous chefs.  my friend ryan
says that 30 minute chef is pretty fine and that's why he bought her book.
 does anyone remember this guy?  this isn't necessarily a quote, but i
pulled it off his website ... http://www.cheftell.com .  he used to be on
i think channel 5 news every night before he got more famous, i guess.

--

I was hungry the first seven years of my life.   Grew up during the war,
and food was rationed.  My mother used to tell me to become a chef so that
I would always have enough food.

- Chef Tell Erhardt

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: World's First Bionic Man

--0-746934847-1119559318=:13853
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Hope this pasted OK. Here's a link if not:http://www.local6.com/news/4643968/detail.htmlBionic Man Moves Artificial Arm With BrainBreakthrough Could Change Lives Of Amputees, Patients With Spinal Cord Injuries
POSTED: 12:55 pm EDT June 23, 2005
UPDATED: 4:07 pm EDT June 23, 2005


CHICAGO -- Researchers have developed artificial arms that can be moved as it if they were real limbs, simply by thinking about making them move, according to Local 6 News. 

 
When Jesse Sullivan's brain tells his arm to do something, it's done in seconds.





The world's first bionic man, Jesse Sullivan, 54, accidentally touched live wires while working as a utility lineman in Tennessee. He suffered severe burns, causing him to lose his arms. 




---------------------------------
 SLIDESHOW: Images Of Bionic Man 
 IMAGES: More strange images featured on Local6.com 
---------------------------------




Now, Sullivan is the first to try out the most sophisticated artificial arms ever designed. 

Surgeons attached his arm nerves to healthy muscles in his chest. 

Video
Bionic Man Moves Artificial Arm With Brain 




"So now when Jess thinks, close hand, the impulse is picked up by a transmitter, and goes to his hand," doctor Todd Kuiken said. "He thinks, closes hand and it does." 

Sullivan's hand rotates 360 degrees, according to the report. When Sullivan's brain tells his arm to do something, it's done in seconds and he has feeling in the bionic arm. 








"This gives me a lot of hope," Sullivan said. "I was an independent kind of guy. I didn't ask anybody for anything. If I could do it, I did it." 

Eventually tiny sensors in the fingertips will allow Sullivan to feel texture and temperature. 

Doctors at the Rehabilitation Institute of Chicago said the breakthrough could change the lives of amputees, patients with spinal cord injuries and stroke victims, according to the report. 

By the time it's perfected, the cost of manufacturing the bionic arm is expected to be about $6 million, according to the report. 

For more information on the Rehabilitation Institute of Chicago, Please click www.ric.org. 

Watch Local 6 News for more on this story. 
Copyright 2005 by Internet Broadcasting Systems and Local6.com. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.

Subject: [sfraves] worst party bust(s)....

hmmm... there were several... which one was the worst?
 well, the most dramatic one was the new years eve
1995 party at 938 harrison street thrown by terrance
alan.  i'll try to make a long story short... it was
an AMAZING party.  radical queers, fnf folks, spaz,
lots of people who normally wouldn't be together at a
big rave.  alex windsor played a hot set.  i was
having a major spiritual experience, uh, seeing "god"
(or, a god, rather), whilst dancing topless (i think?)
surrounded by drag queens, trannies, freaks,
faeries...  very, very magickal.   i even quit smoking
that night!  i remember my friend, billie jack, now
deceased, coming through dressed in red with smoking
incense, and feeling like the whole thing was a
medieval carnival, an alternate world, and having this
thought that it was too good to be true.  and i guess
it was, because at about 4am when i was off backstage
chilling out, my friend came in and announced that the
cops were there.  uh oh.  i think all in all about 11
people were arrested, 1 sexually assaulted, another
had his eye gouged and/or was choked... i've still got
a file somewhere w/ all the news clippings...we did a
bunch of organizing after the bust and managed to get
a cop or two suspended, i think.  and, or course,
terrance alan is now head of the entertainment
commission.  nice!  but yeah, it was an utter shock to
the system, going from such bliss to a cold, hard
police state reality... too bad this wasn't the only
time...

Subject: [sfraves] weekend report...a little late...

Last weekend was a great party weekend for me, and an
excellent way to start off the Solstice time....

Friday we went to see John Tejada and Alexi Delano at
Studio Z.  In the past i've found Tejada pretty good,
but a bit boring, but this time he was really good. 
Alexi Delano was ok, lots of acid, which i like, but
not inspiring enough to keep 
me there super late...

Saturday, well, i went to Konrol at the Rx and ...
Galoppierende Zuversicht were the shit!  They were
amazing, and their set was one of the best i've heard
this year!  Wow!  The whole place was really going
off.  the best party i've been to at the Rx, for
sure...

I had wanted to check out the Advent afterwards, but
my partner balked at spending $20 after paying a cover
already, and i didn't want to have to drive our other
friend home, and then drive him home....  so we
skipped it.  Had heard about a post-Rx afterparty but
it seemed to be a smallish affair so we skipped that,
too.  oh well.  

then, sunday, up to harbin hot springs.  aaahhhh!

Subject: [sfraves] big up to the angel of cop mercy

seriously. I've not had one bust experience yet of any significance.
the last party I was at that got busted, we got directions to another
party FROM THE COPS. they told us where to find the other party, they
told us we could use the other party's location any time we wanted,
they told us the other location wasn't even in their jurisdiction,
they played their siren like a whistle when they left, and they shared
how many years each of them had been on the force. honestly, if these
cops had been any more PLUR, they would have been giving people
lollipops. ^_^

Subject: Re: [sfraves] big up to the angel of cop mercy

This reminds me of a party I went to out in the desert in Utah near the
great Salt Lake. It was a planned 2 day campout on private land, BLM told
us the lines we couldn't cross over.  A couple of the local cops, not in
their jurisdiction (although there is no real jurisdiction in Utah) but
there for the party itself from Tooele were hanging out and having fun
when out of the blue right as the sun is setting and the party is starting
the highway patrol shows up and tells us we crossed the invisible line
onto BLM land by 4 feet with one of the stages, pulls the permit and tells
us to pack up.  The local cops fought with the highway patrol for another
hour to get them to be reasonable and let us move back over the invisible
line and keep going like it was supposed to.  Unfortunately they didn't
see reason and instead we had to use the backup location for the next two
nights and most of the festivities were cancelled for the campout.  The
cops decided to drive all the way into salt lake though for the backup
location and danced all night with the rest of us.  It was pretty cool,
especially since all the Utah cops are almost copy-pasted to only know the
word no, and deny anything can be fun outside of a family unit.

-Rayn

thats my top, never seen anything like it.  the road back to where our cars
were was littered with people, some just grabbing the tents without packing
them and walking while draggin them.  it was horrible!

i still have gregs email he sent out about what went down.

man that was rough.

-----Original Message-----
From: gregvp@comcast.net [mailto:gregvp@comcast.net]
Sent: Wednesday, June 22, 2005 3:30 PM
To: Deepfog; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] question du jour: your worst party bust


It was a Moksha tribe party in a residential neighborhood in San Francisco.
Can't remember the name of the party, but it was one of the early ones
(second Moksha Tribe party, I think). They had great blacklight artwork
(from Joey) premiering at this party. It was such a good vibe until the
bust. Since then of course they have learned where to have these parties
although you never know for sure.

Anyway, the coppers showed up because a neighbor made a noise complaint. So,
they turned down the music to comply but apparently it wasn't enough so the
cops came back again later.

Apollo was at the front door along with Joey, I think, and Apollo was such a
professional at handling these cops. Kept them outside the party, at the
door, which was a good thing. What a smooth talker! Inside, the crew was
trying to keep everyone calm and silent and law-abiding.

I had my roommate with me, and it was his first rave, so he was freaking
out. He wanted to leave immediately. But one of the crew kept him inside,
all she had to do was say, "How do you think it would look if people tried
going outside right now? You think they would let you leave freely without a
search?" And she calmed him down with that thought. Cause yes, it would be
suspicious if people started heading for the very door where the cops are
standing!

When all was clear, we left the party for home, but according to a later
review (by Osby, I think) the event turned into a kind of chill, ambient
mixture (a quiet rave) where people spent the night talking and enjoying
themselves in spite of the bust!

Anyway, that was my only major bust experience. The only other time that
cops came to a party (another Moksha UG in Oakland), I hardly noticed
because I was getting down in a separate room from the main floor and
apparently the music didn't get turned down enough for me to notice!

Greg

Hi all,

I received several emails asking me about the duration of this event.
The ritual/talk lasts from 7:30pm to 10pm approx. So there's still =
plenty of time to go somewhere else afterwards.
The ritual is interactive and experiential but fully voluntary.
If you have any comments or questions about it let me know.

Juan Carlos
Black Note Music - Techno Shamanic Music
-- Energized Sound Creations --
http://www.deconstructionist.com/blacknote/



      "Sacred Shamanic Sex"

      A Magickal Invocational Talk and Ritual by Koyote
      with
      Ambient Electronic Music by Trip Tech
    =20

        Saturday - June 25, 2005 7:30pm


        Sex is at the core of life itself. Creation, Will, and the =
spiritual life all gain their fuel from sexual energy. There is an =
ancient tradition of esoteric work that seeks to access this source of =
unlimited potential for the alchemical transformation of the Being.=20

        This Toltec shamanic teaching has remained hidden for over one =
thousand years and has been passed only by direct transmission while in =
altered states of consciousness.=20

        Koyote will continue this tradition, and pass on this teaching =
through a live ritual designed to create a psychic state where the =
Sacred Serpent within
        you can activate your creativity and spiritual transformation.

        When: Saturday - June 25, 2005=20
        Time: 7:30pm=20
        Price: $5
        Where: At The Gatehouse in Fort Mason

        Click here for directions


        Please send us your email or address if you would like to be on =
our mailing list.




        Koyote has worked with various shamanic and magickal traditions =
throughout his life, including the Thelemic tradition and the Toltec =
Indian Tradition of Mexico. He conducts transformative workshops =
throughout the United States and Latin America where he passes on the =
knowledge he has received from all these various sources. Koyote also =
incorporates music, video and theater into his work to achieve a total =
inmersive experience.=20
    =20

    =20

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Jackal & Hyde - DNA Lounge this Sunday - $5

Sunday night, people.  Jackal & Hyde are bringing the sickness!  Fuck
Mondays!!!!!

for a sample of what to expect:

Jackal & Hyde - Darkstar
http://mp3.juno.co.uk/MP3/SF174483-01-01-01.mp3

Jackal & Hyde - Give it all you got 2000 (remix/remake of old
Afrorican b-boy jam)
http://mp3.juno.co.uk/MP3/SF67099-01-01-02.mp3

For more audio samples of their newer material, check their Myspace page:
http://www.myspace.com/jackalandhyde

AND to top things off, they'll be brining their own visuals with stuff
like this:
http://www.hallucination.com/_subsites/jackalandhyde.com/art.html

this is $5 people and the show will most definitely be worth going to
work tired and hungover on Monday.

-------
Evil Breaks & StrategiK present:
Jackal and Hyde Live
Sunday June 26th, 2005
@ DNA Lounge (375 11th st)

the first 100 people get in 2 for 1, and the door is an amazingly low
price of only $5.
$2 off all drinks till 11pm, thanx to DNA.

Jackal and Hyde - Live (Hallucination/Scheme Addict Records) West Palm Beac=
h, FL
-special visuals provided

Jackal & Hyde have been called "the purveyors of the hardcore-electro
sound" (electro-core), a combination of industrial laden electro
beats, and psychotic keys. Jackal & Hyde was formed in 1998 by
partners Scott Weiser, and Todd Walker in an effort to combine a
harder edge sound with the dancefloor sensibility of Electro or
"Techno-Bass". Besides their original work, Jackal & Hyde's sound has
been requested for multiple remix productions including Kid Rock, Love
& Rockets, and Biochip C. Scott Weiser, who is most recognized for his
work in I.B.M. (Industrial Bass Machine), and the duo Dynamix II, who
have written such dancefloor classics as "Give The DJ A Break" and
"Feel The Bass", has been writing and producing dance music for over a
decade. Scott's influences range anywhere from classic Industrial to
Classical, while partner Todd Walker's influences come from Miami
Ghetto Bass and Industrial Dance. As Jackal & Hyde, Scott and Todd
push the boundaries of dance music and set the standards for the new
school of electro.

J-Break (Cyberian Knights/Afterdark Records) Tampa, FL

J-Break has been rocking the decks all across North America and
Europe, playing his signature style of breaks and electro. After his
debut mix cd, "Bio:Mechanik" on Subculture Records, Jackal & J-Break
founded the electro label, Cyberian Knights Recordings, to release
"This is the Sound of Underground," as heard on the Baby Anne "Mixed
Live: Las Vegas" mixed compilation on Moonshine. J-Break has done
numerous studio collaborations with international renown artists
Infiniti, Fixx, Johnny Cage, and Josef Plante, to name a few. Be on
the lookout for J-Break this fall as he hits the road for his
"Barcelona, Spain" CD Release Tour.

Along with local Breakbeat superstars:

Tung (Brass Tax/Subalicious)

Aaron Jae vs. Bam vs. M.O.D. (Evil Breaks/SFBreaks.org)
-Special 3 by 4 old school funky set

Influence vs. Jay Vigor (Beatsfactory.com/Strategik/London Breakz)
-2 by 4

Capt'n Kirk (Space Cowboys)

Jackal and Hyde will also be bringing their own visual specialist all
the way from Florida to help put on one of the most memorable
performances you will EVER witness. And on top of the already super
ridiculously cheap price of this amazing show, Evil Breaks will be
giving away tons of free tickets to members of its mailing list, so if
you're not a member, sign up now.

Jackal and Hyde Live
Sunday June 26th, 2005
@ DNA Lounge (375 11th st)
first 100 2 for 1
$2 off all drinks till 11
$5 entry

MOKSHA TRIBE PRESENTS GROOVE IN THE GROVE THIS SATURDAY

Date & Time: Saturday, June 25, 2005
12:00 PM
Location: Baylands Grove Amphitheater
Sunnyvale, CA
More Info: 415-564-4768
<http://tinyurl.com/e35c6>tinyurl<http://tinyurl.com/e35c6>.com/e35c6


With spring comes rebirth, and the Moksha Tribe Collective is returning 
this summer with infectious beats and happy vibes.

Our DIY ethic and not for profit focus will continue to be in full effect!!!

The fun recommences with "Groove in the Grove," a sunny, free day party 
scheduled for Saturday, June 25th, from noon to 6:45 PM.

Your groovers for the day:

Cubik and Origami
Marcine
DV8
Sheztek VS BAM (Evilbreaks)
Faye Valentine VS DJ Dilema aka DFD
Hypnotoad

    * Beautiful Virgin Day Party Location in Sunnyvale, just 45 minutes 
from SF:
http://baytrail.abag.ca.gov/vtour/map3/access/Syvlblds/syvlblds3.htm

Party is at Baylands Grove Amphitheater, now Baylands Groove ;)

 From SF:

-All Freeways to 101 South
-Exit Lawrence Expressway in Sunnyvale
-Left onto Lawrence Expressway
-Go straight for about 3/4 of a mile
-Right on Baylands Park Dr.

 From EastBay:

-All Freeways to 880 South
-Exit Highway 237 towards Mountain View
-Exit Caribbean/Lawrence Expressway Exit
-Turn onto Caribbean St.
-First Right onto Baylands Park Dr.

 From SouthBay

-101 North
-Exit Lawrence Expressway
-Right onto Lawrence Expressway
-Go straight for about 3/4 of a mile
-Right on Baylands Park Dr.

      Park on left side of park

    * Bring your own drinks
    * Respect the location and pick up your trash
    * No Pets Allowed
    * $5 entry fee.  This fee is imposed by the park authorities.
    * There is ample parking outside of the park if you wish to avoid the 
entry fee but we encourage guests to pay the $5 to show appreciation for 
use of the facility.
    * We will be taking donations.  Reminder:  Moksha Tribe is Not for Profit.
    * Donations are strictly to cover costs incurred for throwing party; as 
usual monies after expenses will go to Larkin Street Youth Services:
www.larkinstreetyouth.org

Call the Moksha Tribe announce line the day of for updates:

415-564-4768
Web Enabled Cell Phones:  moksha.mp


And when you're finished dancing in the sun with Moksha be sure to attend 
the official "Groove in the Grove" after party:

Fling! And RADI8R proudly present

BETA

The launch party for RADI8R RADIO.

Don't miss the Breaks/house/techno/dnb/progressive/ambient/electro 
extravaganza provided by our friends:

Chel-C Faith
Drop
Emergent

Mark Martini
Mediaboy
Unagi
VTG

8pm-late night
Free before 10:30, $5 after
142 Taylor between Eddy & Turk
<http://www.radi8r.com/>www.radi8r.com


Looking forward to seeing all of you on the dance floor. Been awhile.

Much love,

Apollo for Moksha Tribe

money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

> Jackal and Hyde - Live (Hallucination/Scheme Addict Records) West Palm Be=

> -special visuals provided
>=20
> Jackal & Hyde have been called "the purveyors of the hardcore-electro
> sound" (electro-core), a combination of industrial laden electro
> beats, and psychotic keys. Jackal & Hyde was formed in 1998 by
> partners Scott Weiser, and Todd Walker in an effort to combine a
> harder edge sound with the dancefloor sensibility of Electro or
> "Techno-Bass". Besides their original work, Jackal & Hyde's sound has
> been requested for multiple remix productions including Kid Rock, Love
> & Rockets, and Biochip C. Scott Weiser, who is most recognized for his
> work in I.B.M. (Industrial Bass Machine), and the duo Dynamix II, who
> have written such dancefloor classics as "Give The DJ A Break" and
> "Feel The Bass", has been writing and producing dance music for over a
> decade. Scott's influences range anywhere from classic Industrial to
> Classical, while partner Todd Walker's influences come from Miami
> Ghetto Bass and Industrial Dance. As Jackal & Hyde, Scott and Todd
> push the boundaries of dance music and set the standards for the new
> school of electro.
>=20
> J-Break (Cyberian Knights/Afterdark Records) Tampa, FL
>=20
> J-Break has been rocking the decks all across North America and
> Europe, playing his signature style of breaks and electro. After his
> debut mix cd, "Bio:Mechanik" on Subculture Records, Jackal & J-Break
> founded the electro label, Cyberian Knights Recordings, to release
> "This is the Sound of Underground," as heard on the Baby Anne "Mixed
> Live: Las Vegas" mixed compilation on Moonshine. J-Break has done
> numerous studio collaborations with international renown artists
> Infiniti, Fixx, Johnny Cage, and Josef Plante, to name a few. Be on
> the lookout for J-Break this fall as he hits the road for his
> "Barcelona, Spain" CD Release Tour.
>=20

Subject: [sfraves] genre status

So whats the status of...

D&B - Was popular for several years, then decline, now barely heard
of?

Breaks - Why do I go to some parties and all they seem to play is
breaks? 

Techno - Carried things for a while, my best love, then turned all
metallic and repetitious, producers deciding to delete all melody
lines. Or was that techno? Someone tells me that what I really liked
was tribal trance...

House - Played anywhere besides Sunset parties? At least crowds
still dance to it nowdays.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] genre status

Finding that sound that sunset and wicked spun back in the days til
now can be a little more evasive than the "pop" version of house that
has been sweeping SF the last couple of years...  I still love
intelligent DnB which only seems to exist in SF when LTJ comes to
town, which is a total shame that a lot of SF DnB around here ceases
to embrace its roots from jazz nowdays...   There's still plenty of
deep techno with deep grooving basslines and melodic synth lines and
intelligent appregiator riffs... just doesn't seem to be in SF... or
quite rare that it is.  I saw Ken IIshi recently at 1015 expecting to
hear some of his deeper stuff, but he was just playing full on banging
techno house the majority of his set.

On 6/24/05, Sean Casey <sean@cloudfactory.org> wrote:
> So whats the status of...

> D&B - Was popular for several years, then decline, now barely heard
> of?
>=20
> Breaks - Why do I go to some parties and all they seem to play is
> breaks?
>=20
> Techno - Carried things for a while, my best love, then turned all
> metallic and repetitious, producers deciding to delete all melody
> lines. Or was that techno? Someone tells me that what I really liked
> was tribal trance...
>=20
> House - Played anywhere besides Sunset parties? At least crowds
> still dance to it nowdays.

Content-Type: multipart/alternative;

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Chet Helms, RIP

--=====================_501687==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Chet Helms, a towering figure in the 1960s Bay Area music scene who brought
Janis Joplin to San Francisco and ran the Avalon Ballroom during the Summer of
Love, died early Saturday after suffering a stroke last week.  He was 62.

"Chet didn't really care about money. The music always came first.",
Barry Melton.

He also helped stage free concerts and "Human Be-ins" at Golden Gate Park that
became the backdrop for what became known as San Francisco's Summer of Love in
1967 at the height of anti-Vietnam War sentiment.   His last free concert was
the 1997, 30 year Summer of Love anniversary, which drew 30,000 people to
Golden Gate Park for over 11 hours of free music.

   http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2005/06/26/HELMS.TMP

   http://www.jambase.com/headsup.asp?storyID=6845





Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_501687==.ALT--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] genre status (D&B)

Cool, I do as well, true that it's hard to find a
booking for atmospheric though b/c it's such a niche
music. Promoters rarely think to book it for warmup or
comedown sets (let alone headliner sets) so it's often
just hard hard hard all night.

I do play some of what I would call nu atmospheric or
techmospheric, the new wave of D&B rooted in the Good
Looking sound but more dancefloor oriented. Check out
our free night "Still Doin' It", first Saturdays @ Anu
Bar, 43 Sixth Street btw Market & Mission.  I post
lineups to http://FaultlineDnB.com

For SF D&B at large the only comprehensive event
listings are here:
http://groundscore.net/board/viewforum.php?f=5

The usual suspects are
- Phuturo, every Tuesday @ UndergroundSF
- Compression, every Sunday @ Cellar
- ELEV8, every Wednesday @ 2700 16th St
- Rhythm Method, 2nd Saturdays @ Shadow Lounge
- Silent, 3rd Saturdays @ Il Pirata
- Anthem, 3rd Fridays @ Sublounge

peaz

Dave

To: dj m <djm_freebeats@yahoo.com>

In-Reply-To: <20050626200002.16302.qmail@web52602.mail.yahoo.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Disposition: inline
References: <BAY103-F99E56203F9C563BA700A285EF0@phx.gbl>
	 <20050626200002.16302.qmail@web52602.mail.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] genre status (D&B)

I used to spin jungle and people thought of me as a dolphin DJ because
I owned a few dolphin records. pigeonholing. bleah. like that post
about why do breaks parties only feature breaks. the weird thing about
atmo jungle is that in England, it's the stuff for the "sophisticated"
bars, i.e., expensive drinks, expensive shoes, armani, martinis, that
kind of vibe. I remember telling some girls I had stopped buying atmo
jungle and was only buying breaks and they all sighed like "nooo1!!!!"
when I said it. the market for that shit exists, but relegating it to
the chillroom or to atmo-jungle-only nights is totally unsuccessful.
it would make more sense to do parties with atmo jungle and deep
house, at bars where they can serve up lime green martinis (like they
have at Amber India in SJ) alongside fine dining style appetizers.
then work up to prog by the end of the night and send them home at 1am
to drive their Porsches drunkenly back to the Oakland Hills. ^_^ :P

seriously, if you're looking to get booked as an atmo-jungle DJ, look
to the deep house parties. for a sunrise sound on E, there is NOTHING
better than dolphin jungle, but it's so different from the loud brash
jungle sound that most jungle promoters are more likely to book a
hip-hop DJ or a breaks DJ before a dolphin jungle DJ. the vibe is just
completely different. deep house promoters, however, are already
booking the same music, just at a different tempo. (if you get what
I'm saying.)


On 6/26/05, dj m <djm_freebeats@yahoo.com> wrote:

Subject: Re: [sfraves] genre status (D&B)

I'd argue against that. Some of the bigger "raves" I have been to have 
featured acts like Bukem, Makoto, Marcus Intallex (who can serve up the 
jazzy stuff quite well), High Contrast & others. It doesn't need to be 
quarantined to hoity toity cocktail bars, or deep house nights - it can just 
as easily fit in as a warm up or cool down act at a big party in a chill 
room, or even if placed properly in a lineup - in a main room.

It surprises me for how mature age-wise the SF scene is, how many people 
need pounding beats to sate their musical appetites. Doesn't anyone ever 
just wanna get a nice, soulful swerve on?

*shrug*


Marc(O)
*THWAP!*//Moksha Tribe
DC/MD/VA/CA



>From: Giles Soundwave <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
>Reply-To: Giles Soundwave <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
>To: dj m <djm_freebeats@yahoo.com>
>CC: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] genre status (D&B)
>Date: Sun, 26 Jun 2005 15:03:40 -0700
>
>I used to spin jungle and people thought of me as a dolphin DJ because
>I owned a few dolphin records. pigeonholing. bleah. like that post
>about why do breaks parties only feature breaks. the weird thing about
>atmo jungle is that in England, it's the stuff for the "sophisticated"
>bars, i.e., expensive drinks, expensive shoes, armani, martinis, that
>kind of vibe. I remember telling some girls I had stopped buying atmo
>jungle and was only buying breaks and they all sighed like "nooo1!!!!"
>when I said it. the market for that shit exists, but relegating it to
>the chillroom or to atmo-jungle-only nights is totally unsuccessful.
>it would make more sense to do parties with atmo jungle and deep
>house, at bars where they can serve up lime green martinis (like they
>have at Amber India in SJ) alongside fine dining style appetizers.
>then work up to prog by the end of the night and send them home at 1am
>to drive their Porsches drunkenly back to the Oakland Hills. ^_^ :P
>
>seriously, if you're looking to get booked as an atmo-jungle DJ, look
>to the deep house parties. for a sunrise sound on E, there is NOTHING
>better than dolphin jungle, but it's so different from the loud brash
>jungle sound that most jungle promoters are more likely to book a
>hip-hop DJ or a breaks DJ before a dolphin jungle DJ. the vibe is just
>completely different. deep house promoters, however, are already
>booking the same music, just at a different tempo. (if you get what
>I'm saying.)
>
>

From sfraves-return-122232-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon Jun 27 01:18:30 2005

Message-Id: <6.2.1.2.2.20050626172143.02aba948@mail.speakeasy.org>
X-Mailer: QUALCOMM Windows Eudora Version 6.2.1.2

From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
In-Reply-To: <20050625055833.GG29566@cloudfactory.org>

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_23927234==.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] And while I'm at it, who throws gigs where
  people...

--=====================_23927234==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

At 10:58 PM 6/24/2005, Sean Casey wrote:
>And who throws gigs nowdays where you see crowds consistently
>dancing their booties off like mad? I'm super old school and my
>old tribes, unfortunately, have pretty much cronyied out on the DJs
>until it's crowds *sometimes* dancing and half-time clearing the
>floor.

The old house events in this town used to be like that.  I could depend on 
Come-Unity and Wicked to provide my fix of communal dance with a bit 'o 
transformative experience here and there.  Wow, when was the last time you 
heard someone talk about TAZ?  Met many folks lately who have experienced 
ecstasy (and I don't mean the drug but the experience of the other)?  Used 
to run into them all the time at "nightlife" parties.  One look in the eyes 
and you knew you had a brother/sister.  The experience of ecstasy was an 
important goal for me and the dancers and djs I used to know.  Why go out 
to dance now?

But I'm not answering your question in a linear fashion, am I? :-)  IMHO 
community facilitates good dancing.  The old house community -- and that it 
truly was -- came from the same place:  full moon raves; shared experience; 
and, importantly (and one might add remarkably) shared values.  Same with 
the old gay community.  Oppression and then death and dying builds lots of 
empathy;  respect for life;  movement from the soul outward to the other. 
To find the Other, one must be interested in the other.  More 
self-involvement these days than in the past.  A room full of Me is a 
mess.  So house has become for many a lounge act and Pride a rather boring 
parade of consumer products and sexuality.  Commodities.  People, it seems, 
become commodities too.  Consume My abs;  look at My tits;  want to hear My 
music?  Boring, boring, boring.  The antithesis of ecstasy.  (Interesting 
this thread moved rapidly to individual DJ gigs..or lack of.)

Some say go to Green Gorilla parties for house and transcendence.  Don't 
feel it.  Adnan's Forward shows promise. The psytrance community still has 
it going on -- and it is really a community.  Then there is the Burning Man 
crowd representin' at "Get Freaky," Adam Ohana's popular breaks-oriented 
party.  It was Adam, I think, who popularized breaks in SF and made the 
genre the soup du jour of the BMers.  But that, in Adam's mind, is growing 
tired (as is BM, but one can be stoned to death literally in this town 
speaking ill of the burners.  Truly, there was one Woodstock in 
'69.  Woodstock every year -- sad.)  "Get Freaky" is due for an 
overhall:  "as that was the last get Freaky of the year (BM caledar that 
is).  I feel like we have taken get freaky as far as we can take it, and I 
feel the need to change it up a bit. especially with main room sound making 
it even more diverse, the last few times it was mostly banging breaks.. and 
i feel that it would be nice if the music was way more varied. I get 
nervous because these parties tend to be so high budget, and its tricky 
when you bring new people out that most people aren't clued on to yet. but 
i feel the need to change it up a bit more. "  (Adam on Tribenet)

Hmmm.  BM time.  I've been, and almost everyone I know goes.  What I would 
like to see these days is SF transformed with BM energy all year long like 
it was before folks locked themselves into warehouses putting all their 
love, energy and creativity into Black Rock.

And not everyone can be part of that community.  The organizers say African 
Americans are woefully underrepresented because they "...don't like 
camping."  SF best kept secret is its white bread orientation  Even the 
once oppressed gay community here prefers Wonder Bread.  Liberal 
indeed.  As for camping, I do it to get away from urban life; distraction; 
eternal background noise.  Mystery to me why all kinds of people create 
urban life in the wilds.

Community.  I personally find community at, of all places, hip hop parties 
these days.  Not the pop hop variety like lounge house.  Lots of amazing 
hip hop talent in the Bay.  More so than any other genre.  At parties the 
peeps are REALLY into the music and they dance.  Lots of the local 
performers are involved in community work and action.  Giving back.  Focus 
on the other.  It works for me.  Time now to resurrect and reformat 
house.  Change some paradigms.  Open some doors.  Create serendipity again 
rather than comfortable expectation fulfillment.  Bring back ecstasy.

Love,

Apollo





Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

The Moksha Tribe collective thanks all of you who shared the afternoon with 
us yesterday at "Groove in the Grove."

positive vibes and presence really made the day perfect.

way from Fresno.  Wouldn't be a Moksha party without SWAT.

Looking forward to bring you another Moksha event soon!!!

Much love,

Subject: [sfraves] BSP:  Forward July 1st

--=====================_31396078==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Forward
Friday July 1st
1015 Folsom  San Francisco
For discount list - <http://www.forwardsf.com>www.forwardsf.com

Forward its pleased to bring you one the house music legends, Doc Martin, 
blessings us with a 3 hour set in one of the best Sound Systems in the US.
The Main room of 1015 Folsom will be all about some Jackin' Beats to move 
our feet's.
Doc's live sets bring many styles of music as well as people together. In 
this age of specialized formats among DJ's and producers, what sets Martin 
apart from his peers is his ability to spin everything from deep house, 
acid, funk, tribal, and classics in a set, while having it all make sense.

SF vinyl genius Jeno will be getting the night started for, and closing the 
night we got one of the best Frisco's Producer and DJ that been 
representing us worldwide, Mr. Hector Moralez from Fries & Bridges.

In the front Room a Tag Team Session will be in full effect wit M3 & Galen, 
Sammy D. & Nikola, Adnan & Rebecca and Adam Ohana will get it all started

Main Room:
Doc Martin (Sublevel) 3hr Set
Jeno (Wicked / Woosh!)
Hector Moralez (Fries & Bridges  Minority Music  Robsoul Recordings)

Front Room Tag Team Session:
M3 & Galen (Green Gorilla / Pacific Sound)
Sammy D & Nikola (Classic UK / SWAT)
Adnan & Rebecca (Forward / Get Underground)
Adam Ohana (Get Freaky)

For discount list go to <http://www.forwardsf.com>www.forwardsf.com

Subject: Re: [sfraves] genre status (D&B)

if you can pull it off, more power to you. realistically, though,
there's really only one dolphin DJ who spins at jungle events locally,
and that's Method One. he's good but Mike Bee was better. Mike Bee
doesn't spin out any more, despite producing probably the best jungle
record that ever came out of San Francisco. certainly the best before
Gridlock.

I'm not saying it can't be done, I'm just saying that realistically in
terms of who gets booked where, in the SF scene, this is what I've
observed. I don't go out a lot these days myself but way back when I
was pretty involved. during that time -- about five years going out
every weekend -- I only heard a jungle DJ spinning atmo at a large
event twice. one time was when I went to see LTJ Bukem. the other time
was at a psytrance party. (in the back room.)

all I'm really saying is that the SF jungle scene is (or at least was)
centered around one particular sound, and that if you want to spin a
different sound, the jungle scene shouldn't be the only place you look
for bookings. I don't really see any point in arguing with that. I
mean it's obviously true. it's like arguing about gravity.

ust

> Borealis2000News
> Spectacular Planetary Alignment
> 
> Watch the sky during the hour after sunset on June
> 25-27: Venus, Mercury and Saturn align just above
> the western horizon. The planets gather for a rare
> conjunction and form an impressively tight grouping
> in the western sky (triangle-shaped). Venus is the
> first planet to appear within the glow of the
> setting sun.
