Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_685828==.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] File-Sharing Networks Can Be Held Liable, Court Rules

--=====================_685828==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

June 27, 2005


File-Sharing Networks Can Be Held Liable, Court Rules

By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

Internet file-sharing services will be held responsible if they intend for 
their customers to use software primarily to swap songs and movies 
illegally, the Supreme Court ruled Monday, rejecting warnings that the 
lawsuits will stunt growth of cool tech gadgets such as the next iPod.

The unanimous decision sends the case back to lower court, which had ruled 
in favor of file-sharing services Grokster Ltd. and StreamCast Networks 
Inc. on the grounds that the companies couldn't be sued. The justices said 
there was enough evidence of unlawful intent for the case to go to trial.

File-sharing services shouldn't get a free pass on bad behavior, justices 
said.

"We hold that one who distributes a device with the object of promoting its 
use to infringe copyright, as shown by the clear expression or other 
affirmative steps taken to foster infringement, is liable for the resulting 
acts of infringement by third parties," Justice David H. Souter wrote for 
the court.

At issue was whether the file-sharing services should be held liable even 
if they have no direct control over what millions of online users are doing 
with the software they provide for free. As much as 90 percent of songs and 
movies copied on the file-sharing networks are downloaded illegally, 
according to music industry filings.

The entertainment industry said it needed protection against the billions 
of dollars in revenue they lose to illegal swapping. Consumer groups 
worried that expanded liability will stifle the technology revolution of 
the last two decades that brought video cassette recorders, MP3 players and 
Apple's iPod.

Companies will have to pay music and movie artists for up to billions in 
losses if they are found to have promoted illegal downloading.

Two lower courts previously sided with Grokster without holding a trial. 
They each based their decisions on the 1984 Supreme Court ruling that Sony 
Corp. could not be sued over consumers who used its VCRs to make illegal 
copies of movies.

The lower courts reasoned that, like VCRs, the file-sharing software can be 
used for "substantial" legal purposes, such as giving away free songs, free 
software or government documents. They also said the file-sharing services 
were not legally responsible because they don't have central servers 
pointing users to copyright material.

But in Monday's ruling, Souter said lower courts could find the 
file-sharing services responsible by examining factors such as how 
companies marketed the product or whether they took easily available steps 
to reduce infringing uses.

"There is substantial evidence in MGM's favor on all elements of 
inducement," Souter wrote.

In the closely watched case, supporting the effort to sue the companies 
were dozens of entertainment industry companies, including musicians Don 
Henley, Sheryl Crow and the Dixie Chicks, as well as attorneys general in 
40 states.

About 20 independent recording artists, including musician and producer 
Brian Eno, rockers Heart and rapper-activist Chuck D, supported the 
file-sharing technology to allow for greater distribution of their works.

Monday's ruling gives the entertainment industry another legal option to 
the more costly and less popular route of going directly after millions of 
online file-swappers believed to distribute songs and movies illegally.

It's unclear how much the decision will actually deter the widespread 
problem of piracy since software programs created abroad won't be subject 
to the tougher U.S. copyright laws. Still, analysts say the court's stern 
rebuke should provide a boost to many file-sharing services that offer 
legal downloading for a fee.

Industry observers have said a ruling against Grokster could also prompt 
stiffer enforcement from European regulators, who were watching the case 
for guidance on tackling copyright questions in their countries.

Recording companies in the United States have already sued thousands of 
individual users; at least 600 of the cases were eventually settled for 
roughly $3,000 each.

The case is Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Studios v. Grokster, 04-480.

http://www.nytimes.com/2005/06/27/technology/27cnd-grokster.html?pagewanted=print



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

> locally,

> Mike Bee
> doesn't spin out any more, despite producing probably the
> best jungle
> record that ever came out of San Francisco. certainly the
> best before
> Gridlock.
> 
> I'm not saying it can't be done, I'm just saying that
> realistically in
> terms of who gets booked where, in the SF scene, this is what
> I've

> when I
> was pretty involved. during that time -- about five years
> going out
> every weekend -- I only heard a jungle DJ spinning atmo at a
> large
> event twice. one time was when I went to see LTJ Bukem. the
> other time
> was at a psytrance party. (in the back room.)
>

> least was)
> centered around one particular sound, and that if you want to
> spin a
> different sound, the jungle scene shouldn't be the only place
> you look

Sometimes it just takes a few stubborn people like me to tweak things a bit 
in order for change (albeit small ammounts of change) to occur.

It's funny - I notice people always seem to bitch about not liking funky 
(NOT to be confused with Florida - ew) breaks, and prefer the hard styles of 
jungle to atmospheric, etc. etc. - but when they hear it playing out, get 
all into it. It's like they're embarassed to admit they like something that 
might not be "cool" or something.

Not saying that to YOU Giles - just in general.

>record that ever came out of San Francisco. certainly the best before
>Gridlock.
>
>I'm not saying it can't be done, I'm just saying that realistically in
>terms of who gets booked where, in the SF scene, this is what I've
>observed. I don't go out a lot these days myself but way back when I
>was pretty involved. during that time -- about five years going out
>every weekend -- I only heard a jungle DJ spinning atmo at a large
>event twice. one time was when I went to see LTJ Bukem. the other time
>was at a psytrance party. (in the back room.)
>
>all I'm really saying is that the SF jungle scene is (or at least was)
>centered around one particular sound, and that if you want to spin a
>different sound, the jungle scene shouldn't be the only place you look
>for bookings. I don't really see any point in arguing with that. I
>mean it's obviously true. it's like arguing about gravity.

> > >kind of vibe. I remember telling some girls I had stopped buying atmo
> > >jungle and was only buying breaks and they all sighed like "nooo1!!!!"

> > >better than dolphin jungle, but it's so different from the loud brash
> > >jungle sound that most jungle promoters are more likely to book a
> > >hip-hop DJ or a breaks DJ before a dolphin jungle DJ. the vibe is just
> > >completely different. deep house promoters, however, are already
> > >booking the same music, just at a different tempo. (if you get what

Subject: [sfraves] (BSP) Sun July 3rd :: Deep Impact

Deep Impact, a NASA Discovery Mission, is the first space mission to
probe beneath the surface of a comet and reveal the secrets of its
interior. The hyper-speed impact between space-borne iceberg and
copper-fortified probe is scheduled for approximately 1:52 a.m. EDT on
Independence Day (10:52 p.m. PDT on July 3). The potentially spectacular
collision will be observed by the Deep Impact spacecraft, and ground and
space-based observatories.
http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/deepimpact/main/

:: Sunday July 3rd from Noon - 8pm ::
Cannabass is back with another day party on Treasure Island, to bring
you a day of Chicago House, Dirty House, Breaks, Drum & Bass, Ragga,
Breakcore and Latin Downtempo

Andrew Phelan (djandrewphelan.com)
Bam (evilbreaks)
Brian Walls (ac/stylus)
Happy (cannabass)
Lewt (cannabass)
Sheztek (moksha tribe)
Cutthroat (l.a.b crew)
Simas

The park has bbq grills and picnic tables so bring shit to cook up and
drink up, but please be respectful of the space so that we can continue
to use it.

Directions:
 From the Bay Bridge:
Hillcrest Rd becomes Treasure Island Rd
Treasure Island Rd becomes Avenue Palms
Right on California
Left on Avenue H
If you hit houses, you went too far on H
It's on the corner of H and 9th
(We're behind the soccer field)
By Bus: Take the 108 to Avenue H and 9th St

Bushwhacka! are in town.

> >doesn't spin out any more, despite producing probably the best jungle
> >record that ever came out of San Francisco. certainly the best before
> >Gridlock.
> >
> >I'm not saying it can't be done, I'm just saying that realistically in
> >terms of who gets booked where, in the SF scene, this is what I've
> >observed. I don't go out a lot these days myself but way back when I
> >was pretty involved. during that time -- about five years going out
> >every weekend -- I only heard a jungle DJ spinning atmo at a large
> >event twice. one time was when I went to see LTJ Bukem. the other time
> >was at a psytrance party. (in the back room.)
> >
> >all I'm really saying is that the SF jungle scene is (or at least was)
> >centered around one particular sound, and that if you want to spin a
> >different sound, the jungle scene shouldn't be the only place you look
> >for bookings. I don't really see any point in arguing with that. I
> >mean it's obviously true. it's like arguing about gravity.
> >

> > > >atmo jungle is that in England, it's the stuff for the "sophisticate=
d"
> > > >bars, i.e., expensive drinks, expensive shoes, armani, martinis, tha=
t
> > > >kind of vibe. I remember telling some girls I had stopped buying atm=

> > > >jungle and was only buying breaks and they all sighed like "nooo1!!!=

> > > >when I said it. the market for that shit exists, but relegating it t=

> > > >the chillroom or to atmo-jungle-only nights is totally unsuccessful.
> > > >it would make more sense to do parties with atmo jungle and deep
> > > >house, at bars where they can serve up lime green martinis (like the=
y
> > > >have at Amber India in SJ) alongside fine dining style appetizers.
> > > >then work up to prog by the end of the night and send them home at 1=
am
> > > >to drive their Porsches drunkenly back to the Oakland Hills. ^_^ :P
> > > >
> > > >seriously, if you're looking to get booked as an atmo-jungle DJ, loo=
k
> > > >to the deep house parties. for a sunrise sound on E, there is NOTHIN=
G
> > > >better than dolphin jungle, but it's so different from the loud bras=
h
> > > >jungle sound that most jungle promoters are more likely to book a
> > > >hip-hop DJ or a breaks DJ before a dolphin jungle DJ. the vibe is ju=
st
> > > >completely different. deep house promoters, however, are already
> > > >booking the same music, just at a different tempo. (if you get what
> > > >I'm saying.)
> > > >

Subject: [sfraves] WR: Wow... Eastbay, Southbay, The City

OK.. so Friday night I went 2 Sunscience 4 their 2 year shindig... 1 room
was all Jungle, YUM, another room was all Breaks, YUM, then another room
had GRIME, YUM, & hip hop & dancehall.... but man... it was so fun...
decorations were Dope, the vibe was Awesome, I mean... it was a totally
diferent vibe @ Noodle Factory considering all the parties I've went 2
there were like candy parties.. so yeah.. it was Sick... I mean.. the
SubScience crew did a so Dope job!!!  I will say DJ Bam's set was my Fave
Breaks set & Soundboy's Jungle set was my Fave!  Ya know.. IU also have 2
say, I ran in2 sooooooooo many people there who I ain't seen in 4ever daze
man.. so Dope!!  Loved it!!!  SubScience, YUM!!!

I guess 1/2 way after the party was over, I hitched a ride 2 1015 & caught
Red Stick Man spinning a really eclectic set of everything from Breaks,
ambient, down tempo, & jungle music... KJ was in the main room spinning
this wicked Psy Trance.. i dunno what was going on up stair or who was
there spining, but i was up there @ 1 point & there was Salsa House
Spinning...

LoL... Saturday was fun.... got up early & made it 2 SunyVale 4 the Moksha
Tribe Day Party.. it was Dope... Got there 4 the Cubik Y Origami live PA
thingie.. Oh gosh man.. all the DJs there were Sick... guest DJ Bam was
Awesome!!  The Jungle @ the end was Awesome... all the House in between &
the breaks set ala the Moksha DJs!!  YAY!!  So Fun!

After that, & a lil' rest, I went 2 111 Minna 4 Drive.. Wow.. I mean.. I
just wanted 2 like say HI 2 a few people there... but it was fun.. Good
Vibe & from what i heard, it got paaaaaacked in there!  But it was fun!!

Then i went 2 Anu 4 my Homie Stephan's House Monthlie there... it was fun!!

Then i went 2 the Radi8tor shindig BETA... WOW... so Dope!  I mean.. OK..
there was a breaks set ala Unagi, there was a set that was like psycadelic
house-ie kinda music that ended w/ strait up bangin' Techno, YUM... there
was another breaks set, a house set... most these Dj mixed w/ computers,
CDs, live PA, it was fun!!!

A few highlights of the night, hung out w/ People I Love, met Groovy new
people, hmm, actually wait, i'll make a new post about Charles, oh oh oh..
I hung out w/ Hyde from Jakal & Hyde.. it was Dope, him & I talked about
alot of Stuff 2 talk about.. seriously.. it was Awesome!!

Byut yeah man.. It was fun... the radi8tor shindig was Dope!!  I mean.. it
was weird being back @ that place agin, the space, but it was fun!!  LoL..
more fun than I think i was allowed 2 have.. or Charles was!

OK.. that was my weekend!  Hope y'all had a Dope weekend also!
-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> ObY {8O)

Subject: [sfraves] So yeah... Charles from Saturday night!

I was sooooooooooooo tired on Say night... I mean... really tired, it was
hmmmm... tiring!  When I was @ RADI8TOR.. I was still even more tired & I
dunno.. i need something 2 keep me up... that's when I started introducing
myself as Charles!  LoL.... yeah.. Charles was a fun guy... & like 1/2 the
people @ Drum Machine only knew me as Charles which was fun!  LoL... yeah
man.... LoL...

As far as we developed his character, Charles is an Aboriginee from
Tazmania who moved here 2 Bay Area... but as far as i know... Charles was
onlyhere on sayurday night & who knows when he'll be around again... 
hmmm.. but yeah.. it was just fun havin' Charles around 'cause Charles
kept me awake until I finally got home @ 8AM Sunday Morning!!  I wish
y'all gotta meet charles, he was fun, but iwas told he was kinda raunchy
around people.. hmmm.. interesting!

Hyde suggested that Maximill (instead of Charles) should be @ Evil Breaks
on Sunday & I wish he was... but well... tired, rest, no ride... I Love U
EB & I'm sorry i couldn't make it!!!

Subject: Re: [sfraves] genre status (D&B)

Well no doubt those guys were the dons of "dolphin"
some years ago along with the rest of True Intent and
Forward Thought and the likes. But these days Mike and
M1 are on pretty different tips as DJs, doing great
things but not playing atmos unless they're booked for
an old skool night.  Mikebee plays wicked Tech House
and Broken Beat, in fact he's playing at our new night
"Fahrenheit 111" @ Minna this Friday night.

Anyway these days I would venture to say myself, Nemo,
Fife and Kuze are possibly the only active D&B DJs in
town capable of solid deep-crated atmos sets and who
consistently buy and play new mellow releases. If
anyone wants to try a small crossover night with deep
house or whatever please hit me up, it's a cool idea.

MIME-Version: 1.0

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] another question:  best turnaround

On Tue, 28 Jun 2005, Deepfog wrote:

> so this time:  what was the party where you thought for sure things were
> going to go bad, or thought it was going to get busted, or almost did get
> busted, or whatever, and it turned out to be a really great party instead?

This story is very close to my heart.

1996?, halloween, FnF, truckyard, Oakland, (1 mile from Homebase). At this 
point in my life I've been partying for 1.5 years, 6 mos. in the UG scene. 
I came up quick w/ Harmony productions helping throw parties as a faithful 
gruntman, and began to expand my horizons w/ the FnF & Cloudfactory crews.

I knew of and have been to a few UG FnF parties which have always been the 
completely mind-blowing. And since Harmony and FnF were somewhat connected 
(at the time), I was entrusted with being the courier for the space permit 
up to Oakland.

I arrived at the space during setup, watched the magic unfold by an army 
of enthusiastic ravers in this killer warehouse location. Massive 
decorations, intelligent lighting, multi-screen visuals, big sound, and 
lots of extra comfort accommodations. Easily a $25-30 party by today's 
standards. This one cost $5.

This is going to be one hell of a party =)

Everything started out like it was supposed to. People started arriving en 
masse and getting down! Unfortunately @ ~12am cops come, question the 
promoter, who shows the permit(?) I couriered up and then after heated 
negotiations, still shuts the party down. um..okay.

When word came down, the same busy bees that set everything up, began to 
take everything down, in earnest. Also I see a dozen people feverishly on 
their cell phones.

"What just happened?" I ask Greg (Harmony dude). He says, "We got shut 
down, we're moving".

"MOVING? WHERE??!?!" I replied. Thinking to myself, it took all freakin 
day to set this shit up, it is now 12:30am, where the hell do you think 
you're moving and how are going to move all this shit?!!? I think this 
party is bunk now.

They were off their rocker, talking nonsense, and I want to party Dammit!

Conveniently, Funky Tekno Tribe's Halloween Massive was going off at 
Homebase, down the street. I told Greg I had to bounce and call me if 
there was any new info.

Headed to Homebase, paid my $25 bucks, hung out w/ a bunch of my other 
friends, massive-style, it was fun. At about 4am my phone rings, I check 
my voicemail, Greg calls with directions to the new FnF location.

huh???, you have got to be shitting me! So I say my goodbyes, hop in my 
car, and head down to Derek's warehouse on the peninsula (never been there).

I arrive, just as it begins to break daylight. I enter the warehouse, and 
find, THE SAME FUCKING FnF PARTY I left hours ago. Totally off the hook, 
sound, decorations, lighting all moved (granted on a slighty smaller 
scale), and alot of the same people still there, it was a full blown 
rave going off, possibly better than that Homebase one I just left. I let 
go and had a blast.

In the end, that was my most profound early lesson in the perseverance of 
the UG community. They freaking moved an entire party, at a moment's 
notice, because they had the collective will to make it happen. And I 
didn't have faith, and bailed. In my mind, I failed.

Another side of the rave scene became very clear to me then. And I 
promised myself that night that I would never doubt like that again.

And the cowboys rode off into the sunset ;-)

Thanks for listening, and sorry for being wordy or melodramtic. But like I 
said, this story is and remains close to my heart =)

-terry

P.S. If I can throw a shameless plug, (and I'm sure Sean Casey will 
correct me if I'm wrong), Greg Harrison (writer and director of 'Groove') 
was at that party (I learned many years later), and portions of 
that party were thrown into the movie script.

It's not all fiction =)

JENO'S "NOISE FROM THE VOID" TONIGHT AND EVERY TUESDAY


"Noise from the void" will be a two hour live broadcast from my home 
studio. I'll be sharing treasures from the vaults of my record collection. 
Oddities, rarities, old and new. Everything from dub to goth with a 
sprinkling of dance tracks..

I'll be broadcasting every Tuesday - LIVE - 9-11-ish PST, and the show may 
not be archived, so please tune in as it happens or miss out..!!

For more info go to http://www.djjeno.com/board/viewforum.php?f=6 and to 
tune in live go to http://www.90hz.org for instructions..



jeno..

money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Alumni 3 Fri. 7/22

The first one was SICK...i loved hearing all the ol skool tracks.  The
highlight of the night was when (i can't remember who was spinning at
the time) threw down Brass Disc, by DJ Purdee i think (something like
that)

BEST BREAKBEAT TRACK EVER!!!!!!!

I felt a little wet and sticky down below when that build up came
crashing down on me (as a side note on those same lines, in my never
ending quest for more porn, i came across a short 3 or 4 minute sex
sequence that had that track layered over it, and it was synchronized
with the build-up, Porn + Awesome Dance Tracks =3D Mega Orgasm).  I've
been wanting that track for so long, but i aint about to dump $80 on
Gemm for a copy, at least not during this financially fucked place i
am right now.

I love the idea of having these parties where the DJ's play stuff that
probably hasn't been played out in years and years.  The music back
then was so much better, i know i'll catch some flak for saying that,
but i swear it's true.  Just need to get Danny Teneglia to come out
and spin an ol skool tribal set, like his Mix This Pussy CD.  That
would be orgasmic.

--=20
Chester Copperpot

"Goonies never say die!"
"Meth Monsters are my Anti-Drug"
"I feel like I'm taking crazy pills"

Terry Estioko <terry@saturn5.com> said...

> P.S. If I can throw a shameless plug, (and I'm sure Sean Casey will 
> correct me if I'm wrong), Greg Harrison (writer and director of 'Groove') 
> was at that party (I learned many years later), and portions of 
> that party were thrown into the movie script.
> 
> It's not all fiction =)

I'm not sure if Greg H. was at that one, but he definitely used FnF
as his party model for the movie.

!!!EXCEPT!!!

FNF DOES NOT LEAVE A SITE, RENEGADE OR NO, WITH TRASH ALL OVER THE
FLOOR!!!!!!!!!!!! MAJOR BOO BOO GREG!!!!!

Neither does UW, Rhythmethod, Mad Hatter, Cloudfactory, or any of
the other FnF affiliated groups. We've always left a site cleaner
than we found it, however long it takes (sometimes days), and
otherwise karmically enhanced ;).

There is a "making of groove" DVD that is pretty cool. I don't know
where to get it though. I think I saw it over at Brian's. If you
liked Groove, it's worth finding and getting.

Sean

we didn't know & I was introducing myself as her 2 the new people & I
thought she said "Your name is Charles, not Chell-C" & like ever since
that moment early on in the party, I used that name... although she claims
she never said that & I was in some sort of delusional hearing spree
'cause of my lack of sleep....

we were deciding where Charles was from... @ 1st Layla suggested South
Africa... but my boss @ the club was from there originally & I couldn't
use that.. so I decided Tazmania!!  =)

bday party"

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Balls shaving gear

--=====================_2541421==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

PRIVATE GROOMING


Queer Eye for the Straight Guy mainstreamed the metrosexual, but even
the Fab Five couldn't have predicted that promoting daily showers and
Kiehl's would lead to ads for balls-shaving gear. Remington and Philips
have both created ads for their shave-everywhere products. The print
ads are amusing, but Philips' flash animation came straight from my
nightmares.

Continued:
http://blog.stayfreemagazine.org/2005/06/shaving_nads.html





Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_2541421==.ALT--

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

brass disc on... if you want this party jumpin'...
jump. Alright DJ tear up the town. Too many people
standin' around with a frown. Do you wanna gain
ground? Then let the beat pound..."

Subject: [sfraves] so i had this idea for a party

with evil breaks djs playing nu breaks.

and other local djs playing old school breaks, breakbeat hardcore,

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Re: Brass Disc

I found it. and damn, looking thru the stacks
sometimes seems endless, but I have a pretty good
catalogue system so I found it pretty quickly...

The one I have is:

Dupree
"Brass Disk"
A1 Club Version
A2 Radio Version
B1 Bring The Madness Version
B2 Bassapella
*Remixed by Todd Terry for Kaze Productions
*Produced by Funky Felix and Paul Biddle

I'll see what I can do about getting it recorded to
MP3. I can only put it up on MySpace tho. I don't have
a personal site to store it. I'll let you know when
it's done. I can probably get to it tonight.

good times,

-JH

rekkids ;) *SCORE* I'd probably have to loan him half
of his own records back for the set.. haha. **No
fucker, you don't get 'em back. Don't even think about
it ;)

electro, he'd probably rather play that. Doesn't
matter, equally sick as fuck. And besides... that
leaves the classics set to me! :)

two drinks.  one before your set, then another to sip while you're  
playing. don't have any more until after your set.

keep in mind that it's always going to sound worse to you than to  
anyone else listening, so go easy on yourself.  besides, it's your  
first time playing out, so don't expect it to be perfect... but leave  
that option open. :-)

pxd

Subject: Re: [sfraves] First Timer Advice

you know, i asked a similar question before my first gig infront of
people back in April of 2002.  i saved all the responses i got and
just dug through them.  this one from AndyW was particularly
enlightening:

"p.s.  a little dj to dj advice here...  keep those records turning with
the needle in the best grooves you've got... but keep in mind every genre
has a silent meaning in there somewhere between the beats... house means
"I am feeling this, we all feel this... so testify when the bassline comes
back in" and tech house means "I am feeling this but I also think that
techno is cool but not cool enough to go balls out technostylee and
all the shit that would get me from my friends"  and breaks means "this is
the best shit to dance to ever while intoxicated, up yours if you can't
figure it out" and trance means "hi, I suck donkey nuts for muni fare"."


---
and one from Audiotactix:

DO YOU DRiNK?
DO THE GUESTS DRiNK?
GET DRUNK WITH THE GUESTS!
DONT TAKE REQUESTS, <unless you want to hear it>
NO ONE WiLL NOTICE iF YOU ARE MESSiNG UP, <especially if you play jungle or
gabber>
JUST KEEP PLAYING! <stop when the cops show up!>
GO WiTH THE FLOW,
YOU WiLL PiCK UP THE WRONG NEEDLE, <just back it up a few .cm and DROP iT
reach for drink>
DONT WEAR SUNGLASSES,<not even the cool brad pit rockstar type>

AUDiOTACTiX

---
and another nice one from G Sauce:
as far as tips go
just be yourself and don't get nervous.  that is the whole deal right there=
.
it is alot harder to do than it sounds but confidence is really important.

when you are playing on a different system than you are used to understand
that your first couple tracks will be an adjustment period where you get
used to the system.  so stick to a couple records you know pretty well.
That way you can be confident in your skill with those records while you ge=
t
in touch with the soundsystem.

and whatever happens don't get down on yourself.  you have to have the same
mentality that cornerbacks in the nfl have.  That is,  they think no one ca=
n
beat them....and if they do get burned they forget about it. On the next
play they go right back to thinking they are invincible.    You have to
realize that you can mix records well, and if you don't get it right on one
mix you still have to realize that you can mix records well.  Confidence
lets your talents shine.  If you get too nervous it will show and you will
get distracted and you will mix bad.

you can do it!!
---

From: Sean Casey <sean@cloudfactory.org>
To: The Twilight Laser Outpost <sfraves@hyperreal.org>

Mail-Followup-To: The Twilight Laser Outpost <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
References: <20050629191344.99320.qmail@web32401.mail.mud.yahoo.com> <C7ADE4B0-2A9A-4073-9BD3-6EC74020C3BC@earthlink.net>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
In-Reply-To: <C7ADE4B0-2A9A-4073-9BD3-6EC74020C3BC@earthlink.net>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.3.28i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] First Timer Advice

Philip.X.Diaz <st_indigo@earthlink.net> said...
> keep in mind that it's always going to sound worse to you than to  
> anyone else listening, so go easy on yourself.  besides, it's your  
> first time playing out, so don't expect it to be perfect... but leave  
> that option open. :-)
> 
> pxd

Word. It always sounds better to the crowd than to the DJ or
(especially) on the tape. Don't criticize yourself when you hear the
tape, but do use it later to improve your technique. Your measure of
success is a screaming crowd (the ultimate reward) not perfection on
a tape.

My advice:

- You may be nervous now, or when you start, but 60 seconds into it
  you'll be so busy nothing else matters but the music. Trust me on
  this. So go ahead and be nervous if you want, it won't matter at
  all after that first minute. Bank on that.

- There is no substitute for a weapons-grade bag of records.

- The sonics are always going to be different, loud, and confusing
  at an actual party. Have powerful headphones. If you have any
  friends with any big sound (not just monitors) that you can
  practice with, it'll be a huge help in training your ears.

- If you fuck up gloriously, and you will, more than once, smile,
  and keep going! They'll cheer you on! No shit.

- Be into the crowd. Want them to dance like nothing you ever wanted
  in your whole life. It'll show, and baby, they'll dance.

Sean

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

oh yeah... another thing i like to do is line up a nice long track  
for record # 2.

this lets me catch my breath, read the crowd, get a drink,  
familiarize myself with the mixer (you'll do less of this as you play  
out more and learn the different equipment out there), make  
adjustments (ie: DJ Dumbfuck who played before you left all the  
levels in the red, so bring them down nice and slow;  tone arm  
counterweights are set too heavy, etc.).

pxd

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] First Timer Advice

I remember when my boy Funksion was playing his first live performance 
in front of a lot of people (this was years before I did so it was a 
LOOONNNNGGGG time ago). His set was WICKED and when I asked him about it 
he had no idea how good it was. What he told me was, "All I could think 
for the last 90 minutes was... match beats match beats match beats match 
beats...".

I dont think it really matters what you play the first time you play 
out. Just go up there and experience it. If you're playing on a real 
system, there's nothing like the first time. Nothing. When your playing 
a record you played 100 times at home and can't recognize it over the 
monitors you'll know what I mean. Just mix.... The 2nd time you play out 
you can start worrying about reading the dancefloor and programing.

AUDi,
Gavin


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

--- Bam <invibe@gmail.com> wrote:

> you know, i asked a similar question before my first
> gig infront of
> people back in April of 2002.  i saved all the
> responses i got and
> just dug through them.  this one from AndyW was
> particularly
> enlightening:
> 
> "p.s.  a little dj to dj advice here...  keep those
> records turning with
> the needle in the best grooves you've got... but
> keep in mind every genre
> has a silent meaning in there somewhere between the
> beats... house means
> "I am feeling this, we all feel this... so testify
> when the bassline comes
> back in" and tech house means "I am feeling this but
> I also think that
> techno is cool but not cool enough to go balls out
> technostylee and
> all the shit that would get me from my friends"  and
> breaks means "this is
> the best shit to dance to ever while intoxicated, up
> yours if you can't
> figure it out" and trance means "hi, I suck donkey
> nuts for muni fare"."
> 
> 
> ---
> and one from Audiotactix:
> 
> DO YOU DRiNK?
> DO THE GUESTS DRiNK?
> GET DRUNK WITH THE GUESTS!
> DONT TAKE REQUESTS, <unless you want to hear it>
> NO ONE WiLL NOTICE iF YOU ARE MESSiNG UP,
> <especially if you play jungle or
> gabber>
> JUST KEEP PLAYING! <stop when the cops show up!>
> GO WiTH THE FLOW,
> YOU WiLL PiCK UP THE WRONG NEEDLE, <just back it up
> a few .cm and DROP iT
> reach for drink>
> DONT WEAR SUNGLASSES,<not even the cool brad pit
> rockstar type>
> 
> AUDiOTACTiX
> 
> ---
> and another nice one from G Sauce:
> as far as tips go
> just be yourself and don't get nervous.  that is the
> whole deal right there.
> it is alot harder to do than it sounds but
> confidence is really important.
> 
> when you are playing on a different system than you
> are used to understand
> that your first couple tracks will be an adjustment
> period where you get
> used to the system.  so stick to a couple records
> you know pretty well.
> That way you can be confident in your skill with
> those records while you get
> in touch with the soundsystem.
> 
> and whatever happens don't get down on yourself. 
> you have to have the same
> mentality that cornerbacks in the nfl have.  That
> is,  they think no one can
> beat them....and if they do get burned they forget
> about it. On the next
> play they go right back to thinking they are
> invincible.    You have to
> realize that you can mix records well, and if you
> don't get it right on one
> mix you still have to realize that you can mix
> records well.  Confidence
> lets your talents shine.  If you get too nervous it
> will show and you will
> get distracted and you will mix bad.
> 
> you can do it!!
> ---
> 
> On 6/29/05, Peter Rothman <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>
> wrote:
> > So I've recently been invited to DJ
> > quasi-professionally for the first time.  FWIW I'm
> > going to be playing a little SF style funky house
> to
> > open an evening of mostly funky and deep house.
> I'll
> > probably be totally nervous and suck, but in the
> > interest of sucking as little as possible I'm
> seeking
> > your advice.  Any first timer tips or tricks,
> > entertaining or horrifying first timer stories, or
> > simply anything else worthwhile you'd like to
> offer up
> > will be appreciated.
> > 
> > Peace,
> > 
> > Peter

--- "Philip.X.Diaz" <st_indigo@earthlink.net> wrote:

> oh yeah... another thing i like to do is line up a
> nice long track  
> for record # 2.
> 
> this lets me catch my breath, read the crowd, get a
> drink,  
> familiarize myself with the mixer (you'll do less of
> this as you play  
> out more and learn the different equipment out
> there), make  
> adjustments (ie: DJ Dumbfuck who played before you
> left all the  
> levels in the red, so bring them down nice and slow;
>  tone arm  
> counterweights are set too heavy, etc.).
> 
> pxd
> 
>

--- Sean Casey <sean@cloudfactory.org> wrote:

> Philip.X.Diaz <st_indigo@earthlink.net> said...
> > keep in mind that it's always going to sound worse
> to you than to  
> > anyone else listening, so go easy on yourself. 
> besides, it's your  
> > first time playing out, so don't expect it to be
> perfect... but leave  
> > that option open. :-)
> > 
> > pxd
> 
> Word. It always sounds better to the crowd than to
> the DJ or
> (especially) on the tape. Don't criticize yourself
> when you hear the
> tape, but do use it later to improve your technique.
> Your measure of
> success is a screaming crowd (the ultimate reward)
> not perfection on
> a tape.
> 
> My advice:
> 
> - You may be nervous now, or when you start, but 60
> seconds into it
>   you'll be so busy nothing else matters but the
> music. Trust me on
>   this. So go ahead and be nervous if you want, it
> won't matter at
>   all after that first minute. Bank on that.
> 
> - There is no substitute for a weapons-grade bag of
> records.
> 
> - The sonics are always going to be different, loud,
> and confusing
>   at an actual party. Have powerful headphones. If
> you have any
>   friends with any big sound (not just monitors)
> that you can
>   practice with, it'll be a huge help in training
> your ears.
> 
> - If you fuck up gloriously, and you will, more than
> once, smile,
>   and keep going! They'll cheer you on! No shit.
> 
> - Be into the crowd. Want them to dance like nothing
> you ever wanted
>   in your whole life. It'll show, and baby, they'll
> dance.
> 
> Sean
> 
>

experience while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to 
the time before death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are 
alive, do you think ghosts will do it after?"

the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will 
gradually become visible."

is the high point of your life. Go for it. Work for it. And when it
happens, and it will, relish it, love it, be there, and absolutely
enjoy it like nothing that ever was :).

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] First Timer Advice

> two drinks.  one before your set, then another to
> sip while you're playing. don't have any more until 
> after your set.

this is good advice. don't start slammin' em back to
"take the edge off" even though it might be tempting.
well it was for a drunkass like me at least... the
thing about getting too sauced beforehand is that
you'll *think* you sound awesome when in actuality you
are probably coming off much sloppier than necessary.

the more drinks i down, the "trickier" i tend to get.
sometimes this is fun, but i don't think it's a good
plan for a first time out. 

i would also only drop records that i was really
familiar with. the first time i played out, i knew
every record in that set pretty much backwards and
forwards. it made me feel a lot more comfortable.

good luck, and just have fun.

love,
mo

Subject: [sfraves] 4th of july update

UPDATE!!!!!!
I just talked to the neighbors and found that they will have 2 (two) live 
bands playing  outside(all friends from Expressions music school in 
Emeryville, Psychadelic rock/funk etc.)  This should be somewhat of a repeat 
of lastyear's shindig which was the most fun I have ever had on the 4th.  We 
had around 1300-1500 peeps having a blast on the tiop of YBI
Question: Is there any public transpo?
Answer:  YES!  the 108 "treasure island" leaves from the transbay terminal 
at fremont and 2nd streets (??) right there in downtown.  It usually comes 
every 15 minutes but may be on holiday schedule

Taxi's: YES, find friends the cab ride on avg from SF costs about 15$ but if 
you share a  cab it becomes rediculously cheaper (duh)
I will have my phone on my hip all day so feel free to call on the fourth if 
you need further info or get lost.  I will put some sort of markers down the 
road so we can avoid that from happenning.
Also, if there are concerns about getting rides back, dont fret, there are 
going to be tuns of people heading back to SF later on in the evenning and 
whatnot.  Hope to see you all out here!
if you need info, email me privately or call me if you have my number.
Danny

http://www.live365.com/stations/campwantit

> On 6/29/05, mo corleone <mo_corleone2@yahoo.com> wrote:
> > > two drinks.  one before your set, then another to
> > > sip while you're playing. don't have any more until
> > > after your set.
> >
> > this is good advice. don't start slammin' em back to
> > "take the edge off" even though it might be tempting.
> > well it was for a drunkass like me at least... the
> > thing about getting too sauced beforehand is that
> > you'll *think* you sound awesome when in actuality you
> > are probably coming off much sloppier than necessary.
> >
> > the more drinks i down, the "trickier" i tend to get.
> > sometimes this is fun, but i don't think it's a good
> > plan for a first time out.
> >
> > i would also only drop records that i was really
> > familiar with. the first time i played out, i knew
> > every record in that set pretty much backwards and
> > forwards. it made me feel a lot more comfortable.
> >
> > good luck, and just have fun.
> >
> > love,
> > mo
> >
> >

Subject: [sfraves] No Business, No Copyright

--=====================_3236203==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit


No Business, No Copyright

Patricia R. Zimmermann

<http://www.mediachannel.org>MediaChannel.org

NEW YORK, JUNE 30, 2005  A high stakes civil war rages on your PC. 
But it's not on the Counterstrike computer game. It is between the 
proprietary commercial music industry empire and the file sharing 
freedom fighters. It's a war between intellectual property and fair use.

So argues the audio collage art collective Negativland in their newly 
released multimedia project, No Business (Seeland, 2005).

A multiplatformed, anti-corporate media project, No Business provides 
an operations manual to mobilize the masses and their computers to 
rip, burn, mash, recycle, and intervene into mass culture. A 21st 
century communist manifesto for audio collage, the No Business 
project offers often brilliant polemics against propriety corporate 
culture and copyright.

Negativland camouflages their ignite-the-masses radical politics with 
fun, satire and myriad popular culture references ranging form Ethel 
Merman to the Beatles to Rosie O'Donnell. Uncompromising artistic 
civil disobedience, every image and sound on No Business is 
resolutely illegal.

No Business is about as contrary to easy listening background music 
for a dinner party as you can imagine. It's more like a conceptual 
sonic art piece for headphones, straddling the zones between popular 
culture, activism, music and complex art.

No Business is no cutesy mash-up either. Under the cover of zany, 
seemingly tangential cacophony lurks a compelling, logical and 
surprisingly deductive argument to liberate the public domain from 
corporate colonization. And it insists culture should be free and 
shareda vibrant dose of optimism.

Celebrating their 25th anniversary, the music press has crowned 
Negativland the "elder statesmen" and "merry pranksters" of 
anti-copyright audio collage. Negativland refutes rock star 
auteurism, operating as an artists' collective and rarely identifying 
the so-called band's members.

A hybrid between a political punk rock band and a satirical 
performance art swarming team, Negativland's subversive antics have 
defined interventionist art. They coined the term "culture jammer" in 
1984. They provoked an infamous copyright lawsuit in 1991, when 
Island Records sued them for sampling U2 and recomposing it with 
outtakes from a swearing Casey Kasem. They've wrangled in legal 
scares and skirmishes with the RIAA, Pepsi, Geffen Records, and even 
Phillip Glass.

In 2004, Negativland collaborated with Creative Commons to develop a 
sampling license as an alternative to existing copyright laws. They 
were instrumental in instituting the "no use in advertising" clause.

Negativland's unique aesthetic, a kind of over-caffeinated version of 
Prairie Home Companion on shuffle mode, forges a combustive sonic 
landscape out of tangents, interceptions, and juxtapositions in such 
CDs as Escape from Noise (1987), Helter Stupid (1989) U2 (1991) 
Dispepsi (1997). Besides records, they've produced fine art, videos, 
books, radio shows, and live performances from appropriated sound, 
image and text.

Designed in bright yellow and black, the No Business CD sleeve evokes 
police tape, an allusion to dangerous trespass. The visual 
iconography catalogs the trickster and boundary crossing gods and 
goddesses of spliced and collaged entities from mythology to consumer 
culture: minotaur, unicorn, medusa, sphinx, Wolfman, Batman, Smokey 
the Bear, the Little Mermaid, Elsie the Cow, Frankenstein, Mickey Mouse.

In the 56 page booklet, "Two Relationship to a Cultural Public 
Domain," Negativland advances two worlds at war. The firstand 
clearly the most dangerousadheres to the idea that all cultural work 
is proprietary and requires financial compensation, a position 
identified with the five transnational media corporations that 
control most of the music industry. The secondand for Negativland 
the most creative and democraticengages a culture endlessly 
reproducing, redistributing and remaking itself in free and open 
creative exchange.

Negativland contends digital technology has rendered copyright an 
outmoded legal form. Self-ownership and free exchange may be the 
future of music on the internet. The booklet refutes the music 
industry's standard argument that file sharing eats market shares, 
pointing out impact from declines in long form album production, 
Clear Channel, and consumer migrations to DVD and gaming. The 
internet's open decentralized technology of easy exchange subverts 
corporate control. Negativland advocates for a legal expansion of 
fair use to protect transformative arts practices.

The home computer functions as "the ultimate collage and 
appropriation box," a tool for creative recycling with free access 
for free expression. Outdated, commercially biased copyright 
restrictions constitute prior restraints, censoring creative practice 
and inhibiting social commentary, satire and criticism. The essay 
argues for a politics and aesthetics of transformation--"the logical 
and inalienable right of artists"-- to "enlarge all of our brains in 
a less intellectually constructed environment."

The eight soundscapes on the CD counter the serious arguments of "Two 
Relations" with a wryly ribald and irreverently gutsy sound design 
and recompositionsanother strategy to make the same argument about 
fair use with disconcerting aural juxtapositions and ju-jitsu editing.

"Old is New" creates an eerie, horror film-like environment by 
layering and pitch shifting voices from a Beatles track into a Greek 
chorus. The title cut, "No Business," features an Ethel Merman's 1954 
ode to the entertainment industry "there's no business like show 
business" recut to say "there's no business like stealing."

The almost 10 minute long "Downloading" represents the political tour 
de force of the CD. It interrupts and intercepts President/CEO of the 
National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences Michael Green's 
anti-file sharing and anti-downloading speech from a Grammy Awards 
broadcast with layers of sound dissonance gleaned from BBC News, NPR, 
Elton John and others. Green's choice phrases, like "downloading," 
"worldwide theft and indifference," and "rip, rip, rip" and "entire 
music food chain" are repeated, tweaked, and morphed into what 
amounts to a town hall of oppositional voices.

No Business features a video called Gimme the Mermaid, rendered at 
night on Disney's own computers. The No Business project also 
includes an anti-copyright Whoopee cushion in case you still need to 
be convinced that copyright strangles creativity.

No Business exemplifies a form of radical cultural practice 
straddling between arguments and tangents, analog and digital, 
political polemics and multi-layered mass culture humor. Plundering 
the political unconscious of mass culture, No Business propels the 
listener to refuse culture as propertyand to make something new out 
of the old.

 Patricia R. Zimmermann is the author of Reel Families: A Social 
History of Amateur Film, States of Emergency: Documentaries, Wars, 
Democracies, and co-editor of Mining the Home Movie: Excavations in 
Histories and Memories.


http://www.mediachannel.org/views/dissector/affalert403.shtml




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all 
the money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody 
else in the world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into 
experience while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to 
the time before death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are 
alive, do you think ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of 
the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will 
gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_3236203==.ALT--

Subject: [sfraves] (BSP) Sun July 3rd :: Deep Impact (set times)

Deep Impact, a NASA Discovery Mission, is the first space mission to 
probe beneath the surface of a comet and reveal the secrets of its
interior. The hyper-speed impact between space-borne iceberg and
copper-fortified probe is scheduled for approximately 1:52 a.m. EDT on
Independence Day (10:52 p.m. PDT on July 3). The potentially spectacular
collision will be observed by the Deep Impact spacecraft, and ground and
space-based observatories.
http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/deepimpact/main/

:: Sunday July 3rd from Noon - 8pm ::
Cannabass is back with another day party on Treasure Island, to bring
you a day of Chicago House, Dirty House, Breaks, Drum & Bass, Ragga,
Breakcore and Latin Downtempo

12 Happy (cannabass)
1 Lewt (cannabass)
2 Cutthroat (l.a.b crew)
3 Sheztek (moksha tribe)
4 Andrew Phelan (djandrewphelan.com)
5 Bam (evilbreaks)
6 Brian Walls (ac/stylus)
7 Simas

The park has bbq grills and picnic tables so bring shit to cook up and
drink up, but please be respectful of the space so that we can continue
to use it.

** It can get cold and windy on the Bay, so please bring a jacket so you 
don't freeze! **

Directions:
 From the Bay Bridge:
Hillcrest Rd becomes Treasure Island Rd
Treasure Island Rd becomes Avenue Palms
Right on California
Left on Avenue H
If you hit houses, you went too far on H
It's on the corner of H and 9th
(We're behind the soccer field)
By Bus: Take the 108 to Avenue H and 9th St

--Apple-Mail-2-142639929

	format=flowed

Yes kiddies, there WILL be a test, so please MEMORIZE the information=20
below. seriously.  it potentially could save you a whole lot of misery=20=

when Deputy Roscoe P. Coltrane wants to poke around your General Lee as=20=

you're leaving a party.  you know what i mean.

Have fun, party your brains out for fuck's sake, but PLEASE be safe=20
this summer.

-philip-





A Guide Provided by the Folks at the Rainbow Gathering
=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=
=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=
=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D
This "Rap Sheet" as it's called is NOT legal advice. But, it seems to=20
come from the experience of good folks who want to share that=20
experience.

This rap sheet has been prepared to help you stay out of jail. In the=20
past, we have been the target of unjustified police influence and=20
harassment, often illegal. This rap sheet is a tool. Read and=20
understand it and next time YOU will have the upper hand in the=20
situation.
ROADBLOCKS (DUI CHECKPOINTS, ETC.)

When heading to a gathering, ALWAYS be prepared to deal with the=20
authorities. It is very important that you know your rights before an=20
encounter because this is where most of the coercive tactics and=20
encroachments of rights will take place.

=95 Law enforcement officers are trained to intimidate people into=20
consenting to searches. You may be asked SEVERAL times during the=20
detention if they can search your car or person. ALWAYS refuse and=20
you'll be fine.
=95 The only legal reason they have to search you without arrest is that=20=

they feel they are in danger of being attacked which should not be an=20
issue with us.
=95 If you do find yourself under arrest for any reason, always exercise=20=

your right to silence. Continue to refuse to allow any searches and=20
politely inform them that you will not say anything until your attorney=20=

is present.
=95 Your driver's license, registration and proof of insurance should be=20=

legal and accessible. You will sometimes need all three as the=20
requirement laws vary from state to state. Always assume that you need=20=

all three and you'll never have a problem.
=95 Your car must be road-legal. No broken tail-lights, windshields,=20
headlights, etc. You will be cited for these.
=95 Never leave anything in "plain view." Anything inside the car that =
is=20
visible to the officer is considered to be in "plain view." Although=20
this does not give them the right to search your car, they can=20
confiscate the item and place you under arrest. They will still need to=20=

obtain a warrant to search the rest of your car which will not be very=20=

hard if they found something in plain view.
=95 Never consent to a search of your body or your vehicle. This is your=20=

fourth amendment. The only reason they would ask is that they do not=20
have enough evidence to obtain a search warrant (or they may just be=20
too lazy to get one). JUST SAY NO!!
=95 At Rainbow Gatherings officers have been known to plant drugs in =
cars=20
after consent to search is given. You can avoid this problem by=20
refusing to consent.
=95 If you are harassed or mistreated, write down all the information =
you=20
can about the incident. The officer's county, name, rank, badge number,=20=

etc. Date, time of day, location, etc. Contact one of the organizations=20=

listed at the end of this document to pursue the matter or just file a=20=

complaint with that officer's superior.

OTHER POLICE CONTACT
=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D
=95 It is important to remember a few things about police officers. One=20=

is that they are aware of your rights and they have been known to=20
intentionally violate them. If you find yourself in a situation with an=20=

officer who is out of control, it is best to be submissive in order to=20=

avoid injury or even death. =95 Remember that THEY are ARMED AND=20
DANGEROUS!
=95 If you are stopped by an officer outside of a vehicle, your contact=20=

with him/her will fall into three categories. Consensual contact,=20
detention or arrest. We are mainly concerned with consensual contact=20
and detention as this document is intended to help you in NOT GETTING=20
ARRESTED.

CONSENSUAL CONTACT
------------------
=95  Consensual contact means the officer comes up to you and says, Can =
I=20
speak with you?" If you say "yes," you have consented to have contact=20
with the police. This is not good. When you consent to contact, you=20
waive some of your rights especially if you think you may be guilty of=20=

something. NEVER consent to speak with an officer.
=95 If the officer asks, "can I talk to you," reply with something like=20=

"I'm sorry, I'm in a hurry and don't have time to talk to you right=20
now." If he/she insists, ask, "Are you detaining me? Am I free to=20
leave?" You should ask this several times to make sure the officer will=20=

remember you asking if the encounter results in an arrest and court=20
case. If it is really a consensual contact, the officer is required to=20=

let you go on your way if you ask to. If you don't verbally ask to=20
leave, the court will presume you consented to whatever follows.

DETENTION
---------
=95  The police are only allowed to detain citizens when there are=20
"specific and articulable facts supporting suspicion" (SAF) that you=20
are involved in criminal activity.
=95 This means they can't detain you on a "hunch." They must have=20
observed something about your behavior or character that links you with=20=

specific criminal activity. If you are detained without SAF, you are=20
detained illegally. If this matter ever lands in court, you may be able=20=

to get off because the original detention on their part was illegal.
=95 When you use terms like "detention" and "specific and articulable=20
facts", the officer will usually back down a bit. The majority of a=20
police officer's power in the united states comes from intimidation and=20=

prey on the public=B9s ignorance of its own rights.
It is crucial that you let the officer know that you are not consenting=20=

to talk with him and that the only way you will talk to him is if he=20
detains you which he can not do without SAF.

ARREST
------
=95 If you find yourself under arrest, there's not much left you can do.=20=

You are going to be searched. It is important to continue refusing=20
consent to search your vehicle (if there is one involved) as they will=20=

still need a search warrant to search your vehicle. This, however, will=20=

not be difficult to obtain now that you are under arrest.
=95 By refusing to consent to a search of your vehicle, though, you are=20=

maintaining your position. They may get impatient and search the=20
vehicle without a warrant which is completely illegal. If this happens,=20=

anything they find in the vehicle will not be accepted by the court=20
because it was evidence obtained illegally.
=95 Those are the basics rights you have when involved with the police.=20=

By exercising these rights and using a little common sense, you should=20=

be able to have a safe and happy gathering. Below are some legal=20
contacts you may find yourself in need of if placed under arrest.
For everyday police harassment, call COPWATCH at 510/548-0425.
=95 If you feel your rights were violated or that you are being charged=20=

unjustly, contact the National Office of The American Civil Liberties=20
Union at 132 West 43rd Street, New York, NY 10036. or call=20
212-944-9800.
=95Love your brothers & sisters with guns even when they are misguided.
Know your rights. Spread the light.=

--Apple-Mail-2-142639929--

From sfraves-return-122357-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri Jul 01 02:46:03 2005

Message-ID: <BAY103-F1296D4E6C54D91B37CA55685E20@phx.gbl>

From: "Van Mundegaarde" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>

Date: Thu, 30 Jun 2005 19:45:56 -0700

Subject: RE: [sfraves] A Guide to Dealing with the Po Po

This is one of the bets things I've seen posted on this list thus far.

I was arrested several years ago for a couple of misdemeanor possesion 
charges in Virginia. I had to obtain a lawyer to avoid being sent to jail 
(yes - REALLY - Virginia has archaic laws, and Nazi-esque police), and the 
best advice I got came from my lawyer, and ex police officer.

He said:

A. Cops are NOT (despite what their cars might have written on them) there 
to "protect and serve", they are there to MAKE MONEY FOR THE STATE AND 
COUNTY. EVERYONE is a potential suspect to them. PERIOD.

B. NEVER under ANY circumstances TALK to the police. Give them ONLY 
pertinent information about yourself , name, address, SS# - that's it. Nine 
times out of ten it is YOU who gets yourself arrested because you think that 
if you only tell them certain little things, or god forbid "the truth" , 
that they'll go easy on you. THEY WON'T.

C. Like this post says - NEVER CONSENT TO A SEARCH. If they search you 
WITHOUT your consent, it is ILLEGAL and can be INADMISSABLE as evidence! (I 
myself have seen people walk on charges due to this)

D. Unless you have something ON your person, or maybe *with* something like 
your purse, or wallet, or in your glove box (i.e. something that is 
OBVIOUSLY yours) - they CANNOT prove it is yours. DO NOT own up to it!!!

E. If you're being "detained" - no matter how much they bug you, don't say 
anything other than "Am I under arrest?", because if you're NOT - they have 
to let you go at some point. If you ARE under arrest, remain silent until 
you have spoken with an attorney.

Of course, being smart and not travelling with anything illegal, or having 
illegal things on you is the way to go - but since it DOES happen, be smart 
and be safe.

ez.
~M


>From: Philip.X.Diaz <st_indigo@earthlink.net>
>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org (Yo Momma Wears Mickey Gloves)
>Subject: [sfraves] A Guide to Dealing with the Po Po
>Date: Thu, 30 Jun 2005 19:09:20 -0700
>
>Yes kiddies, there WILL be a test, so please MEMORIZE the information 
>below. seriously.  it potentially could save you a whole lot of misery when 
>Deputy Roscoe P. Coltrane wants to poke around your General Lee as you're 
>leaving a party.  you know what i mean.
>
>Have fun, party your brains out for fuck's sake, but PLEASE be safe this 
>summer.
>
>-philip-
>
>
>
>
>
>A Guide Provided by the Folks at the Rainbow Gathering
>=========================================================
>This "Rap Sheet" as it's called is NOT legal advice. But, it seems to come 
>from the experience of good folks who want to share that experience.
>
>This rap sheet has been prepared to help you stay out of jail. In the past, 
>we have been the target of unjustified police influence and harassment, 
>often illegal. This rap sheet is a tool. Read and understand it and next 
>time YOU will have the upper hand in the situation.
>ROADBLOCKS (DUI CHECKPOINTS, ETC.)
>
>When heading to a gathering, ALWAYS be prepared to deal with the 
>authorities. It is very important that you know your rights before an 
>encounter because this is where most of the coercive tactics and 
>encroachments of rights will take place.
>
> Law enforcement officers are trained to intimidate people into consenting 
>to searches. You may be asked SEVERAL times during the detention if they 
>can search your car or person. ALWAYS refuse and you'll be fine.
> The only legal reason they have to search you without arrest is that they 
>feel they are in danger of being attacked which should not be an issue with 
>us.
> If you do find yourself under arrest for any reason, always exercise your 
>right to silence. Continue to refuse to allow any searches and politely 
>inform them that you will not say anything until your attorney is present.
> Your driver's license, registration and proof of insurance should be 
>legal and accessible. You will sometimes need all three as the requirement 
>laws vary from state to state. Always assume that you need all three and 
>you'll never have a problem.
> Your car must be road-legal. No broken tail-lights, windshields, 
>headlights, etc. You will be cited for these.
> Never leave anything in "plain view." Anything inside the car that is 
>visible to the officer is considered to be in "plain view." Although this 
>does not give them the right to search your car, they can confiscate the 
>item and place you under arrest. They will still need to obtain a warrant 
>to search the rest of your car which will not be very hard if they found 
>something in plain view.
> Never consent to a search of your body or your vehicle. This is your 
>fourth amendment. The only reason they would ask is that they do not have 
>enough evidence to obtain a search warrant (or they may just be too lazy to 
>get one). JUST SAY NO!!
> At Rainbow Gatherings officers have been known to plant drugs in cars 
>after consent to search is given. You can avoid this problem by refusing to 
>consent.
> If you are harassed or mistreated, write down all the information you can 
>about the incident. The officer's county, name, rank, badge number, etc. 
>Date, time of day, location, etc. Contact one of the organizations listed 
>at the end of this document to pursue the matter or just file a complaint 
>with that officer's superior.
>
>OTHER POLICE CONTACT
>=====================
> It is important to remember a few things about police officers. One is 
>that they are aware of your rights and they have been known to 
>intentionally violate them. If you find yourself in a situation with an 
>officer who is out of control, it is best to be submissive in order to 
>avoid injury or even death.  Remember that THEY are ARMED AND DANGEROUS!
> If you are stopped by an officer outside of a vehicle, your contact with 
>him/her will fall into three categories. Consensual contact, detention or 
>arrest. We are mainly concerned with consensual contact and detention as 
>this document is intended to help you in NOT GETTING ARRESTED.
>
>CONSENSUAL CONTACT
>------------------
>  Consensual contact means the officer comes up to you and says, Can I 
>speak with you?" If you say "yes," you have consented to have contact with 
>the police. This is not good. When you consent to contact, you waive some 
>of your rights especially if you think you may be guilty of something. 
>NEVER consent to speak with an officer.
> If the officer asks, "can I talk to you," reply with something like "I'm 
>sorry, I'm in a hurry and don't have time to talk to you right now." If 
>he/she insists, ask, "Are you detaining me? Am I free to leave?" You should 
>ask this several times to make sure the officer will remember you asking if 
>the encounter results in an arrest and court case. If it is really a 
>consensual contact, the officer is required to let you go on your way if 
>you ask to. If you don't verbally ask to leave, the court will presume you 
>consented to whatever follows.
>
>DETENTION
>---------
>  The police are only allowed to detain citizens when there are "specific 
>and articulable facts supporting suspicion" (SAF) that you are involved in 
>criminal activity.
> This means they can't detain you on a "hunch." They must have observed 
>something about your behavior or character that links you with specific 
>criminal activity. If you are detained without SAF, you are detained 
>illegally. If this matter ever lands in court, you may be able to get off 
>because the original detention on their part was illegal.
> When you use terms like "detention" and "specific and articulable facts", 
>the officer will usually back down a bit. The majority of a police 
>officer's power in the united states comes from intimidation and prey on 
>the publics ignorance of its own rights.
>It is crucial that you let the officer know that you are not consenting to 
>talk with him and that the only way you will talk to him is if he detains 
>you which he can not do without SAF.
>
>ARREST
>------
> If you find yourself under arrest, there's not much left you can do. You 
>are going to be searched. It is important to continue refusing consent to 
>search your vehicle (if there is one involved) as they will still need a 
>search warrant to search your vehicle. This, however, will not be difficult 
>to obtain now that you are under arrest.
> By refusing to consent to a search of your vehicle, though, you are 
>maintaining your position. They may get impatient and search the vehicle 
>without a warrant which is completely illegal. If this happens, anything 
>they find in the vehicle will not be accepted by the court because it was 
>evidence obtained illegally.
> Those are the basics rights you have when involved with the police. By 
>exercising these rights and using a little common sense, you should be able 
>to have a safe and happy gathering. Below are some legal contacts you may 
>find yourself in need of if placed under arrest.
>For everyday police harassment, call COPWATCH at 510/548-0425.
> If you feel your rights were violated or that you are being charged 
>unjustly, contact the National Office of The American Civil Liberties Union 
>at 132 West 43rd Street, New York, NY 10036. or call 212-944-9800.
>Love your brothers & sisters with guns even when they are misguided.
>Know your rights. Spread the light.

_________________________________________________________________
Dont just search. Find. Check out the new MSN Search! 
http://search.msn.click-url.com/go/onm00200636ave/direct/01/
